3
4#include "qrhi_p_p.h"
5#include <qmath.h>
6#include <QLoggingCategory>
7
8#include "qrhinull_p_p.h"
9#ifndef QT_NO_OPENGL
10#include "qrhigles2_p_p.h"
11#endif
12#if QT_CONFIG(vulkan)
13#include "qrhivulkan_p_p.h"
14#endif
15#ifdef Q_OS_WIN
16#include "qrhid3d11_p_p.h"
17#endif
18#if defined(Q_OS_MACOS) || defined(Q_OS_IOS)
19#include "qrhimetal_p_p.h"
20#endif
21
22#include <memory>
23
24QT_BEGIN_NAMESPACE
25
26Q_LOGGING_CATEGORY(QRHI_LOG_INFO, "qt.rhi.general")
27
28/*!
29 \class QRhi
30 \internal
31 \inmodule QtGui
32
33 \brief Accelerated 2D/3D graphics API abstraction.
34
35 The Qt Rendering Hardware Interface is an abstraction for hardware accelerated
36 graphics APIs, such as, \l{https://www.khronos.org/opengl/}{OpenGL},
37 \l{https://www.khronos.org/opengles/}{OpenGL ES},
38 \l{https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/direct3d}{Direct3D},
39 \l{https://developer.apple.com/metal/}{Metal}, and
40 \l{https://www.khronos.org/vulkan/}{Vulkan}.
41
42 Some of the main design goals are:
43
44 \list
45
46 \li Simple, minimal, understandable, extensible. Follow the proven path of the
47 Qt Quick scenegraph.
48
49 \li Aim to be a product - and in the bigger picture, part of a product (Qt) -
50 that is usable out of the box both by internal (such as, Qt Quick) and,
51 eventually, external users.
52
53 \li Not a complete 1:1 wrapper for any of the underlying APIs. The feature set
54 is tuned towards the needs of Qt's 2D and 3D offering (QPainter, Qt Quick, Qt
55 3D Studio). Iterate and evolve in a sustainable manner.
56
57 \li Intrinsically cross-platform, without reinventing: abstracting
58 cross-platform aspects of certain APIs (such as, OpenGL context creation and
59 windowing system interfaces, Vulkan instance and surface management) is not in
60 scope here. These are delegated to the existing QtGui facilities (QWindow,
61 QOpenGLContext, QVulkanInstance) and its backing QPA architecture.
62
63 \endlist
64
65 Each QRhi instance is backed by a backend for a specific graphics API. The
66 selection of the backend is a run time choice and is up to the application
67 or library that creates the QRhi instance. Some backends are available on
68 multiple platforms (OpenGL, Vulkan, Null), while APIs specific to a given
69 platform are only available when running on the platform in question (Metal
70 on macOS/iOS/tvOS, Direct3D on Windows).
71
72 The available backends currently are:
73
74 \list
75
76 \li OpenGL 2.1 or OpenGL ES 2.0 or newer. Some extensions are utilized when
77 present, for example to enable multisample framebuffers.
78
79 \li Direct3D 11.1
80
81 \li Metal
82
83 \li Vulkan 1.0, optionally with some extensions that are part of Vulkan 1.1
84
85 \li Null - A "dummy" backend that issues no graphics calls at all.
86
87 \endlist
88
89 In order to allow shader code to be written once in Qt applications and
90 libraries, all shaders are expected to be written in a single language
91 which is then compiled into SPIR-V. Versions for various shading language
92 are then generated from that, together with reflection information (inputs,
93 outputs, shader resources). This is then packed into easily and efficiently
94 serializable QShader instances. The compilers and tools to generate such
95 shaders are not part of QRhi, but the core classes for using such shaders,
96 QShader and QShaderDescription, are.
97
98 \section2 Design Fundamentals
99
100 A QRhi cannot be instantiated directly. Instead, use the create()
101 function. Delete the QRhi instance normally to release the graphics device.
102
103 \section3 Resources
104
105 Instances of classes deriving from QRhiResource, such as, QRhiBuffer,
106 QRhiTexture, etc., encapsulate zero, one, or more native graphics
107 resources. Instances of such classes are always created via the \c new
108 functions of the QRhi, such as, newBuffer(), newTexture(),
109 newTextureRenderTarget(), newSwapChain().
110
111 \badcode
112 vbuf = rhi->newBuffer(QRhiBuffer::Immutable, QRhiBuffer::VertexBuffer, sizeof(vertexData));
113 if (!vbuf->create()) { error }
114 ...
115 delete vbuf;
116 \endcode
117
118 \list
119
120 \li The returned value from functions like newBuffer() is always owned by
121 the caller.
122
123 \li Just creating a QRhiResource subclass never allocates or initializes any
124 native resources. That is only done when calling the \c create() function of a
125 subclass, for example, QRhiBuffer::create() or QRhiTexture::create().
126
127 \li The exceptions are
128 QRhiTextureRenderTarget::newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor(),
129 QRhiSwapChain::newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor(), and
130 QRhiRenderPassDescriptor::newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor(). There is no
131 \c create() operation for these and the returned object is immediately
132 active.
133
134 \li The resource objects themselves are treated as immutable: once a
135 resource has create() called, changing any parameters via the setters, such as,
136 QRhiTexture::setPixelSize(), has no effect, unless the underlying native
137 resource is released and \c create() is called again. See more about resource
138 reuse in the sections below.
139
140 \li The underlying native resources are scheduled for releasing by the
141 QRhiResource destructor, or by calling QRhiResource::destroy(). Backends
142 often queue release requests and defer executing them to an unspecified
143 time, this is hidden from the applications. This way applications do not
144 have to worry about releasing native resources that may still be in use by
145 an in-flight frame.
146
147 \li Note that this does not mean that a QRhiResource can freely be
148 destroy()'ed or deleted within a frame (that is, in a
149 \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::beginFrame()}{beginFrame()} -
150 \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::endFrame()}{endFrame()} section). As a general rule,
151 all referenced QRhiResource objects must stay unchanged until the frame is
152 submitted by calling \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::endFrame()}{endFrame()}. To ease
153 this, QRhiResource::deleteLater() is provided as a convenience.
154
155 \endlist
156
157 \section3 Command buffers and deferred command execution
158
159 Regardless of the design and capabilities of the underlying graphics API,
160 all QRhi backends implement some level of command buffers. No
161 QRhiCommandBuffer function issues any native bind or draw command (such as,
162 \c glDrawElements) directly. Commands are always recorded in a queue,
163 either native or provided by the QRhi backend. The command buffer is
164 submitted, and so execution starts only upon QRhi::endFrame() or
165 QRhi::finish().
166
167 The deferred nature has consequences for some types of objects. For example,
168 writing to a dynamic buffer multiple times within a frame, in case such
169 buffers are backed by host-visible memory, will result in making the
170 results of all writes are visible to all draw calls in the command buffer
171 of the frame, regardless of when the dynamic buffer update was recorded
172 relative to a draw call.
173
174 Furthermore, instances of QRhiResource subclasses must be treated immutable
175 within a frame in which they are referenced in any way. Create
176 all resources upfront, before starting to record commands for the next
177 frame. Reusing a QRhiResource instance within a frame (by calling \c create()
178 then referencing it again in the same \c{beginFrame - endFrame} section)
179 should be avoided as it may lead to unexpected results, depending on the
180 backend.
181
182 As a general rule, all referenced QRhiResource objects must stay valid and
183 unmodified until the frame is submitted by calling
184 \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::endFrame()}{endFrame()}. On the other hand, calling
185 \l{QRhiResource::destroy()}{destroy()} or deleting the QRhiResource are
186 always safe once the frame is submitted, regardless of the status of the
187 underlying native resources (which may still be in use by the GPU - but
188 that is taken care of internally).
189
190 Unlike APIs like OpenGL, upload and copy type of commands cannot be mixed
191 with draw commands. The typical renderer will involve a sequence similar to
192 the following: \c{(re)create resources} - \c{begin frame} - \c{record
193 uploads and copies} - \c{start renderpass} - \c{record draw calls} - \c{end
194 renderpass} - \c{end frame}. Recording copy type of operations happens via
195 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch. Such operations are committed typically on
196 \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::beginPass()}{beginPass()}.
197
198 When working with legacy rendering engines designed for OpenGL, the
199 migration to QRhi often involves redesigning from having a single \c render
200 step (that performs copies and uploads, clears buffers, and issues draw
201 calls, all mixed together) to a clearly separated, two phase \c prepare -
202 \c render setup where the \c render step only starts a renderpass and
203 records draw calls, while all resource creation and queuing of updates,
204 uploads and copies happens beforehand, in the \c prepare step.
205
206 QRhi does not at the moment allow freely creating and submitting command
207 buffers. This may be lifted in the future to some extent, in particular if
208 compute support is introduced, but the model of well defined
209 \c{frame-start} and \c{frame-end} points, combined with a dedicated,
210 "frame" command buffer, where \c{frame-end} implies presenting, is going to
211 remain the primary way of operating since this is what fits Qt's various UI
212 technologies best.
213
214 \section3 Threading
215
216 A QRhi instance and the associated resources can be created and used on any
217 thread but all usage must be limited to that one single thread. When
218 rendering to multiple QWindows in an application, having a dedicated thread
219 and QRhi instance for each window is often advisable, as this can eliminate
220 issues with unexpected throttling caused by presenting to multiple windows.
221 Conceptually that is then the same as how Qt Quick scene graph's threaded
222 render loop operates when working directly with OpenGL: one thread for each
223 window, one QOpenGLContext for each thread. When moving onto QRhi,
224 QOpenGLContext is replaced by QRhi, making the migration straightforward.
225
226 When it comes to externally created native objects, such as OpenGL contexts
227 passed in via QRhiGles2NativeHandles, it is up to the application to ensure
228 they are not misused by other threads.
229
230 Resources are not shareable between QRhi instances. This is an intentional
231 choice since QRhi hides most queue, command buffer, and resource
232 synchronization related tasks, and provides no API for them. Safe and
233 efficient concurrent use of graphics resources from multiple threads is
234 tied to those concepts, however, and is thus a topic that is currently out
235 of scope, but may be introduced in the future.
236
237 \note The Metal backend requires that an autorelease pool is available on
238 the rendering thread, ideally wrapping each iteration of the render loop.
239 This needs no action from the users of QRhi when rendering on the main
240 (gui) thread, but becomes important when a separate, dedicated render
241 thread is used.
242
243 \section3 Resource synchronization
244
245 QRhi does not expose APIs for resource barriers or image layout
246 transitions. Such synchronization is done implicitly by the backends, where
247 applicable (for example, Vulkan), by tracking resource usage as necessary.
248 Buffer and image barriers are inserted before render or compute passes
249 transparently to the application.
250
251 \note Resources within a render or compute pass are expected to be bound to
252 a single usage during that pass. For example, a buffer can be used as
253 vertex, index, uniform, or storage buffer, but not a combination of them
254 within a single pass. However, it is perfectly fine to use a buffer as a
255 storage buffer in a compute pass, and then as a vertex buffer in a render
256 pass, for example, assuming the buffer declared both usages upon creation.
257
258 \note Textures have this rule relaxed in certain cases, because using two
259 subresources (typically two different mip levels) of the same texture for
260 different access (one for load, one for store) is supported even within the
261 same pass.
262
263 \section3 Resource reuse
264
265 From the user's point of view a QRhiResource is reusable immediately after
266 calling QRhiResource::destroy(). With the exception of swapchains, calling
267 \c create() on an already created object does an implicit \c destroy(). This
268 provides a handy shortcut to reuse a QRhiResource instance with different
269 parameters, with a new native graphics object underneath.
270
271 The importance of reusing the same object lies in the fact that some
272 objects reference other objects: for example, a QRhiShaderResourceBindings
273 can reference QRhiBuffer, QRhiTexture, and QRhiSampler instances. If in a
274 later frame one of these buffers need to be resized or a sampler parameter
275 needs changing, destroying and creating a whole new QRhiBuffer or
276 QRhiSampler would invalidate all references to the old instance. By just
277 changing the appropriate parameters via QRhiBuffer::setSize() or similar
278 and then calling QRhiBuffer::create(), everything works as expected and
279 there is no need to touch the QRhiShaderResourceBindings at all, even
280 though there is a good chance that under the hood the QRhiBuffer is now
281 backed by a whole new native buffer.
282
283 \badcode
284 ubuf = rhi->newBuffer(QRhiBuffer::Dynamic, QRhiBuffer::UniformBuffer, 256);
285 ubuf->create();
286
287 srb = rhi->newShaderResourceBindings()
288 srb->setBindings({
289 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBuffer(0, QRhiShaderResourceBinding::VertexStage | QRhiShaderResourceBinding::FragmentStage, ubuf)
290 });
291 srb->create();
292
293 ...
294
295 // now in a later frame we need to grow the buffer to a larger size
296 ubuf->setSize(512);
297 ubuf->create(); // same as ubuf->destroy(); ubuf->create();
298
299 // That's it, srb needs no changes whatsoever, any references in it to
300 // ubuf stay valid. When it comes to internal details, such as that
301 // ubuf may now be backed by a completely different native buffer
302 // resource, that is is recognized and handled automatically by the
303 // next setShaderResources().
304 \endcode
305
306 QRhiTextureRenderTarget offers the same contract: calling
307 QRhiCommandBuffer::beginPass() is safe even when one of the render target's
308 associated textures or renderbuffers has been rebuilt (by calling \c
309 create() on it) since the creation of the render target object. This allows
310 the application to resize a texture by setting a new pixel size on the
311 QRhiTexture and calling create(), thus creating a whole new native texture
312 resource underneath, without having to update the QRhiTextureRenderTarget
313 as that will be done implicitly in beginPass().
314
315 \section3 Pooled objects
316
317 In addition to resources, there are pooled objects as well, such as,
318 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch. An instance is retrieved via a \c next function,
319 such as, nextResourceUpdateBatch(). The caller does not own the returned
320 instance in this case. The only valid way of operating here is calling
321 functions on the QRhiResourceUpdateBatch and then passing it to
322 QRhiCommandBuffer::beginPass() or QRhiCommandBuffer::endPass(). These
323 functions take care of returning the batch to the pool. Alternatively, a
324 batch can be "canceled" and returned to the pool without processing by
325 calling QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::destroy().
326
327 A typical pattern is thus:
328
329 \badcode
330 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *resUpdates = rhi->nextResourceUpdateBatch();
331 ...
332 resUpdates->updateDynamicBuffer(ubuf, 0, 64, mvp.constData());
333 if (!image.isNull()) {
334 resUpdates->uploadTexture(texture, image);
335 image = QImage();
336 }
337 ...
338 QRhiCommandBuffer *cb = m_sc->currentFrameCommandBuffer();
339 cb->beginPass(swapchain->currentFrameRenderTarget(), clearCol, clearDs, resUpdates);
340 \endcode
341
342 \section3 Swapchain specifics
343
344 QRhiSwapChain features some special semantics due to the peculiar nature of
345 swapchains.
346
347 \list
348
349 \li It has no \c create() but rather a QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize().
350 Repeatedly calling this function is \b not the same as calling
351 QRhiSwapChain::destroy() followed by QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize(). This
352 is because swapchains often have ways to handle the case where buffers need
353 to be resized in a manner that is more efficient than a brute force
354 destroying and recreating from scratch.
355
356 \li An active QRhiSwapChain must be released by calling
357 \l{QRhiSwapChain::destroy()}{destroy()}, or by destroying the object, before
358 the QWindow's underlying QPlatformWindow, and so the associated native
359 window object, is destroyed. It should not be postponed because releasing
360 the swapchain may become problematic (and with some APIs, like Vulkan, is
361 explicitly disallowed) when the native window is not around anymore, for
362 example because the QPlatformWindow got destroyed upon getting a
363 QWindow::close(). Therefore, releasing the swapchain must happen whenever
364 the targeted QWindow sends the
365 QPlatformSurfaceEvent::SurfaceAboutToBeDestroyed event. If the event does
366 not arrive before the destruction of the QWindow - this can happen when
367 using QCoreApplication::quit() -, then check QWindow::handle() after the
368 event loop exits and invoke the swapchain release when non-null (meaning
369 the underlying native window is still around).
370
371 \endlist
372
373 \section3 Ownership
374
375 The general rule is no ownership transfer. Creating a QRhi with an already
376 existing graphics device does not mean the QRhi takes ownership of the
377 device object. Similarly, ownership is not given away when a device or
378 texture object is "exported" via QRhi::nativeHandles() or
379 QRhiTexture::nativeHandles(). Most importantly, passing pointers in structs
380 and via setters does not transfer ownership.
381
382 \section2 Troubleshooting
383
384 Errors are printed to the output via qWarning(). Additional debug messages
385 can be enabled via the following logging categories. Messages from these
386 categories are not printed by default unless explicitly enabled via
387 QLoggingCategory or the \c QT_LOGGING_RULES environment variable.
388
389 \list
390 \li \c{qt.rhi.general}
391 \endlist
392
393 It is strongly advised to inspect the output with the logging categories
394 (\c{qt.rhi.*}) enabled whenever a QRhi-based application is not behaving as
395 expected. For better interoperation with Qt Quick, the environment variable
396 \c{QSG_INFO} also enables these debug prints.
397 */
398
399/*!
400 \enum QRhi::Implementation
401 Describes which graphics API-specific backend gets used by a QRhi instance.
402
403 \value Null
404 \value Vulkan
405 \value OpenGLES2
406 \value D3D11
407 \value Metal
408 */
409
410/*!
411 \enum QRhi::Flag
412 Describes what special features to enable.
413
414 \value EnableProfiling This flag has currently no effect.
415
416 \value EnableDebugMarkers Enables debug marker groups. Without this frame
417 debugging features like making debug groups and custom resource name
418 visible in external GPU debugging tools will not be available and functions
419 like QRhiCommandBuffer::debugMarkBegin() will become a no-op. Avoid
420 enabling in production builds as it may involve a performance penalty.
421
422 \value PreferSoftwareRenderer Indicates that backends should prefer
423 choosing an adapter or physical device that renders in software on the CPU.
424 For example, with Direct3D there is typically a "Basic Render Driver"
425 adapter available with \c{DXGI_ADAPTER_FLAG_SOFTWARE}. Setting this flag
426 requests the backend to choose that adapter over any other, as long as no
427 specific adapter was forced by other backend-specific means. With Vulkan
428 this maps to preferring physical devices with
429 \c{VK_PHYSICAL_DEVICE_TYPE_CPU}. When not available, or when it is not
430 possible to decide if an adapter/device is software-based, this flag is
431 ignored. It may also be ignored with graphics APIs that have no concept and
432 means of enumerating adapters/devices.
433
434 \value EnablePipelineCacheDataSave Enables retrieving the pipeline cache
435 contents, where applicable. When not set, pipelineCacheData() will return
436 an empty blob always. With backends where retrieving and restoring the
437 pipeline cache contents is not supported, the flag has no effect and the
438 serialized cache data is always empty. The flag provides an opt-in
439 mechanism because the cost of maintaining the related data structures is
440 not insignificant with some backends. With Vulkan this feature maps
441 directly to VkPipelineCache, vkGetPipelineCacheData and
442 VkPipelineCacheCreateInfo::pInitialData. With D3D11 there is no real
443 pipline cache, but the results of HLSL->DXBC compilations are stored and
444 can be serialized/deserialized via this mechanism. This allows skipping the
445 time consuming D3DCompile() in future runs of the applications for shaders
446 that come with HLSL source instead of offline pre-compiled bytecode. This
447 can provide a huge boost in startup and load times, if there is a lot of
448 HLSL source compilation happening. With OpenGL the "pipeline cache" is
449 simulated by retrieving and loading shader program binaries (if supported
450 by the driver). With OpenGL there are additional, disk-based caching
451 mechanisms for shader/program binaries provided by Qt. Writing to those may
452 get disabled whenever this flag is set since storing program binaries to
453 multiple caches is not sensible.
454 */
455
456/*!
457 \enum QRhi::FrameOpResult
458 Describes the result of operations that can have a soft failure.
459
460 \value FrameOpSuccess Success
461
462 \value FrameOpError Unspecified error
463
464 \value FrameOpSwapChainOutOfDate The swapchain is in an inconsistent state
465 internally. This can be recoverable by attempting to repeat the operation
466 (such as, beginFrame()) later.
467
468 \value FrameOpDeviceLost The graphics device was lost. This can be
469 recoverable by attempting to repeat the operation (such as, beginFrame())
470 after releasing and reinitializing all objects backed by native graphics
471 resources. See isDeviceLost().
472 */
473
474/*!
475 \enum QRhi::Feature
476 Flag values to indicate what features are supported by the backend currently in use.
477
478 \value MultisampleTexture Indicates that textures with a sample count larger
479 than 1 are supported. In practice this feature will be unsupported with
480 OpenGL ES versions older than 3.1, and OpenGL older than 3.0.
481
482 \value MultisampleRenderBuffer Indicates that renderbuffers with a sample
483 count larger than 1 are supported. In practice this feature will be
484 unsupported with OpenGL ES 2.0, and may also be unsupported with OpenGL 2.x
485 unless the relevant extensions are present.
486
487 \value DebugMarkers Indicates that debug marker groups (and so
488 QRhiCommandBuffer::debugMarkBegin()) are supported.
489
490 \value Timestamps Indicates that command buffer timestamps are supported.
491 Relevant for addGpuFrameTimeCallback(). Can be expected to be supported on
492 D3D11 and Vulkan, assuming the underlying implementation supports it.
493
494 \value Instancing Indicates that instanced drawing is supported. In
495 practice this feature will be unsupported with OpenGL ES 2.0 and OpenGL
496 3.2 or older.
497
498 \value CustomInstanceStepRate Indicates that instance step rates other
499 than 1 are supported. In practice this feature will always be unsupported
500 with OpenGL. In addition, running with Vulkan 1.0 without
501 VK_EXT_vertex_attribute_divisor will also lead to reporting false for this
502 feature.
503
504 \value PrimitiveRestart Indicates that restarting the assembly of
505 primitives when encountering an index value of 0xFFFF
506 (\l{QRhiCommandBuffer::IndexUInt16}{IndexUInt16}) or 0xFFFFFFFF
507 (\l{QRhiCommandBuffer::IndexUInt32}{IndexUInt32}) is enabled, for certain
508 primitive topologies at least. QRhi will try to enable this with all
509 backends, but in some cases it will not be supported. Dynamically
510 controlling primitive restart is not possible since with some APIs
511 primitive restart with a fixed index is always on. Applications must assume
512 that whenever this feature is reported as supported, the above mentioned
513 index values \c may be treated specially, depending on the topology. The
514 only two topologies where primitive restart is guaranteed to behave
515 identically across backends, as long as this feature is reported as
516 supported, are \l{QRhiGraphicsPipeline::LineStrip}{LineStrip} and
517 \l{QRhiGraphicsPipeline::TriangleStrip}{TriangleStrip}.
518
519 \value NonDynamicUniformBuffers Indicates that creating buffers with the
520 usage \l{QRhiBuffer::UniformBuffer}{UniformBuffer} and the types
521 \l{QRhiBuffer::Immutable}{Immutable} or \l{QRhiBuffer::Static}{Static} is
522 supported. When reported as unsupported, uniform (constant) buffers must be
523 created as \l{QRhiBuffer::Dynamic}{Dynamic}. (which is recommended
524 regardless)
525
526 \value NonFourAlignedEffectiveIndexBufferOffset Indicates that effective
527 index buffer offsets (\c{indexOffset + firstIndex * indexComponentSize})
528 that are not 4 byte aligned are supported. When not supported, attempting
529 to issue a \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::drawIndexed()}{drawIndexed()} with a
530 non-aligned effective offset may lead to unspecified behavior. Relevant in
531 particular for Metal, where this will be reported as unsupported.
532
533 \value NPOTTextureRepeat Indicates that the
534 \l{QRhiSampler::Repeat}{Repeat} wrap mode and mipmap filtering modes are
535 supported for textures with a non-power-of-two size. In practice this can
536 only be false with OpenGL ES 2.0 implementations without
537 \c{GL_OES_texture_npot}.
538
539 \value RedOrAlpha8IsRed Indicates that the
540 \l{QRhiTexture::RED_OR_ALPHA8}{RED_OR_ALPHA8} format maps to a one
541 component 8-bit \c red format. This is the case for all backends except
542 OpenGL when using either OpenGL ES or a non-core profile context. There
543 \c{GL_ALPHA}, a one component 8-bit \c alpha format, is used
544 instead. Using the special texture format allows having a single code
545 path for creating textures, leaving it up to the backend to decide the
546 actual format, while the feature flag can be used to pick the
547 appropriate shader variant for sampling the texture.
548
549 \value ElementIndexUint Indicates that 32-bit unsigned integer elements are
550 supported in the index buffer. In practice this is true everywhere except
551 when running on plain OpenGL ES 2.0 implementations without the necessary
552 extension. When false, only 16-bit unsigned elements are supported in the
553 index buffer.
554
555 \value Compute Indicates that compute shaders, image load/store, and
556 storage buffers are supported. OpenGL older than 4.3 and OpenGL ES older
557 than 3.1 have no compute support.
558
559 \value WideLines Indicates that lines with a width other than 1 are
560 supported. When reported as not supported, the line width set on the
561 graphics pipeline state is ignored. This can always be false with some
562 backends (D3D11, Metal). With Vulkan, the value depends on the
563 implementation. With OpenGL, wide lines are not supported in core profile
564 contexts.
565
566 \value VertexShaderPointSize Indicates that the size of rasterized points
567 set via \c{gl_PointSize} in the vertex shader is taken into account. When
568 reported as not supported, drawing points with a size other than 1 is not
569 supported. Setting \c{gl_PointSize} in the shader is still valid then, but
570 is ignored. (for example, when generating HLSL, the assignment is silently
571 dropped from the generated code) Note that some APIs (Metal, Vulkan)
572 require the point size to be set in the shader explicitly whenever drawing
573 points, even when the size is 1, as they do not automatically default to 1.
574
575 \value BaseVertex Indicates that
576 \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::drawIndexed()}{drawIndexed()} supports the \c
577 vertexOffset argument. When reported as not supported, the vertexOffset
578 value in an indexed draw is ignored. In practice this feature will be
579 unsupported with OpenGL and OpenGL ES versions lower than 3.2, and with
580 Metal on older iOS devices, including the iOS Simulator.
581
582 \value BaseInstance Indicates that instanced draw commands support the \c
583 firstInstance argument. When reported as not supported, the firstInstance
584 value is ignored and the instance ID starts from 0. In practice this feature
585 will be unsupported with OpenGL, and with Metal on older iOS devices,
586 including the iOS Simulator.
587
588 \value TriangleFanTopology Indicates that QRhiGraphicsPipeline::setTopology()
589 supports QRhiGraphicsPipeline::TriangleFan. In practice this feature will be
590 unsupported with Metal and Direct 3D 11.
591
592 \value ReadBackNonUniformBuffer Indicates that
593 \l{QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::readBackBuffer()}{reading buffer contents} is
594 supported for QRhiBuffer instances with a usage different than
595 UniformBuffer. In practice this feature will be unsupported with OpenGL ES
596 2.0.
597
598 \value ReadBackNonBaseMipLevel Indicates that specifying a mip level other
599 than 0 is supported when reading back texture contents. When not supported,
600 specifying a non-zero level in QRhiReadbackDescription leads to returning
601 an all-zero image. In practice this feature will be unsupported with OpenGL
602 ES 2.0.
603
604 \value TexelFetch Indicates that texelFetch() and textureLod() are available
605 in shaders. In practice this will be reported as unsupported with OpenGL ES
606 2.0 and OpenGL 2.x contexts, because GLSL 100 es and versions before 130 do
607 not support these functions.
608
609 \value RenderToNonBaseMipLevel Indicates that specifying a mip level other
610 than 0 is supported when creating a QRhiTextureRenderTarget with a
611 QRhiTexture as its color attachment. When not supported, create() will fail
612 whenever the target mip level is not zero. In practice this feature will be
613 unsupported with OpenGL ES 2.0.
614
615 \value IntAttributes Indicates that specifying input attributes with
616 signed and unsigned integer types for a shader pipeline is supported. When
617 not supported, build() will succeed but just show a warning message and the
618 values of the target attributes will be broken. In practice this feature
619 will be unsupported with OpenGL ES 2.0 and OpenGL 2.x.
620
621 \value ScreenSpaceDerivatives Indicates that functions such as dFdx(),
622 dFdy(), and fwidth() are supported in shaders. In practice this feature will
623 be unsupported with OpenGL ES 2.0 without the GL_OES_standard_derivatives
624 extension.
625
626 \value ReadBackAnyTextureFormat Indicates that reading back texture
627 contents can be expected to work for any QRhiTexture::Format. Backends
628 other than OpenGL can be expected to return true for this feature. When
629 reported as false, which will typically happen with OpenGL, only the
630 formats QRhiTexture::RGBA8 and QRhiTexture::BGRA8 are guaranteed to be
631 supported for readbacks. In addition, with OpenGL, but not OpenGL ES,
632 reading back the 1 byte per component formats QRhiTexture::R8 and
633 QRhiTexture::RED_OR_ALPHA8 are supported as well. Reading back floating
634 point formats QRhiTexture::RGBA16F and RGBA32F may work too with OpenGL, as
635 long as the implementation provides support for these, but QRhi can give no
636 guarantees, as indicated by this flag.
637
638 \value PipelineCacheDataLoadSave Indicates that the pipelineCacheData() and
639 setPipelineCacheData() functions are functional. When not supported, the
640 functions will not perform any action, the retrieved blob is always empty,
641 and thus no benefits can be expected from retrieving and, during a
642 subsequent run of the application, reloading the pipeline cache content.
643
644 \value ImageDataStride Indicates that specifying a custom stride (row
645 length) for raw image data in texture uploads is supported. When not
646 supported (which can happen when the underlying API is OpenGL ES 2.0 without
647 support for GL_UNPACK_ROW_LENGTH),
648 QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription::setDataStride() must not be used.
649
650 \value RenderBufferImport Indicates that QRhiRenderBuffer::createFrom() is
651 supported. For most graphics APIs this is not sensible because
652 QRhiRenderBuffer encapsulates texture objects internally, just like
653 QRhiTexture. With OpenGL however, renderbuffer object exist as a separate
654 object type in the API, and in certain environments (for example, where one
655 may want to associated a renderbuffer object with an EGLImage object) it is
656 important to allow wrapping an existing OpenGL renderbuffer object with a
657 QRhiRenderBuffer.
658
659 \value ThreeDimensionalTextures Indicates that 3D textures are supported.
660 In practice this feature will be unsupported with OpenGL and OpenGL ES
661 versions lower than 3.0.
662
663 \value RenderTo3DTextureSlice Indicates that rendering to a slice in a 3D
664 texture is supported. This can be unsupported with Vulkan 1.0 due to
665 relying on VK_IMAGE_CREATE_2D_ARRAY_COMPATIBLE_BIT which is a Vulkan 1.1
666 feature.
667
668 \value TextureArrays Indicates that texture arrays are supported and
669 QRhi::newTextureArray() is functional. Note that even when texture arrays
670 are not supported, arrays of textures are still available as those are two
671 independent features.
672
673 \value Tessellation Indicates that the tessellation control and evaluation
674 stages are supported. When reported as supported, the topology of a
675 QRhiGraphicsPipeline can be set to
676 \l{QRhiGraphicsPipeline::Patches}{Patches}, the number of control points
677 can be set via
678 \l{QRhiGraphicsPipeline::setPatchControlPointCount()}{setPatchControlPointCount()},
679 and shaders for tessellation control and evaluation can be specified in the
680 QRhiShaderStage list. Tessellation shaders have portability issues between
681 APIs (for example, translating GLSL/SPIR-V to HLSL is problematic due to
682 the way hull shaders are structured, whereas Metal uses a somewhat
683 different tessellation pipeline than others), and therefore unexpected
684 issues may still arise, even though basic functionality is implemented
685 across all the underlying APIs. For Direct 3D in particular, handwritten
686 HLSL hull and domain shaders must be injected into each QShader for the
687 tessellation control and evaluation stages, respectively, since qsb cannot
688 generate these from SPIR-V. Note that isoline tessellation should be
689 avoided as it will not be supported by all backends. The maximum patch
690 control point count portable between backends is 32.
691
692 \value GeometryShader Indicates that the geometry shader stage is
693 supported. When supported, a geometry shader can be specified in the
694 QRhiShaderStage list. Geometry Shaders are considered an experimental
695 feature in QRhi and can only be expected to be supported with Vulkan,
696 Direct 3D, OpenGL (3.2+) and OpenGL ES (3.2+), assuming the implementation
697 reports it as supported at run time. Geometry shaders have portability
698 issues between APIs, and therefore no guarantees can be given for a
699 universal solution. They will never be supported with Metal. Whereas with
700 Direct 3D a handwritten HLSL geometry shader must be injected into each
701 QShader for the geometry stage since qsb cannot generate this from SPIR-V.
702
703 \value TextureArrayRange Indicates that for
704 \l{QRhi::newTextureArray()}{texture arrays} it is possible to specify a
705 range that is exposed to the shaders. Normally all array layers are exposed
706 and it is up to the shader to select the layer (via the third coordinate
707 passed to texture() when sampling the \c sampler2DArray). When supported,
708 calling QRhiTexture::setArrayRangeStart() and
709 QRhiTexture::setArrayRangeLength() before
710 \l{QRhiTexture::create()}{building} or
711 \l{QRhiTexture::createFrom()}{importing} the native texture has an effect,
712 and leads to selecting only the specified range from the array. This will
713 be necessary in special cases, such as when working with accelerated video
714 decoding and Direct 3D 11, because a texture array with both
715 \c{D3D11_BIND_DECODER} and \c{D3D11_BIND_SHADER_RESOURCE} on it is only
716 usable as a shader resource if a single array layer is selected. Note that
717 all this is applicable only when the texture is used as a
718 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::SampledTexture or
719 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::Texture shader resource, and is not compatible
720 with image load/store. This feature is only available with some backends as
721 it does not map well to all graphics APIs, and it is only meant to provide
722 support for special cases anyhow. In practice the feature can be expected to
723 be supported with Direct3D 11 and Vulkan.
724
725 \value NonFillPolygonMode Indicates that setting a PolygonMode other than
726 the default Fill is supported for QRhiGraphicsPipeline. A common use case
727 for changing the mode to Line is to get wireframe rendering. This however
728 is not available as a core OpenGL ES feature, and is optional with Vulkan
729 as well as some mobile GPUs may not offer the feature.
730
731 \value OneDimensionalTextures Indicates that 1D textures are supported.
732 In practice this feature will be unsupported on OpenGL ES.
733
734 \value OneDimensionalTextureMipmaps Indicates that 1D texture mipmaps and
735 1D texture render targets are supported. In practice this feature will be
736 unsupported on backends that do not report support for
737 \l{OneDimensionalTextures}, and Metal.
738
739 */
740
741/*!
742 \enum QRhi::BeginFrameFlag
743 Flag values for QRhi::beginFrame()
744 */
745
746/*!
747 \enum QRhi::EndFrameFlag
748 Flag values for QRhi::endFrame()
749
750 \value SkipPresent Specifies that no present command is to be queued or no
751 swapBuffers call is to be made. This way no image is presented. Generating
752 multiple frames with all having this flag set is not recommended (except,
753 for example, for benchmarking purposes - but keep in mind that backends may
754 behave differently when it comes to waiting for command completion without
755 presenting so the results are not comparable between them)
756 */
757
758/*!
759 \enum QRhi::ResourceLimit
760 Describes the resource limit to query.
761
762 \value TextureSizeMin Minimum texture width and height. This is typically
763 1. The minimum texture size is handled gracefully, meaning attempting to
764 create a texture with an empty size will instead create a texture with the
765 minimum size.
766
767 \value TextureSizeMax Maximum texture width and height. This depends on the
768 graphics API and sometimes the platform or implementation as well.
769 Typically the value is in the range 4096 - 16384. Attempting to create
770 textures larger than this is expected to fail.
771
772 \value MaxColorAttachments The maximum number of color attachments for a
773 QRhiTextureRenderTarget, in case multiple render targets are supported. When
774 MRT is not supported, the value is 1. Otherwise this is typically 8, but
775 watch out for the fact that OpenGL only mandates 4 as the minimum, and that
776 is what some OpenGL ES implementations provide.
777
778 \value FramesInFlight The number of frames the backend may keep "in
779 flight": with backends like Vulkan or Metal, it is the responsibility of
780 QRhi to block whenever starting a new frame and finding the CPU is already
781 \c{N - 1} frames ahead of the GPU (because the command buffer submitted in
782 frame no. \c{current} - \c{N} has not yet completed). The value N is what
783 is returned from here, and is typically 2. This can be relevant to
784 applications that integrate rendering done directly with the graphics API,
785 as such rendering code may want to perform double (if the value is 2)
786 buffering for resources, such as, buffers, similarly to the QRhi backends
787 themselves. The current frame slot index (a value running 0, 1, .., N-1,
788 then wrapping around) is retrievable from QRhi::currentFrameSlot(). The
789 value is 1 for backends where the graphics API offers no such low level
790 control over the command submission process. Note that pipelining may still
791 happen even when this value is 1 (some backends, such as D3D11, are
792 designed to attempt to enable this, for instance, by using an update
793 strategy for uniform buffers that does not stall the pipeline), but that is
794 then not controlled by QRhi and so not reflected here in the API.
795
796 \value MaxAsyncReadbackFrames The number of \l{QRhi::endFrame()}{submitted}
797 frames (including the one that contains the readback) after which an
798 asynchronous texture or buffer readback is guaranteed to complete upon
799 \l{QRhi::beginFrame()}{starting a new frame}.
800
801 \value MaxThreadGroupsPerDimension The maximum number of compute
802 work/thread groups that can be dispatched. Effectively the maximum value
803 for the arguments of QRhiCommandBuffer::dispatch(). Typically 65535.
804
805 \value MaxThreadsPerThreadGroup The maximum number of invocations in a
806 single local work group, or in other terminology, the maximum number of
807 threads in a thread group. Effectively the maximum value for the product of
808 \c local_size_x, \c local_size_y, and \c local_size_z in the compute
809 shader. Typical values are 128, 256, 512, 1024, or 1536. Watch out that
810 both OpenGL ES and Vulkan specify only 128 as the minimum required limit
811 for implementations. While uncommon for Vulkan, some OpenGL ES 3.1
812 implementations for mobile/embedded devices only support the spec-mandated
813 minimum value.
814
815 \value MaxThreadGroupX The maximum size of a work/thread group in the X
816 dimension. Effectively the maximum value of \c local_size_x in the compute
817 shader. Typically 256 or 1024.
818
819 \value MaxThreadGroupY The maximum size of a work/thread group in the Y
820 dimension. Effectively the maximum value of \c local_size_y in the compute
821 shader. Typically 256 or 1024.
822
823 \value MaxThreadGroupZ The maximum size of a work/thread group in the Z
824 dimension. Effectively the maximum value of \c local_size_z in the compute
825 shader. Typically 64 or 256.
826
827 \value TextureArraySizeMax Maximum texture array size. Typically in range
828 256 - 2048. Attempting to \l{QRhi::newTextureArray()}{create a texture
829 array} with more elements will likely fail.
830
831 \value MaxUniformBufferRange The number of bytes that can be exposed from a
832 uniform buffer to the shaders at once. On OpenGL ES 2.0 and 3.0
833 implementations this may be as low as 3584 bytes (224 four component, 32
834 bits per component vectors). Elsewhere the value is typically 16384 (1024
835 vec4s) or 65536 (4096 vec4s).
836
837 \value MaxVertexInputs The number of input attributes to the vertex shader.
838 The location in a QRhiVertexInputAttribute must be in range \c{[0,
839 MaxVertexInputs-1]}. The value may be as low as 8 with OpenGL ES 2.0.
840 Elsewhere, typical values are 16, 31, or 32.
841
842 \value MaxVertexOutputs The maximum number of outputs (4 component vector
843 \c out variables) from the vertex shader. The value may be as low as 8 with
844 OpenGL ES 2.0, and 15 with OpenGL ES 3.0 and some Metal devices. Elsewhere,
845 a typical value is 32.
846 */
847
848/*!
849 \class QRhiInitParams
850 \internal
851 \inmodule QtGui
852 \brief Base class for backend-specific initialization parameters.
853
854 Contains fields that are relevant to all backends.
855 */
856
857/*!
858 \class QRhiDepthStencilClearValue
859 \internal
860 \inmodule QtGui
861 \brief Specifies clear values for a depth or stencil buffer.
862 */
863
864/*!
865 \fn QRhiDepthStencilClearValue::QRhiDepthStencilClearValue()
866
867 Constructs a depth/stencil clear value with depth clear value 1.0f and
868 stencil clear value 0.
869 */
870
871/*!
872 Constructs a depth/stencil clear value with depth clear value \a d and
873 stencil clear value \a s.
874 */
875QRhiDepthStencilClearValue::QRhiDepthStencilClearValue(float d, quint32 s)
876 : m_d(d),
877 m_s(s)
878{
879}
880
881/*!
882 \return \c true if the values in the two QRhiDepthStencilClearValue objects
883 \a a and \a b are equal.
884
885 \relates QRhiDepthStencilClearValue
886 */
887bool operator==(const QRhiDepthStencilClearValue &a, const QRhiDepthStencilClearValue &b) noexcept
888{
889 return a.depthClearValue() == b.depthClearValue()
890 && a.stencilClearValue() == b.stencilClearValue();
891}
892
893/*!
894 \return \c false if the values in the two QRhiDepthStencilClearValue
895 objects \a a and \a b are equal; otherwise returns \c true.
896
897 \relates QRhiDepthStencilClearValue
898*/
899bool operator!=(const QRhiDepthStencilClearValue &a, const QRhiDepthStencilClearValue &b) noexcept
900{
901 return !(a == b);
902}
903
904/*!
905 \return the hash value for \a v, using \a seed to seed the calculation.
906
907 \relates QRhiDepthStencilClearValue
908 */
909size_t qHash(const QRhiDepthStencilClearValue &v, size_t seed) noexcept
910{
911 return seed * (uint(qFloor(v: qreal(v.depthClearValue()) * 100)) + v.stencilClearValue());
912}
913
914#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
915QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiDepthStencilClearValue &v)
916{
917 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
918 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiDepthStencilClearValue(depth-clear=" << v.depthClearValue()
919 << " stencil-clear=" << v.stencilClearValue()
920 << ')';
921 return dbg;
922}
923#endif
924
925/*!
926 \class QRhiViewport
927 \internal
928 \inmodule QtGui
929 \brief Specifies a viewport rectangle.
930
931 Used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setViewport().
932
933 QRhi assumes OpenGL-style viewport coordinates, meaning x and y are
934 bottom-left. Negative width or height are not allowed.
935
936 Typical usage is like the following:
937
938 \badcode
939 const QSize outputSizeInPixels = swapchain->currentPixelSize();
940 const QRhiViewport viewport(0, 0, outputSizeInPixels.width(), outputSizeInPixels.height());
941 cb->beginPass(swapchain->currentFrameRenderTarget(), { 0, 0, 0, 1 }, { 1, 0 });
942 cb->setGraphicsPipeline(ps);
943 cb->setViewport(viewport);
944 ...
945 \endcode
946
947 \sa QRhiCommandBuffer::setViewport(), QRhi::clipSpaceCorrMatrix(), QRhiScissor
948 */
949
950/*!
951 \fn QRhiViewport::QRhiViewport()
952
953 Constructs a viewport description with an empty rectangle and a depth range
954 of 0.0f - 1.0f.
955
956 \sa QRhi::clipSpaceCorrMatrix()
957 */
958
959/*!
960 Constructs a viewport description with the rectangle specified by \a x, \a
961 y, \a w, \a h and the depth range \a minDepth and \a maxDepth.
962
963 \note \a x and \a y are assumed to be the bottom-left position. \a w and \a
964 h should not be negative, the viewport will be ignored by
965 QRhiCommandBuffer::setViewport() otherwise.
966
967 \sa QRhi::clipSpaceCorrMatrix()
968 */
969QRhiViewport::QRhiViewport(float x, float y, float w, float h, float minDepth, float maxDepth)
970 : m_rect { ._M_elems: { x, y, w, h } },
971 m_minDepth(minDepth),
972 m_maxDepth(maxDepth)
973{
974}
975
976/*!
977 \return \c true if the values in the two QRhiViewport objects
978 \a a and \a b are equal.
979
980 \relates QRhiViewport
981 */
982bool operator==(const QRhiViewport &a, const QRhiViewport &b) noexcept
983{
984 return a.viewport() == b.viewport()
985 && a.minDepth() == b.minDepth()
986 && a.maxDepth() == b.maxDepth();
987}
988
989/*!
990 \return \c false if the values in the two QRhiViewport
991 objects \a a and \a b are equal; otherwise returns \c true.
992
993 \relates QRhiViewport
994*/
995bool operator!=(const QRhiViewport &a, const QRhiViewport &b) noexcept
996{
997 return !(a == b);
998}
999
1000/*!
1001 \return the hash value for \a v, using \a seed to seed the calculation.
1002
1003 \relates QRhiViewport
1004 */
1005size_t qHash(const QRhiViewport &v, size_t seed) noexcept
1006{
1007 const std::array<float, 4> r = v.viewport();
1008 return seed + uint(r[0]) + uint(r[1]) + uint(r[2]) + uint(r[3])
1009 + uint(qFloor(v: qreal(v.minDepth()) * 100)) + uint(qFloor(v: qreal(v.maxDepth()) * 100));
1010}
1011
1012#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
1013QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiViewport &v)
1014{
1015 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
1016 const std::array<float, 4> r = v.viewport();
1017 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiViewport(bottom-left-x=" << r[0]
1018 << " bottom-left-y=" << r[1]
1019 << " width=" << r[2]
1020 << " height=" << r[3]
1021 << " minDepth=" << v.minDepth()
1022 << " maxDepth=" << v.maxDepth()
1023 << ')';
1024 return dbg;
1025}
1026#endif
1027
1028/*!
1029 \class QRhiScissor
1030 \internal
1031 \inmodule QtGui
1032 \brief Specifies a scissor rectangle.
1033
1034 Used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setScissor(). Setting a scissor rectangle is
1035 only possible with a QRhiGraphicsPipeline that has
1036 QRhiGraphicsPipeline::UsesScissor set.
1037
1038 QRhi assumes OpenGL-style scissor coordinates, meaning x and y are
1039 bottom-left. Negative width or height are not allowed. However, apart from
1040 that, the flexible OpenGL semantics apply: negative x and y, partially out
1041 of bounds rectangles, etc. will be handled gracefully, clamping as
1042 appropriate. Therefore, any rendering logic targeting OpenGL can feed
1043 scissor rectangles into QRhiScissor as-is, without any adaptation.
1044
1045 \sa QRhiCommandBuffer::setScissor(), QRhiViewport
1046 */
1047
1048/*!
1049 \fn QRhiScissor::QRhiScissor()
1050
1051 Constructs an empty scissor.
1052 */
1053
1054/*!
1055 Constructs a scissor with the rectangle specified by \a x, \a y, \a w, and
1056 \a h.
1057
1058 \note \a x and \a y are assumed to be the bottom-left position. Negative \a w
1059 or \a h are not allowed, such scissor rectangles will be ignored by
1060 QRhiCommandBuffer. Other than that, the flexible OpenGL semantics apply:
1061 negative x and y, partially out of bounds rectangles, etc. will be handled
1062 gracefully, clamping as appropriate.
1063 */
1064QRhiScissor::QRhiScissor(int x, int y, int w, int h)
1065 : m_rect { ._M_elems: { x, y, w, h } }
1066{
1067}
1068
1069/*!
1070 \return \c true if the values in the two QRhiScissor objects
1071 \a a and \a b are equal.
1072
1073 \relates QRhiScissor
1074 */
1075bool operator==(const QRhiScissor &a, const QRhiScissor &b) noexcept
1076{
1077 return a.scissor() == b.scissor();
1078}
1079
1080/*!
1081 \return \c false if the values in the two QRhiScissor
1082 objects \a a and \a b are equal; otherwise returns \c true.
1083
1084 \relates QRhiScissor
1085*/
1086bool operator!=(const QRhiScissor &a, const QRhiScissor &b) noexcept
1087{
1088 return !(a == b);
1089}
1090
1091/*!
1092 \return the hash value for \a v, using \a seed to seed the calculation.
1093
1094 \relates QRhiScissor
1095 */
1096size_t qHash(const QRhiScissor &v, size_t seed) noexcept
1097{
1098 const std::array<int, 4> r = v.scissor();
1099 return seed + uint(r[0]) + uint(r[1]) + uint(r[2]) + uint(r[3]);
1100}
1101
1102#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
1103QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiScissor &s)
1104{
1105 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
1106 const std::array<int, 4> r = s.scissor();
1107 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiScissor(bottom-left-x=" << r[0]
1108 << " bottom-left-y=" << r[1]
1109 << " width=" << r[2]
1110 << " height=" << r[3]
1111 << ')';
1112 return dbg;
1113}
1114#endif
1115
1116/*!
1117 \class QRhiVertexInputBinding
1118 \internal
1119 \inmodule QtGui
1120 \brief Describes a vertex input binding.
1121
1122 Specifies the stride (in bytes, must be a multiple of 4), the
1123 classification and optionally the instance step rate.
1124
1125 As an example, assume a vertex shader with the following inputs:
1126
1127 \badcode
1128 layout(location = 0) in vec4 position;
1129 layout(location = 1) in vec2 texcoord;
1130 \endcode
1131
1132 Now let's assume also that 3 component vertex positions \c{(x, y, z)} and 2
1133 component texture coordinates \c{(u, v)} are provided in a non-interleaved
1134 format in a buffer (or separate buffers even). Defining two bindings
1135 could then be done like this:
1136
1137 \badcode
1138 QRhiVertexInputLayout inputLayout;
1139 inputLayout.setBindings({
1140 { 3 * sizeof(float) },
1141 { 2 * sizeof(float) }
1142 });
1143 \endcode
1144
1145 Only the stride is interesting here since instancing is not used. The
1146 binding number is given by the index of the QRhiVertexInputBinding
1147 element in the bindings vector of the QRhiVertexInputLayout.
1148
1149 Once a graphics pipeline with this vertex input layout is bound, the vertex
1150 inputs could be set up like the following for drawing a cube with 36
1151 vertices, assuming we have a single buffer with first the positions and
1152 then the texture coordinates:
1153
1154 \badcode
1155 const QRhiCommandBuffer::VertexInput vbufBindings[] = {
1156 { cubeBuf, 0 },
1157 { cubeBuf, 36 * 3 * sizeof(float) }
1158 };
1159 cb->setVertexInput(0, 2, vbufBindings);
1160 \endcode
1161
1162 Note how the index defined by \c {startBinding + i}, where \c i is the
1163 index in the second argument of
1164 \l{QRhiCommandBuffer::setVertexInput()}{setVertexInput()}, matches the
1165 index of the corresponding entry in the \c bindings vector of the
1166 QRhiVertexInputLayout.
1167
1168 \note the stride must always be a multiple of 4.
1169
1170 \sa QRhiCommandBuffer::setVertexInput()
1171 */
1172
1173/*!
1174 \enum QRhiVertexInputBinding::Classification
1175 Describes the input data classification.
1176
1177 \value PerVertex Data is per-vertex
1178 \value PerInstance Data is per-instance
1179 */
1180
1181/*!
1182 \fn QRhiVertexInputBinding::QRhiVertexInputBinding()
1183
1184 Constructs a default vertex input binding description.
1185 */
1186
1187/*!
1188 Constructs a vertex input binding description with the specified \a stride,
1189 classification \a cls, and instance step rate \a stepRate.
1190
1191 \note \a stepRate other than 1 is only supported when
1192 QRhi::CustomInstanceStepRate is reported to be supported.
1193 */
1194QRhiVertexInputBinding::QRhiVertexInputBinding(quint32 stride, Classification cls, quint32 stepRate)
1195 : m_stride(stride),
1196 m_classification(cls),
1197 m_instanceStepRate(stepRate)
1198{
1199}
1200
1201/*!
1202 \return \c true if the values in the two QRhiVertexInputBinding objects
1203 \a a and \a b are equal.
1204
1205 \relates QRhiVertexInputBinding
1206 */
1207bool operator==(const QRhiVertexInputBinding &a, const QRhiVertexInputBinding &b) noexcept
1208{
1209 return a.stride() == b.stride()
1210 && a.classification() == b.classification()
1211 && a.instanceStepRate() == b.instanceStepRate();
1212}
1213
1214/*!
1215 \return \c false if the values in the two QRhiVertexInputBinding
1216 objects \a a and \a b are equal; otherwise returns \c true.
1217
1218 \relates QRhiVertexInputBinding
1219*/
1220bool operator!=(const QRhiVertexInputBinding &a, const QRhiVertexInputBinding &b) noexcept
1221{
1222 return !(a == b);
1223}
1224
1225/*!
1226 \return the hash value for \a v, using \a seed to seed the calculation.
1227
1228 \relates QRhiVertexInputBinding
1229 */
1230size_t qHash(const QRhiVertexInputBinding &v, size_t seed) noexcept
1231{
1232 return seed + v.stride() + v.classification();
1233}
1234
1235#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
1236QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiVertexInputBinding &b)
1237{
1238 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
1239 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiVertexInputBinding(stride=" << b.stride()
1240 << " cls=" << b.classification()
1241 << " step-rate=" << b.instanceStepRate()
1242 << ')';
1243 return dbg;
1244}
1245#endif
1246
1247/*!
1248 \class QRhiVertexInputAttribute
1249 \internal
1250 \inmodule QtGui
1251 \brief Describes a single vertex input element.
1252
1253 The members specify the binding number, location, format, and offset for a
1254 single vertex input element.
1255
1256 \note For HLSL it is assumed that the vertex shader uses
1257 \c{TEXCOORD<location>} as the semantic for each input. Hence no separate
1258 semantic name and index.
1259
1260 As an example, assume a vertex shader with the following inputs:
1261
1262 \badcode
1263 layout(location = 0) in vec4 position;
1264 layout(location = 1) in vec2 texcoord;
1265 \endcode
1266
1267 Now let's assume that we have 3 component vertex positions \c{(x, y, z)}
1268 and 2 component texture coordinates \c{(u, v)} are provided in a
1269 non-interleaved format in a buffer (or separate buffers even). Once two
1270 bindings are defined, the attributes could be specified as:
1271
1272 \badcode
1273 QRhiVertexInputLayout inputLayout;
1274 inputLayout.setBindings({
1275 { 3 * sizeof(float) },
1276 { 2 * sizeof(float) }
1277 });
1278 inputLayout.setAttributes({
1279 { 0, 0, QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float3, 0 },
1280 { 1, 1, QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float2, 0 }
1281 });
1282 \endcode
1283
1284 Once a graphics pipeline with this vertex input layout is bound, the vertex
1285 inputs could be set up like the following for drawing a cube with 36
1286 vertices, assuming we have a single buffer with first the positions and
1287 then the texture coordinates:
1288
1289 \badcode
1290 const QRhiCommandBuffer::VertexInput vbufBindings[] = {
1291 { cubeBuf, 0 },
1292 { cubeBuf, 36 * 3 * sizeof(float) }
1293 };
1294 cb->setVertexInput(0, 2, vbufBindings);
1295 \endcode
1296
1297 When working with interleaved data, there will typically be just one
1298 binding, with multiple attributes referring to that same buffer binding
1299 point:
1300
1301 \badcode
1302 QRhiVertexInputLayout inputLayout;
1303 inputLayout.setBindings({
1304 { 5 * sizeof(float) }
1305 });
1306 inputLayout.setAttributes({
1307 { 0, 0, QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float3, 0 },
1308 { 0, 1, QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float2, 3 * sizeof(float) }
1309 });
1310 \endcode
1311
1312 and then:
1313
1314 \badcode
1315 const QRhiCommandBuffer::VertexInput vbufBinding(interleavedCubeBuf, 0);
1316 cb->setVertexInput(0, 1, &vbufBinding);
1317 \endcode
1318
1319 \sa QRhiCommandBuffer::setVertexInput()
1320 */
1321
1322/*!
1323 \enum QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Format
1324 Specifies the type of the element data.
1325
1326 \value Float4 Four component float vector
1327 \value Float3 Three component float vector
1328 \value Float2 Two component float vector
1329 \value Float Float
1330 \value UNormByte4 Four component normalized unsigned byte vector
1331 \value UNormByte2 Two component normalized unsigned byte vector
1332 \value UNormByte Normalized unsigned byte
1333 \value UInt4 Four component unsigned integer vector
1334 \value UInt3 Three component unsigned integer vector
1335 \value UInt2 Two component unsigned integer vector
1336 \value UInt Unsigned integer
1337 \value SInt4 Four component signed integer vector
1338 \value SInt3 Three component signed integer vector
1339 \value SInt2 Two component signed integer vector
1340 \value SInt Signed integer
1341 */
1342
1343/*!
1344 \fn QRhiVertexInputAttribute::QRhiVertexInputAttribute()
1345
1346 Constructs a default vertex input attribute description.
1347 */
1348
1349/*!
1350 Constructs a vertex input attribute description with the specified \a
1351 binding number, \a location, \a format, and \a offset.
1352
1353 \a matrixSlice should be -1 except when this attribute corresponds to a row
1354 or column of a matrix (for example, a 4x4 matrix becomes 4 vec4s, consuming
1355 4 consecutive vertex input locations), in which case it is the index of the
1356 row or column. \c{location - matrixSlice} must always be equal to the \c
1357 location for the first row or column of the unrolled matrix.
1358 */
1359QRhiVertexInputAttribute::QRhiVertexInputAttribute(int binding, int location, Format format, quint32 offset, int matrixSlice)
1360 : m_binding(binding),
1361 m_location(location),
1362 m_format(format),
1363 m_offset(offset),
1364 m_matrixSlice(matrixSlice)
1365{
1366}
1367
1368/*!
1369 \return \c true if the values in the two QRhiVertexInputAttribute objects
1370 \a a and \a b are equal.
1371
1372 \relates QRhiVertexInputAttribute
1373 */
1374bool operator==(const QRhiVertexInputAttribute &a, const QRhiVertexInputAttribute &b) noexcept
1375{
1376 return a.binding() == b.binding()
1377 && a.location() == b.location()
1378 && a.format() == b.format()
1379 && a.offset() == b.offset();
1380}
1381
1382/*!
1383 \return \c false if the values in the two QRhiVertexInputAttribute
1384 objects \a a and \a b are equal; otherwise returns \c true.
1385
1386 \relates QRhiVertexInputAttribute
1387*/
1388bool operator!=(const QRhiVertexInputAttribute &a, const QRhiVertexInputAttribute &b) noexcept
1389{
1390 return !(a == b);
1391}
1392
1393/*!
1394 \return the hash value for \a v, using \a seed to seed the calculation.
1395
1396 \relates QRhiVertexInputAttribute
1397 */
1398size_t qHash(const QRhiVertexInputAttribute &v, size_t seed) noexcept
1399{
1400 return seed + uint(v.binding()) + uint(v.location()) + uint(v.format()) + v.offset();
1401}
1402
1403#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
1404QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiVertexInputAttribute &a)
1405{
1406 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
1407 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiVertexInputAttribute(binding=" << a.binding()
1408 << " location=" << a.location()
1409 << " format=" << a.format()
1410 << " offset=" << a.offset()
1411 << ')';
1412 return dbg;
1413}
1414#endif
1415
1416QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Format QRhiImplementation::shaderDescVariableFormatToVertexInputFormat(QShaderDescription::VariableType type) const
1417{
1418 switch (type) {
1419 case QShaderDescription::Vec4:
1420 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float4;
1421 case QShaderDescription::Vec3:
1422 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float3;
1423 case QShaderDescription::Vec2:
1424 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float2;
1425 case QShaderDescription::Float:
1426 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float;
1427
1428 case QShaderDescription::Int4:
1429 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt4;
1430 case QShaderDescription::Int3:
1431 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt3;
1432 case QShaderDescription::Int2:
1433 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt2;
1434 case QShaderDescription::Int:
1435 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt;
1436
1437 case QShaderDescription::Uint4:
1438 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt4;
1439 case QShaderDescription::Uint3:
1440 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt3;
1441 case QShaderDescription::Uint2:
1442 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt2;
1443 case QShaderDescription::Uint:
1444 return QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt;
1445
1446 default:
1447 Q_UNREACHABLE_RETURN(QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float);
1448 }
1449}
1450
1451quint32 QRhiImplementation::byteSizePerVertexForVertexInputFormat(QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Format format) const
1452{
1453 switch (format) {
1454 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float4:
1455 return 4 * sizeof(float);
1456 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float3:
1457 return 4 * sizeof(float); // vec3 still takes 16 bytes
1458 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float2:
1459 return 2 * sizeof(float);
1460 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float:
1461 return sizeof(float);
1462
1463 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UNormByte4:
1464 return 4 * sizeof(quint8);
1465 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UNormByte2:
1466 return 2 * sizeof(quint8);
1467 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UNormByte:
1468 return sizeof(quint8);
1469
1470 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt4:
1471 return 4 * sizeof(quint32);
1472 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt3:
1473 return 4 * sizeof(quint32); // ivec3 still takes 16 bytes
1474 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt2:
1475 return 2 * sizeof(quint32);
1476 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::UInt:
1477 return sizeof(quint32);
1478
1479 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt4:
1480 return 4 * sizeof(qint32);
1481 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt3:
1482 return 4 * sizeof(qint32); // uvec3 still takes 16 bytes
1483 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt2:
1484 return 2 * sizeof(qint32);
1485 case QRhiVertexInputAttribute::SInt:
1486 return sizeof(qint32);
1487
1488 default:
1489 Q_UNREACHABLE_RETURN(1);
1490 }
1491}
1492
1493/*!
1494 \class QRhiVertexInputLayout
1495 \internal
1496 \inmodule QtGui
1497 \brief Describes the layout of vertex inputs consumed by a vertex shader.
1498
1499 The vertex input layout is defined by the collections of
1500 QRhiVertexInputBinding and QRhiVertexInputAttribute.
1501 */
1502
1503/*!
1504 \fn QRhiVertexInputLayout::QRhiVertexInputLayout()
1505
1506 Constructs an empty vertex input layout description.
1507 */
1508
1509/*!
1510 \return \c true if the values in the two QRhiVertexInputLayout objects
1511 \a a and \a b are equal.
1512
1513 \relates QRhiVertexInputLayout
1514 */
1515bool operator==(const QRhiVertexInputLayout &a, const QRhiVertexInputLayout &b) noexcept
1516{
1517 return a.m_bindings == b.m_bindings && a.m_attributes == b.m_attributes;
1518}
1519
1520/*!
1521 \return \c false if the values in the two QRhiVertexInputLayout
1522 objects \a a and \a b are equal; otherwise returns \c true.
1523
1524 \relates QRhiVertexInputLayout
1525*/
1526bool operator!=(const QRhiVertexInputLayout &a, const QRhiVertexInputLayout &b) noexcept
1527{
1528 return !(a == b);
1529}
1530
1531/*!
1532 \return the hash value for \a v, using \a seed to seed the calculation.
1533
1534 \relates QRhiVertexInputLayout
1535 */
1536size_t qHash(const QRhiVertexInputLayout &v, size_t seed) noexcept
1537{
1538 return qHash(key: v.m_bindings, seed) + qHash(key: v.m_attributes, seed);
1539}
1540
1541#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
1542QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiVertexInputLayout &v)
1543{
1544 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
1545 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiVertexInputLayout(bindings=" << v.m_bindings
1546 << " attributes=" << v.m_attributes
1547 << ')';
1548 return dbg;
1549}
1550#endif
1551
1552/*!
1553 \class QRhiShaderStage
1554 \internal
1555 \inmodule QtGui
1556 \brief Specifies the type and the shader code for a shader stage in the pipeline.
1557 */
1558
1559/*!
1560 \enum QRhiShaderStage::Type
1561 Specifies the type of the shader stage.
1562
1563 \value Vertex Vertex stage
1564
1565 \value TessellationControlStage Tessellation control (hull shader) stage.
1566 Must be used only when the QRhi::Tessellation feature is supported.
1567
1568 \value TessellationEvaluationStage Tessellation evaluation (domain shader)
1569 stage. Must be used only when the QRhi::Tessellation feature is supported.
1570
1571 \value Fragment Fragment (pixel shader) stage
1572
1573 \value Compute Compute stage. Must be used only when the QRhi::Compute
1574 feature is supported.
1575
1576 \value Geometry Geometry stage. Must be used only when the
1577 QRhi::GeometryShader feature is supported.
1578 */
1579
1580/*!
1581 \fn QRhiShaderStage::QRhiShaderStage()
1582
1583 Constructs a shader stage description for the vertex stage with an empty
1584 QShader.
1585 */
1586
1587/*!
1588 Constructs a shader stage description with the \a type of the stage and the
1589 \a shader.
1590
1591 The shader variant \a v defaults to QShader::StandardShader. A
1592 QShader contains multiple source and binary versions of a shader.
1593 In addition, it can also contain variants of the shader with slightly
1594 modified code. \a v can then be used to select the desired variant.
1595 */
1596QRhiShaderStage::QRhiShaderStage(Type type, const QShader &shader, QShader::Variant v)
1597 : m_type(type),
1598 m_shader(shader),
1599 m_shaderVariant(v)
1600{
1601}
1602
1603/*!
1604 \return \c true if the values in the two QRhiShaderStage objects
1605 \a a and \a b are equal.
1606
1607 \relates QRhiShaderStage
1608 */
1609bool operator==(const QRhiShaderStage &a, const QRhiShaderStage &b) noexcept
1610{
1611 return a.type() == b.type()
1612 && a.shader() == b.shader()
1613 && a.shaderVariant() == b.shaderVariant();
1614}
1615
1616/*!
1617 \return \c false if the values in the two QRhiShaderStage
1618 objects \a a and \a b are equal; otherwise returns \c true.
1619
1620 \relates QRhiShaderStage
1621*/
1622bool operator!=(const QRhiShaderStage &a, const QRhiShaderStage &b) noexcept
1623{
1624 return !(a == b);
1625}
1626
1627/*!
1628 \return the hash value for \a v, using \a seed to seed the calculation.
1629
1630 \relates QRhiShaderStage
1631 */
1632size_t qHash(const QRhiShaderStage &v, size_t seed) noexcept
1633{
1634 return v.type() + qHash(s: v.shader(), seed) + v.shaderVariant();
1635}
1636
1637#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
1638QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiShaderStage &s)
1639{
1640 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
1641 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiShaderStage(type=" << s.type()
1642 << " shader=" << s.shader()
1643 << " variant=" << s.shaderVariant()
1644 << ')';
1645 return dbg;
1646}
1647#endif
1648
1649/*!
1650 \class QRhiColorAttachment
1651 \internal
1652 \inmodule QtGui
1653 \brief Describes the a single color attachment of a render target.
1654
1655 A color attachment is either a QRhiTexture or a QRhiRenderBuffer. The
1656 former, when texture() is set, is used in most cases.
1657
1658 \note texture() and renderBuffer() cannot be both set (be non-null at the
1659 same time).
1660
1661 Setting renderBuffer instead is recommended only when multisampling is
1662 needed. Relying on QRhi::MultisampleRenderBuffer is a better choice than
1663 QRhi::MultisampleTexture in practice since the former is available in more
1664 run time configurations (e.g. when running on OpenGL ES 3.0 which has no
1665 support for multisample textures, but does support multisample
1666 renderbuffers).
1667
1668 When targeting a non-multisample texture, the layer() and level() indicate
1669 the targeted layer (face index \c{0-5} for cubemaps) and mip level. For 3D
1670 textures layer() specifies the slice (one 2D image within the 3D texture)
1671 to render to. For texture arrays layer() is the array index.
1672
1673 When texture() or renderBuffer() is multisample, resolveTexture() can be
1674 set optionally. When set, samples are resolved automatically into that
1675 (non-multisample) texture at the end of the render pass. When rendering
1676 into a multisample renderbuffers, this is the only way to get resolved,
1677 non-multisample content out of them. Multisample textures allow sampling in
1678 shaders so for them this is just one option.
1679
1680 \note when resolving is enabled, the multisample data may not be written
1681 out at all. This means that the multisample texture() must not be used
1682 afterwards with shaders for sampling when resolveTexture() is set.
1683 */
1684
1685/*!
1686 \fn QRhiColorAttachment::QRhiColorAttachment()
1687
1688 Constructs an empty color attachment description.
1689 */
1690
1691/*!
1692 Constructs a color attachment description that specifies \a texture as the
1693 associated color buffer.
1694 */
1695QRhiColorAttachment::QRhiColorAttachment(QRhiTexture *texture)
1696 : m_texture(texture)
1697{
1698}
1699
1700/*!
1701 Constructs a color attachment description that specifies \a renderBuffer as
1702 the associated color buffer.
1703 */
1704QRhiColorAttachment::QRhiColorAttachment(QRhiRenderBuffer *renderBuffer)
1705 : m_renderBuffer(renderBuffer)
1706{
1707}
1708
1709/*!
1710 \class QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription
1711 \internal
1712 \inmodule QtGui
1713 \brief Describes the color and depth or depth/stencil attachments of a render target.
1714
1715 A texture render target has zero or more textures as color attachments,
1716 zero or one renderbuffer as combined depth/stencil buffer or zero or one
1717 texture as depth buffer.
1718
1719 \note depthStencilBuffer() and depthTexture() cannot be both set (cannot be
1720 non-null at the same time).
1721 */
1722
1723/*!
1724 \fn QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription::QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription()
1725
1726 Constructs an empty texture render target description.
1727 */
1728
1729/*!
1730 Constructs a texture render target description with one attachment
1731 described by \a colorAttachment.
1732 */
1733QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription::QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription(const QRhiColorAttachment &colorAttachment)
1734{
1735 m_colorAttachments.append(t: colorAttachment);
1736}
1737
1738/*!
1739 Constructs a texture render target description with two attachments, a
1740 color attachment described by \a colorAttachment, and a depth/stencil
1741 attachment with \a depthStencilBuffer.
1742 */
1743QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription::QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription(const QRhiColorAttachment &colorAttachment,
1744 QRhiRenderBuffer *depthStencilBuffer)
1745 : m_depthStencilBuffer(depthStencilBuffer)
1746{
1747 m_colorAttachments.append(t: colorAttachment);
1748}
1749
1750/*!
1751 Constructs a texture render target description with two attachments, a
1752 color attachment described by \a colorAttachment, and a depth attachment
1753 with \a depthTexture.
1754
1755 \note \a depthTexture must have a suitable format, such as QRhiTexture::D16
1756 or QRhiTexture::D32F.
1757 */
1758QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription::QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription(const QRhiColorAttachment &colorAttachment,
1759 QRhiTexture *depthTexture)
1760 : m_depthTexture(depthTexture)
1761{
1762 m_colorAttachments.append(t: colorAttachment);
1763}
1764
1765/*!
1766 \class QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription
1767 \internal
1768 \inmodule QtGui
1769 \brief Describes the source for one mip level in a layer in a texture upload operation.
1770
1771 The source content is specified either as a QImage or as a raw blob. The
1772 former is only allowed for uncompressed textures with a format that can be
1773 mapped to QImage, while the latter is supported for all formats, including
1774 floating point and compressed.
1775
1776 \note image() and data() cannot be both set at the same time.
1777
1778 destinationTopLeft() specifies the top-left corner of the target
1779 rectangle. Defaults to (0, 0).
1780
1781 An empty sourceSize() (the default) indicates that size is assumed to be
1782 the size of the subresource. With QImage-based uploads this implies that
1783 the size of the source image() must match the subresource. When providing
1784 raw data instead, sufficient number of bytes must be provided in data().
1785
1786 sourceTopLeft() is supported only for QImage-based uploads, and specifies
1787 the top-left corner of the source rectangle.
1788
1789 \note Setting sourceSize() or sourceTopLeft() may trigger a QImage copy
1790 internally, depending on the format and the backend.
1791
1792 When providing raw data, and the stride is not specified via
1793 setDataStride(), the stride (row pitch, row length in bytes) of the
1794 provided data must be equal to \c{width * pixelSize} where \c pixelSize is
1795 the number of bytes used for one pixel, and there must be no additional
1796 padding between rows. There is no row start alignment requirement.
1797
1798 When there is unused data at the end of each row in the input raw data,
1799 call setDataStride() with the total number of bytes per row. The stride
1800 must always be a multiple of the number of bytes for one pixel. The row
1801 stride is only applicable to image data for textures with an uncompressed
1802 format.
1803
1804 \note The format of the source data must be compatible with the texture
1805 format. With many graphics APIs the data is copied as-is into a staging
1806 buffer, there is no intermediate format conversion provided by QRhi. This
1807 applies to floating point formats as well, with, for example, RGBA16F
1808 requiring half floats in the source data.
1809
1810 \note Setting the stride via setDataStride() is only functional when
1811 QRhi::ImageDataStride is reported as
1812 \l{QRhi::isFeatureSupported()}{supported}. In practice this can be expected
1813 to be supported everywhere except for OpenGL ES 2.0.
1814
1815 \note When a QImage is given, the stride returned from
1816 QImage::bytesPerLine() is taken into account automatically.
1817
1818 \warning When a QImage is given and the QImage does not own the underlying
1819 pixel data, it is up to the caller to ensure that the associated data stays
1820 valid until the end of the frame. (just submitting the resource update batch
1821 is not sufficient, the data must stay valid until QRhi::endFrame() is called
1822 in order to be portable across all backends) If this cannot be ensured, the
1823 caller is strongly encouraged to call QImage::detach() on the image before
1824 passing it to uploadTexture().
1825 */
1826
1827/*!
1828 \fn QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription::QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription()
1829
1830 Constructs an empty subresource description.
1831
1832 \note an empty QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription is not useful on its
1833 own and should not be submitted to a QRhiTextureUploadEntry. At minimum
1834 image or data must be set first.
1835 */
1836
1837/*!
1838 Constructs a mip level description with a \a image.
1839
1840 The \l{QImage::size()}{size} of \a image must match the size of the mip
1841 level. For level 0 that is the \l{QRhiTexture::pixelSize()}{texture size}.
1842
1843 The bit depth of \a image must be compatible with the
1844 \l{QRhiTexture::Format}{texture format}.
1845
1846 To describe a partial upload, call setSourceSize(), setSourceTopLeft(), or
1847 setDestinationTopLeft() afterwards.
1848 */
1849QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription::QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription(const QImage &image)
1850 : m_image(image)
1851{
1852}
1853
1854/*!
1855 Constructs a mip level description with the image data is specified by \a
1856 data and \a size. This is suitable for floating point and compressed
1857 formats as well.
1858
1859 \a data can safely be destroyed or changed once this function returns.
1860 */
1861QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription::QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription(const void *data, quint32 size)
1862 : m_data(reinterpret_cast<const char *>(data), size)
1863{
1864}
1865
1866/*!
1867 Constructs a mip level description with the image data specified by \a
1868 data. This is suitable for floating point and compressed formats as well.
1869 */
1870QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription::QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription(const QByteArray &data)
1871 : m_data(data)
1872{
1873}
1874
1875/*!
1876 \class QRhiTextureUploadEntry
1877 \internal
1878 \inmodule QtGui
1879
1880 \brief Describes one layer (face for cubemaps, slice for 3D textures,
1881 element for texture arrays) in a texture upload operation.
1882 */
1883
1884/*!
1885 \fn QRhiTextureUploadEntry::QRhiTextureUploadEntry()
1886
1887 Constructs an empty QRhiTextureUploadEntry targeting layer 0 and level 0.
1888
1889 \note an empty QRhiTextureUploadEntry should not be submitted without
1890 setting a QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription via setDescription()
1891 first.
1892 */
1893
1894/*!
1895 Constructs a QRhiTextureUploadEntry targeting the given \a layer and mip
1896 \a level, with the subresource contents described by \a desc.
1897 */
1898QRhiTextureUploadEntry::QRhiTextureUploadEntry(int layer, int level,
1899 const QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription &desc)
1900 : m_layer(layer),
1901 m_level(level),
1902 m_desc(desc)
1903{
1904}
1905
1906/*!
1907 \class QRhiTextureUploadDescription
1908 \internal
1909 \inmodule QtGui
1910 \brief Describes a texture upload operation.
1911
1912 Used with QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::uploadTexture(). That function has two
1913 variants: one taking a QImage and one taking a
1914 QRhiTextureUploadDescription. The former is a convenience version,
1915 internally creating a QRhiTextureUploadDescription with a single image
