1916 targeting level 0 for layer 0. However, when cubemaps, pre-generated mip
1917 images, or compressed textures are involved, applications will have to work
1918 directly with this class instead.
1919
1920 QRhiTextureUploadDescription also enables specifying batched uploads, which
1921 are useful for example when generating an atlas or glyph cache texture:
1922 multiple, partial uploads for the same subresource (meaning the same layer
1923 and level) are supported, and can be, depending on the backend and the
1924 underlying graphics API, more efficient when batched into the same
1925 QRhiTextureUploadDescription as opposed to issuing individual
1926 \l{QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::uploadTexture()}{uploadTexture()} commands for
1927 each of them.
1928
1929 \note Cubemaps have one layer for each of the six faces in the order +X,
1930 -X, +Y, -Y, +Z, -Z.
1931
1932 For example, specifying the faces of a cubemap could look like the following:
1933
1934 \badcode
1935 QImage faces[6];
1936 ...
1937 QList<QRhiTextureUploadEntry> entries;
1938 for (int i = 0; i < 6; ++i)
1939 entries.append(QRhiTextureUploadEntry(i, 0, faces[i]));
1940 QRhiTextureUploadDescription desc;
1941 desc.setEntries(entries.cbegin(), entries.cend());
1942 resourceUpdates->uploadTexture(texture, desc);
1943 \endcode
1944
1945 Another example that specifies mip images for a compressed texture:
1946
1947 \badcode
1948 QList<QRhiTextureUploadEntry> entries;
1949 const int mipCount = rhi->mipLevelsForSize(compressedTexture->pixelSize());
1950 for (int level = 0; level < mipCount; ++level) {
1951 const QByteArray compressedDataForLevel = ..
1952 entries.append(QRhiTextureUploadEntry(0, level, compressedDataForLevel));
1953 }
1954 QRhiTextureUploadDescription desc;
1955 desc.setEntries(entries.cbegin(), entries.cend());
1956 resourceUpdates->uploadTexture(compressedTexture, desc);
1957 \endcode
1958
1959 With partial uploads targeting the same subresource, it is recommended to
1960 batch them into a single upload request, whenever possible:
1961
1962 \badcode
1963 QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription subresDesc(image);
1964 subresDesc.setSourceSize(QSize(10, 10));
1965 subResDesc.setDestinationTopLeft(QPoint(50, 40));
1966 QRhiTextureUploadEntry entry(0, 0, subresDesc); // layer 0, level 0
1967
1968 QRhiTextureSubresourceUploadDescription subresDesc2(image);
1969 subresDesc2.setSourceSize(QSize(30, 40));
1970 subResDesc2.setDestinationTopLeft(QPoint(100, 200));
1971 QRhiTextureUploadEntry entry2(0, 0, subresDesc2); // layer 0, level 0, i.e. same subresource
1972
1973 QRhiTextureUploadDescription desc({ entry, entry2});
1974 resourceUpdates->uploadTexture(texture, desc);
1975 \endcode
1976 */
1977
1978/*!
1979 \fn QRhiTextureUploadDescription::QRhiTextureUploadDescription()
1980
1981 Constructs an empty texture upload description.
1982 */
1983
1984/*!
1985 Constructs a texture upload description with a single subresource upload
1986 described by \a entry.
1987 */
1988QRhiTextureUploadDescription::QRhiTextureUploadDescription(const QRhiTextureUploadEntry &entry)
1989{
1990 m_entries.append(t: entry);
1991}
1992
1993/*!
1994 Constructs a texture upload description with the specified \a list of entries.
1995
1996 \note \a list can also contain multiple QRhiTextureUploadEntry elements
1997 with the same layer and level. This makes sense when those uploads are
1998 partial, meaning their subresource description has a source size or image
1999 smaller than the subresource dimensions, and can be more efficient than
2000 issuing separate uploadTexture()'s.
2001 */
2002QRhiTextureUploadDescription::QRhiTextureUploadDescription(std::initializer_list<QRhiTextureUploadEntry> list)
2003 : m_entries(list)
2004{
2005}
2006
2007/*!
2008 \class QRhiTextureCopyDescription
2009 \internal
2010 \inmodule QtGui
2011 \brief Describes a texture-to-texture copy operation.
2012
2013 An empty pixelSize() indicates that the entire subresource is to be copied.
2014 A default constructed copy description therefore leads to copying the
2015 entire subresource at level 0 of layer 0.
2016
2017 \note The source texture must be created with
2018 QRhiTexture::UsedAsTransferSource.
2019
2020 \note The source and destination rectangles defined by pixelSize(),
2021 sourceTopLeft(), and destinationTopLeft() must fit the source and
2022 destination textures, respectively. The behavior is undefined otherwise.
2023
2024 With cubemaps, 3D textures, and texture arrays one face or slice can be
2025 copied at a time. The face or slice is specified by the source and
2026 destination layer indices. With mipmapped textures one mip level can be
2027 copied at a time. The source and destination layer and mip level indices can
2028 differ, but the size and position must be carefully controlled to avoid out
2029 of bounds copies, in which case the behavior is undefined.
2030 */
2031
2032/*!
2033 \fn QRhiTextureCopyDescription::QRhiTextureCopyDescription()
2034
2035 Constructs an empty texture copy description.
2036 */
2037
2038/*!
2039 \class QRhiReadbackDescription
2040 \internal
2041 \inmodule QtGui
2042 \brief Describes a readback (reading back texture contents from possibly GPU-only memory) operation.
2043
2044 The source of the readback operation is either a QRhiTexture or the
2045 current backbuffer of the currently targeted QRhiSwapChain. When
2046 texture() is not set, the swapchain is used. Otherwise the specified
2047 QRhiTexture is treated as the source.
2048
2049 \note Textures used in readbacks must be created with
2050 QRhiTexture::UsedAsTransferSource.
2051
2052 \note Swapchains used in readbacks must be created with
2053 QRhiSwapChain::UsedAsTransferSource.
2054
2055 layer() and level() are only applicable when the source is a QRhiTexture.
2056
2057 \note Multisample textures cannot be read back. Readbacks are supported for
2058 multisample swapchain buffers however.
2059 */
2060
2061/*!
2062 \fn QRhiReadbackDescription::QRhiReadbackDescription()
2063
2064 Constructs an empty texture readback description.
2065
2066 \note The source texture is set to null by default, which is still a valid
2067 readback: it specifies that the backbuffer of the current swapchain is to
2068 be read back. (current meaning the frame's target swapchain at the time of
2069 committing the QRhiResourceUpdateBatch with the
2070 \l{QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::readBackTexture()}{texture readback} on it)
2071 */
2072
2073/*!
2074 Constructs an texture readback description that specifies that level 0 of
2075 layer 0 of \a texture is to be read back.
2076
2077 \note \a texture can also be null in which case this constructor is
2078 identical to the argumentless variant.
2079 */
2080QRhiReadbackDescription::QRhiReadbackDescription(QRhiTexture *texture)
2081 : m_texture(texture)
2082{
2083}
2084
2085/*!
2086 \class QRhiReadbackResult
2087 \internal
2088 \inmodule QtGui
2089 \brief Describes the results of a potentially asynchronous readback operation.
2090
2091 When \l completed is set, the function is invoked when the \l data is
2092 available. \l format and \l pixelSize are set upon completion together with
2093 \l data.
2094 */
2095
2096/*!
2097 \class QRhiNativeHandles
2098 \internal
2099 \inmodule QtGui
2100 \brief Base class for classes exposing backend-specific collections of native resource objects.
2101 */
2102
2103/*!
2104 \class QRhiResource
2105 \internal
2106 \inmodule QtGui
2107 \brief Base class for classes encapsulating native resource objects.
2108 */
2109
2110/*!
2111 \fn QRhiResource::Type QRhiResource::resourceType() const
2112
2113 \return the type of the resource.
2114 */
2115
2116/*!
2117 \internal
2118 */
2119QRhiResource::QRhiResource(QRhiImplementation *rhi)
2120 : m_rhi(rhi)
2121{
2122 m_id = QRhiGlobalObjectIdGenerator::newId();
2123}
2124
2125/*!
2126 Destructor.
2127
2128 Releases (or requests deferred releasing of) the underlying native graphics
2129 resources, if there are any.
2130
2131 \note Resources referenced by commands for the current frame should not be
2132 released until the frame is submitted by QRhi::endFrame().
2133
2134 \sa destroy()
2135 */
2136QRhiResource::~QRhiResource()
2137{
2138 // destroy() cannot be called here, due to virtuals; it is up to the
2139 // subclasses to do that.
2140}
2141
2142/*!
2143 \fn void QRhiResource::destroy()
2144
2145 Releases (or requests deferred releasing of) the underlying native graphics
2146 resources. Safe to call multiple times, subsequent invocations will be a
2147 no-op then.
2148
2149 Once destroy() is called, the QRhiResource instance can be reused, by
2150 calling \c create() again. That will then result in creating new native
2151 graphics resources underneath.
2152
2153 \note Resources referenced by commands for the current frame should not be
2154 released until the frame is submitted by QRhi::endFrame().
2155
2156 The QRhiResource destructor also performs the same task, so calling this
2157 function is not necessary before destroying a QRhiResource.
2158
2159 \sa deleteLater()
2160 */
2161
2162/*!
2163 When called without a frame being recorded, this function is equivalent to
2164 deleting the object. Between a QRhi::beginFrame() and QRhi::endFrame()
2165 however the behavior is different: the QRhiResource will not be destroyed
2166 until the frame is submitted via QRhi::endFrame(), thus satisfying the QRhi
2167 requirement of not altering QRhiResource objects that are referenced by the
2168 frame being recorded.
2169
2170 \sa destroy()
2171 */
2172void QRhiResource::deleteLater()
2173{
2174 m_rhi->addDeleteLater(res: this);
2175}
2176
2177/*!
2178 \return the currently set object name. By default the name is empty.
2179 */
2180QByteArray QRhiResource::name() const
2181{
2182 return m_objectName;
2183}
2184
2185/*!
2186 Sets a \a name for the object.
2187
2188 This has two uses: to get descriptive names for the native graphics
2189 resources visible in graphics debugging tools, such as
2190 \l{https://renderdoc.org/}{RenderDoc} and
2191 \l{https://developer.apple.com/xcode/}{XCode}.
2192
2193 When it comes to naming native objects by relaying the name via the
2194 appropriate graphics API, note that the name is ignored when
2195 QRhi::DebugMarkers are not supported, and may, depending on the backend,
2196 also be ignored when QRhi::EnableDebugMarkers is not set.
2197
2198 \note The name may be ignored for objects other than buffers,
2199 renderbuffers, and textures, depending on the backend.
2200
2201 \note The name may be modified. For slotted resources, such as a QRhiBuffer
2202 backed by multiple native buffers, QRhi will append a suffix to make the
2203 underlying native buffers easily distinguishable from each other.
2204 */
2205void QRhiResource::setName(const QByteArray &name)
2206{
2207 m_objectName = name;
2208}
2209
2210/*!
2211 \return the global, unique identifier of this QRhiResource.
2212
2213 User code rarely needs to deal with the value directly. It is used
2214 internally for tracking and bookkeeping purposes.
2215 */
2216quint64 QRhiResource::globalResourceId() const
2217{
2218 return m_id;
2219}
2220
2221/*!
2222 \return the QRhi that created this resource.
2223 */
2224QRhi *QRhiResource::rhi() const
2225{
2226 return m_rhi->q;
2227}
2228
2229/*!
2230 \class QRhiBuffer
2231 \internal
2232 \inmodule QtGui
2233 \brief Vertex, index, or uniform (constant) buffer resource.
2234 */
2235
2236/*!
2237 \enum QRhiBuffer::Type
2238 Specifies storage type of buffer resource.
2239
2240 \value Immutable Indicates that the data is not expected to change ever
2241 after the initial upload. Under the hood such buffer resources are
2242 typically placed in device local (GPU) memory (on systems where
2243 applicable). Uploading new data is possible, but may be expensive. The
2244 upload typically happens by copying to a separate, host visible staging
2245 buffer from which a GPU buffer-to-buffer copy is issued into the actual
2246 GPU-only buffer.
2247
2248 \value Static Indicates that the data is expected to change only
2249 infrequently. Typically placed in device local (GPU) memory, where
2250 applicable. On backends where host visible staging buffers are used for
2251 uploading, the staging buffers are kept around for this type, unlike with
2252 Immutable, so subsequent uploads do not suffer in performance. Frequent
2253 updates, especially updates in consecutive frames, should be avoided.
2254
2255 \value Dynamic Indicates that the data is expected to change frequently.
2256 Not recommended for large buffers. Typically backed by host visible memory
2257 in 2 copies in order to allow for changing without stalling the graphics
2258 pipeline. The double buffering is managed transparently to the applications
2259 and is not exposed in the API here in any form. This is the recommended,
2260 and, with some backends, the only possible, type for buffers with
2261 UniformBuffer usage.
2262 */
2263
2264/*!
2265 \enum QRhiBuffer::UsageFlag
2266 Flag values to specify how the buffer is going to be used.
2267
2268 \value VertexBuffer Vertex buffer. This allows the QRhiBuffer to be used in
2269 \l{setVertexInput()}{QRhiCommandBuffer::setVertexInput()}.
2270
2271 \value IndexBuffer Index buffer. This allows the QRhiBuffer to be used in
2272 \l{setVertexInput()}{QRhiCommandBuffer::setVertexInput()}.
2273
2274 \value UniformBuffer Uniform buffer (also called constant buffer). This
2275 allows the QRhiBuffer to be used in combination with
2276 \l{UniformBuffer}{QRhiShaderResourceBinding::UniformBuffer}. When
2277 \l{QRhi::NonDynamicUniformBuffers}{NonDynamicUniformBuffers} is reported as
2278 not supported, this usage can only be combined with the type Dynamic.
2279
2280 \value StorageBuffer Storage buffer. This allows the QRhiBuffer to be used
2281 in combination with \l{BufferLoad}{QRhiShaderResourceBinding::BufferLoad},
2282 \l{BufferStore}{QRhiShaderResourceBinding::BufferStore}, or
2283 \l{BufferLoadStore}{QRhiShaderResourceBinding::BufferLoadStore}. This usage
2284 can only be combined with the types Immutable or Static, and is only
2285 available when the \l{QRhi::Compute}{Compute feature} is reported as
2286 supported.
2287 */
2288
2289/*!
2290 \fn void QRhiBuffer::setSize(int sz)
2291
2292 Sets the size of the buffer in bytes. The size is normally specified in
2293 QRhi::newBuffer() so this function is only used when the size has to be
2294 changed. As with other setters, the size only takes effect when calling
2295 create(), and for already created buffers this involves releasing the previous
2296 native resource and creating new ones under the hood.
2297
2298 Backends may choose to allocate buffers bigger than \a sz in order to
2299 fulfill alignment requirements. This is hidden from the applications and
2300 size() will always report the size requested in \a sz.
2301 */
2302
2303/*!
2304 \class QRhiBuffer::NativeBuffer
2305 \brief Contains information about the underlying native resources of a buffer.
2306 */
2307
2308/*!
2309 \variable QRhiBuffer::NativeBuffer::objects
2310 \brief an array with pointers to the native object handles.
2311
2312 With OpenGL, the native handle is a GLuint value, so the elements in the \c
2313 objects array are pointers to a GLuint. With Vulkan, the native handle is a
2314 VkBuffer, so the elements of the array are pointers to a VkBuffer. With
2315 Direct3D 11 and Metal the elements are pointers to a ID3D11Buffer or
2316 MTLBuffer pointer, respectively.
2317
2318 \note Pay attention to the fact that the elements are always pointers to
2319 the native buffer handle type, even if the native type itself is a pointer.
2320 */
2321
2322/*!
2323 \variable QRhiBuffer::NativeBuffer::slotCount
2324 \brief Specifies the number of valid elements in the objects array.
2325
2326 The value can be 0, 1, 2, or 3 in practice. 0 indicates that the QRhiBuffer
2327 is not backed by any native buffer objects. This can happen with
2328 QRhiBuffers with the usage UniformBuffer when the underlying API does not
2329 support (or the backend chooses not to use) native uniform buffers. 1 is
2330 commonly used for Immutable and Static types (but some backends may
2331 differ). 2 or 3 is typical when the type is Dynamic (but some backends may
2332 differ).
2333
2334 \sa QRhi::currentFrameSlot(), QRhi::FramesInFlight
2335 */
2336
2337/*!
2338 \internal
2339 */
2340QRhiBuffer::QRhiBuffer(QRhiImplementation *rhi, Type type_, UsageFlags usage_, quint32 size_)
2341 : QRhiResource(rhi),
2342 m_type(type_), m_usage(usage_), m_size(size_)
2343{
2344}
2345
2346/*!
2347 \return the resource type.
2348 */
2349QRhiResource::Type QRhiBuffer::resourceType() const
2350{
2351 return Buffer;
2352}
2353
2354/*!
2355 \fn bool QRhiBuffer::create()
2356
2357 Creates the corresponding native graphics resources. If there are already
2358 resources present due to an earlier create() with no corresponding
2359 destroy(), then destroy() is called implicitly first.
2360
2361 \return \c true when successful, \c false when a graphics operation failed.
2362 Regardless of the return value, calling destroy() is always safe.
2363 */
2364
2365/*!
2366 \return the underlying native resources for this buffer. The returned value
2367 will be empty if exposing the underlying native resources is not supported by
2368 the backend.
2369
2370 A QRhiBuffer may be backed by multiple native buffer objects, depending on
2371 the type() and the QRhi backend in use. When this is the case, all of them
2372 are returned in the objects array in the returned struct, with slotCount
2373 specifying the number of native buffer objects. While
2374 \l{QRhi::beginFrame()}{recording a frame}, QRhi::currentFrameSlot() can be
2375 used to determine which of the native buffers QRhi is using for operations
2376 that read or write from this QRhiBuffer within the frame being recorded.
2377
2378 In some cases a QRhiBuffer will not be backed by a native buffer object at
2379 all. In this case slotCount will be set to 0 and no valid native objects
2380 are returned. This is not an error, and is perfectly valid when a given
2381 backend does not use native buffers for QRhiBuffers with certain types or
2382 usages.
2383
2384 \note Be aware that QRhi backends may employ various buffer update
2385 strategies. Unlike textures, where uploading image data always means
2386 recording a buffer-to-image (or similar) copy command on the command
2387 buffer, buffers, in particular Dynamic and UniformBuffer ones, can operate
2388 in many different ways. For example, a QRhiBuffer with usage type
2389 UniformBuffer may not even be backed by a native buffer object at all if
2390 uniform buffers are not used or supported by a given backend and graphics
2391 API. There are also differences to how data is written to the buffer and
2392 the type of backing memory used. For buffers backed by host visible memory,
2393 calling this function guarantees that pending host writes are executed for
2394 all the returned native buffers.
2395
2396 \sa QRhi::currentFrameSlot(), QRhi::FramesInFlight
2397 */
2398QRhiBuffer::NativeBuffer QRhiBuffer::nativeBuffer()
2399{
2400 return {};
2401}
2402
2403/*!
2404 \return a pointer to a memory block with the host visible buffer data.
2405
2406 This is a shortcut for medium-to-large dynamic uniform buffers that have
2407 their \b entire contents (or at least all regions that are read by the
2408 shaders in the current frame) changed \b{in every frame} and the
2409 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch-based update mechanism is seen too heavy due to the
2410 amount of data copying involved.
2411
2412 The call to this function must be eventually followed by a call to
2413 endFullDynamicUniformBufferUpdateForCurrentFrame(), before recording any
2414 render or compute pass that relies on this buffer.
2415
2416 \warning Updating data via this method is not compatible with
2417 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch-based updates and readbacks. Unexpected behavior
2418 may occur when attempting to combine the two update models for the same
2419 buffer. Similarly, the data updated this direct way may not be visible to
2420 \l{QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::readBackBuffer()}{readBackBuffer operations},
2421 depending on the backend.
2422
2423 \warning When updating buffer data via this method, the update must be done
2424 in every frame, otherwise backends that perform double or triple buffering
2425 of resources may end up in unexpected behavior.
2426
2427 \warning Partial updates are not possible with this approach since some
2428 backends may choose a strategy where the previous contents of the buffer is
2429 lost upon calling this function. Data must be written to all regions that
2430 are read by shaders in the frame currently being prepared.
2431
2432 \warning This function can only be called when recording a frame, so
2433 between QRhi::beginFrame() and QRhi::endFrame().
2434
2435 \warning This function can only be called on Dynamic buffers.
2436 */
2437char *QRhiBuffer::beginFullDynamicBufferUpdateForCurrentFrame()
2438{
2439 return nullptr;
2440}
2441
2442/*!
2443 To be called when the entire contents of the buffer data has been updated
2444 in the memory block returned from
2445 beginFullDynamicBufferUpdateForCurrentFrame().
2446 */
2447void QRhiBuffer::endFullDynamicBufferUpdateForCurrentFrame()
2448{
2449}
2450
2451/*!
2452 \class QRhiRenderBuffer
2453 \internal
2454 \inmodule QtGui
2455 \brief Renderbuffer resource.
2456
2457 Renderbuffers cannot be sampled or read but have some benefits over
2458 textures in some cases:
2459
2460 A DepthStencil renderbuffer may be lazily allocated and be backed by
2461 transient memory with some APIs. On some platforms this may mean the
2462 depth/stencil buffer uses no physical backing at all.
2463
2464 Color renderbuffers are useful since QRhi::MultisampleRenderBuffer may be
2465 supported even when QRhi::MultisampleTexture is not.
2466
2467 How the renderbuffer is implemented by a backend is not exposed to the
2468 applications. In some cases it may be backed by ordinary textures, while in
2469 others there may be a different kind of native resource used.
2470
2471 Renderbuffers that are used as (and are only used as) depth-stencil buffers
2472 in combination with a QRhiSwapChain's color buffers should have the
2473 UsedWithSwapChainOnly flag set. This serves a double purpose: such buffers,
2474 depending on the backend and the underlying APIs, be more efficient, and
2475 QRhi provides automatic sizing behavior to match the color buffers, which
2476 means calling setPixelSize() and create() are not necessary for such
2477 renderbuffers.
2478 */
2479
2480/*!
2481 \enum QRhiRenderBuffer::Type
2482 Specifies the type of the renderbuffer
2483
2484 \value DepthStencil Combined depth/stencil
2485 \value Color Color
2486 */
2487
2488/*!
2489 \enum QRhiRenderBuffer::Flag
2490 Flag values for flags() and setFlags()
2491
2492 \value UsedWithSwapChainOnly For DepthStencil renderbuffers this indicates
2493 that the renderbuffer is only used in combination with a QRhiSwapChain, and
2494 never in any other way. This provides automatic sizing and resource
2495 rebuilding, so calling setPixelSize() or create() is not needed whenever
2496 this flag is set. This flag value may also trigger backend-specific
2497 behavior, for example with OpenGL, where a separate windowing system
2498 interface API is in use (EGL, GLX, etc.), the flag is especially important
2499 as it avoids creating any actual renderbuffer resource as there is already
2500 a windowing system provided depth/stencil buffer as requested by
2501 QSurfaceFormat.
2502 */
2503
2504/*!
2505 \internal
2506 */
2507QRhiRenderBuffer::QRhiRenderBuffer(QRhiImplementation *rhi, Type type_, const QSize &pixelSize_,
2508 int sampleCount_, Flags flags_,
2509 QRhiTexture::Format backingFormatHint_)
2510 : QRhiResource(rhi),
2511 m_type(type_), m_pixelSize(pixelSize_), m_sampleCount(sampleCount_), m_flags(flags_),
2512 m_backingFormatHint(backingFormatHint_)
2513{
2514}
2515
2516/*!
2517 \return the resource type.
2518 */
2519QRhiResource::Type QRhiRenderBuffer::resourceType() const
2520{
2521 return RenderBuffer;
2522}
2523
2524/*!
2525 \fn bool QRhiRenderBuffer::create()
2526
2527 Creates the corresponding native graphics resources. If there are already
2528 resources present due to an earlier create() with no corresponding
2529 destroy(), then destroy() is called implicitly first.
2530
2531 \return \c true when successful, \c false when a graphics operation failed.
2532 Regardless of the return value, calling destroy() is always safe.
2533 */
2534
2535/*!
2536 Similar to create() except that no new native renderbuffer objects are
2537 created. Instead, the native renderbuffer object specified by \a src is
2538 used.
2539
2540 This allows importing an existing renderbuffer object (which must belong to
2541 the same device or sharing context, depending on the graphics API) from an
2542 external graphics engine.
2543
2544 \note This is currently applicable to OpenGL only. This function exists
2545 solely to allow importing a renderbuffer object that is bound to some
2546 special, external object, such as an EGLImageKHR. Once the application
2547 performed the glEGLImageTargetRenderbufferStorageOES call, the renderbuffer
2548 object can be passed to this function to create a wrapping
2549 QRhiRenderBuffer, which in turn can be passed in as a color attachment to
2550 a QRhiTextureRenderTarget to enable rendering to the EGLImage.
2551
2552 \note pixelSize(), sampleCount(), and flags() must still be set correctly.
2553 Passing incorrect sizes and other values to QRhi::newRenderBuffer() and
2554 then following it with a createFrom() expecting that the native
2555 renderbuffer object alone is sufficient to deduce such values is \b wrong
2556 and will lead to problems.
2557
2558 \note QRhiRenderBuffer does not take ownership of the native object, and
2559 destroy() will not release that object.
2560
2561 \note This function is only implemented when the QRhi::RenderBufferImport
2562 feature is reported as \l{QRhi::isFeatureSupported()}{supported}. Otherwise,
2563 the function does nothing and the return value is \c false.
2564
2565 \return \c true when successful, \c false when not supported.
2566 */
2567bool QRhiRenderBuffer::createFrom(NativeRenderBuffer src)
2568{
2569 Q_UNUSED(src);
2570 return false;
2571}
2572
2573/*!
2574 \fn QRhiTexture::Format QRhiRenderBuffer::backingFormat() const
2575
2576 \internal
2577 */
2578
2579/*!
2580 \class QRhiTexture
2581 \internal
2582 \inmodule QtGui
2583 \brief Texture resource.
2584 */
2585
2586/*!
2587 \enum QRhiTexture::Flag
2588
2589 Flag values to specify how the texture is going to be used. Not honoring
2590 the flags set before create() and attempting to use the texture in ways that
2591 was not declared upfront can lead to unspecified behavior or decreased
2592 performance depending on the backend and the underlying graphics API.
2593
2594 \value RenderTarget The texture going to be used in combination with
2595 QRhiTextureRenderTarget.
2596
2597 \value CubeMap The texture is a cubemap. Such textures have 6 layers, one
2598 for each face in the order of +X, -X, +Y, -Y, +Z, -Z. Cubemap textures
2599 cannot be multisample.
2600
2601 \value MipMapped The texture has mipmaps. The appropriate mip count is
2602 calculated automatically and can also be retrieved via
2603 QRhi::mipLevelsForSize(). The images for the mip levels have to be
2604 provided in the texture uploaded or generated via
2605 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::generateMips(). Multisample textures cannot have
2606 mipmaps.
2607
2608 \value sRGB Use an sRGB format.
2609
2610 \value UsedAsTransferSource The texture is used as the source of a texture
2611 copy or readback, meaning the texture is given as the source in
2612 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::copyTexture() or
2613 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::readBackTexture().
2614
2615 \value UsedWithGenerateMips The texture is going to be used with
2616 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::generateMips().
2617
2618 \value UsedWithLoadStore The texture is going to be used with image
2619 load/store operations, for example, in a compute shader.
2620
2621 \value UsedAsCompressedAtlas The texture has a compressed format and the
2622 dimensions of subresource uploads may not match the texture size.
2623
2624 \value ExternalOES The texture should use the GL_TEXTURE_EXTERNAL_OES
2625 target with OpenGL. This flag is ignored with other graphics APIs.
2626
2627 \value ThreeDimensional The texture is a 3D texture. Such textures should
2628 be created with the QRhi::newTexture() overload taking a depth in addition
2629 to width and height. A 3D texture can have mipmaps but cannot be
2630 multisample. When rendering into, or uploading data to a 3D texture, the \c
2631 layer specified in the render target's color attachment or the upload
2632 description refers to a single slice in range [0..depth-1]. The underlying
2633 graphics API may not support 3D textures at run time. Support is indicated
2634 by the QRhi::ThreeDimensionalTextures feature.
2635
2636 \value TextureRectangleGL The texture should use the GL_TEXTURE_RECTANGLE
2637 target with OpenGL. This flag is ignored with other graphics APIs. Just
2638 like ExternalOES, this flag is useful when working with platform APIs where
2639 native OpenGL texture objects received from the platform are wrapped in a
2640 QRhiTexture, and the platform can only provide textures for a non-2D
2641 texture target.
2642
2643 \value TextureArray The texture is a texture array, i.e. a single texture
2644 object that is a homogeneous array of 2D textures. Texture arrays are
2645 created with QRhi::newTextureArray(). The underlying graphics API may not
2646 support texture array objects at run time. Support is indicated by the
2647 QRhi::TextureArrays feature. When rendering into, or uploading data to a
2648 texture array, the \c layer specified in the render target's color
2649 attachment or the upload description selects a single element in the array.
2650 */
2651
2652/*!
2653 \enum QRhiTexture::Format
2654
2655 Specifies the texture format. See also QRhi::isTextureFormatSupported() and
2656 note that flags() can modify the format when QRhiTexture::sRGB is set.
2657
2658 \value UnknownFormat Not a valid format. This cannot be passed to setFormat().
2659
2660 \value RGBA8 Four component, unsigned normalized 8 bit per component. Always supported.
2661
2662 \value BGRA8 Four component, unsigned normalized 8 bit per component.
2663
2664 \value R8 One component, unsigned normalized 8 bit.
2665
2666 \value RG8 Two components, unsigned normalized 8 bit.
2667
2668 \value R16 One component, unsigned normalized 16 bit.
2669
2670 \value RG16 Two component, unsigned normalized 16 bit.
2671
2672 \value RED_OR_ALPHA8 Either same as R8, or is a similar format with the component swizzled to alpha,
2673 depending on \l{QRhi::RedOrAlpha8IsRed}{RedOrAlpha8IsRed}.
2674
2675 \value RGBA16F Four components, 16-bit float per component.
2676
2677 \value RGBA32F Four components, 32-bit float per component.
2678
2679 \value R16F One component, 16-bit float.
2680
2681 \value R32F One component, 32-bit float.
2682
2683 \value RGBA10A2 Four components, unsigned normalized 10 bit R, G, and B,
2684 2-bit alpha. This is a packed format so native endianness applies. Note
2685 that there is no BGR10A2. This is because RGB10A2 maps to
2686 DXGI_FORMAT_R10G10B10A2_UNORM with D3D, MTLPixelFormatRGB10A2Unorm with
2687 Metal, VK_FORMAT_A2B10G10R10_UNORM_PACK32 with Vulkan, and
2688 GL_RGB10_A2/GL_RGB/GL_UNSIGNED_INT_2_10_10_10_REV on OpenGL (ES). This is
2689 the only universally supported RGB30 option. The corresponding QImage
2690 formats are QImage::Format_BGR30 and QImage::Format_A2BGR30_Premultiplied.
2691
2692 \value D16 16-bit depth (normalized unsigned integer)
2693
2694 \value D24 24-bit depth (normalized unsigned integer)
2695
2696 \value D24S8 24-bit depth (normalized unsigned integer), 8 bit stencil
2697
2698 \value D32F 32-bit depth (32-bit float)
2699
2700 \value BC1
2701 \value BC2
2702 \value BC3
2703 \value BC4
2704 \value BC5
2705 \value BC6H
2706 \value BC7
2707
2708 \value ETC2_RGB8
2709 \value ETC2_RGB8A1
2710 \value ETC2_RGBA8
2711
2712 \value ASTC_4x4
2713 \value ASTC_5x4
2714 \value ASTC_5x5
2715 \value ASTC_6x5
2716 \value ASTC_6x6
2717 \value ASTC_8x5
2718 \value ASTC_8x6
2719 \value ASTC_8x8
2720 \value ASTC_10x5
2721 \value ASTC_10x6
2722 \value ASTC_10x8
2723 \value ASTC_10x10
2724 \value ASTC_12x10
2725 \value ASTC_12x12
2726 */
2727
2728/*!
2729 \class QRhiTexture::NativeTexture
2730 \brief Contains information about the underlying native resources of a texture.
2731 */
2732
2733/*!
2734 \variable QRhiTexture::NativeTexture::object
2735 \brief 64-bit integer containing the native object handle.
2736
2737 With OpenGL, the native handle is a GLuint value, so \c object can then be
2738 cast to a GLuint. With Vulkan, the native handle is a VkImage, so \c
2739 object can be cast to a VkImage. With Direct3D 11 and Metal \c
2740 object contains a ID3D11Texture2D or MTLTexture pointer, respectively.
2741 */
2742
2743/*!
2744 \variable QRhiTexture::NativeTexture::layout
2745 \brief Specifies the current image layout for APIs like Vulkan.
2746
2747 For Vulkan, \c layout contains a \c VkImageLayout value.
2748 */
2749
2750/*!
2751 \internal
2752 */
2753QRhiTexture::QRhiTexture(QRhiImplementation *rhi, Format format_, const QSize &pixelSize_, int depth_,
2754 int arraySize_, int sampleCount_, Flags flags_)
2755 : QRhiResource(rhi),
2756 m_format(format_), m_pixelSize(pixelSize_), m_depth(depth_),
2757 m_arraySize(arraySize_), m_sampleCount(sampleCount_), m_flags(flags_)
2758{
2759}
2760
2761/*!
2762 \return the resource type.
2763 */
2764QRhiResource::Type QRhiTexture::resourceType() const
2765{
2766 return Texture;
2767}
2768
2769/*!
2770 \fn bool QRhiTexture::create()
2771
2772 Creates the corresponding native graphics resources. If there are already
2773 resources present due to an earlier create() with no corresponding
2774 destroy(), then destroy() is called implicitly first.
2775
2776 \return \c true when successful, \c false when a graphics operation failed.
2777 Regardless of the return value, calling destroy() is always safe.
2778 */
2779
2780/*!
2781 \return the underlying native resources for this texture. The returned value
2782 will be empty if exposing the underlying native resources is not supported by
2783 the backend.
2784
2785 \sa createFrom()
2786 */
2787QRhiTexture::NativeTexture QRhiTexture::nativeTexture()
2788{
2789 return {};
2790}
2791
2792/*!
2793 Similar to create() except that no new native textures are created. Instead,
2794 the native texture resources specified by \a src is used.
2795
2796 This allows importing an existing native texture object (which must belong
2797 to the same device or sharing context, depending on the graphics API) from
2798 an external graphics engine.
2799
2800 \note format(), pixelSize(), sampleCount(), and flags() must still be set
2801 correctly. Passing incorrect sizes and other values to QRhi::newTexture()
2802 and then following it with a createFrom() expecting that the native texture
2803 object alone is sufficient to deduce such values is \b wrong and will lead
2804 to problems.
2805
2806 \note QRhiTexture does not take ownership of the texture object. destroy()
2807 does not free the object or any associated memory.
2808
2809 The opposite of this operation, exposing a QRhiTexture-created native
2810 texture object to a foreign engine, is possible via nativeTexture().
2811
2812 \note When importing a 3D texture, or a texture array object, or, with
2813 OpenGL ES, an external texture, it is then especially important to set the
2814 corresponding flags (ThreeDimensional, TextureArray, ExternalOES) via
2815 setFlags() before calling this function.
2816*/
2817bool QRhiTexture::createFrom(QRhiTexture::NativeTexture src)
2818{
2819 Q_UNUSED(src);
2820 return false;
2821}
2822
2823/*!
2824 With some graphics APIs, such as Vulkan, integrating custom rendering code
2825 that uses the graphics API directly needs special care when it comes to
2826 image layouts. This function allows communicating the expected layout the
2827 image backing the QRhiTexture is in after the native rendering commands.
2828
2829 For example, consider rendering into a QRhiTexture's VkImage directly with
2830 Vulkan in a code block enclosed by QRhiCommandBuffer::beginExternal() and
2831 QRhiCommandBuffer::endExternal(), followed by using the image for texture
2832 sampling in a QRhi-based render pass. To avoid potentially incorrect image
2833 layout transitions, this function can be used to indicate what the image
2834 layout will be once the commands recorded in said code block complete.
2835
2836 Calling this function makes sense only after
2837 QRhiCommandBuffer::endExternal() and before a subsequent
2838 QRhiCommandBuffer::beginPass().
2839
2840 This function has no effect with QRhi backends where the underlying
2841 graphics API does not expose a concept of image layouts.
2842 */
2843void QRhiTexture::setNativeLayout(int layout)
2844{
2845 Q_UNUSED(layout);
2846}
2847
2848/*!
2849 \class QRhiSampler
2850 \internal
2851 \inmodule QtGui
2852 \brief Sampler resource.
2853 */
2854
2855/*!
2856 \enum QRhiSampler::Filter
2857 Specifies the minification, magnification, or mipmap filtering
2858
2859 \value None Applicable only for mipmapMode(), indicates no mipmaps to be used
2860 \value Nearest
2861 \value Linear
2862 */
2863
2864/*!
2865 \enum QRhiSampler::AddressMode
2866 Specifies the addressing mode
2867
2868 \value Repeat
2869 \value ClampToEdge
2870 \value Mirror
2871 */
2872
2873/*!
2874 \enum QRhiSampler::CompareOp
2875 Specifies the texture comparison function.
2876
2877 \value Never (default)
2878 \value Less
2879 \value Equal
2880 \value LessOrEqual
2881 \value Greater
2882 \value NotEqual
2883 \value GreaterOrEqual
2884 \value Always
2885 */
2886
2887/*!
2888 \internal
2889 */
2890QRhiSampler::QRhiSampler(QRhiImplementation *rhi,
2891 Filter magFilter_, Filter minFilter_, Filter mipmapMode_,
2892 AddressMode u_, AddressMode v_, AddressMode w_)
2893 : QRhiResource(rhi),
2894 m_magFilter(magFilter_), m_minFilter(minFilter_), m_mipmapMode(mipmapMode_),
2895 m_addressU(u_), m_addressV(v_), m_addressW(w_),
2896 m_compareOp(QRhiSampler::Never)
2897{
2898}
2899
2900/*!
2901 \return the resource type.
2902 */
2903QRhiResource::Type QRhiSampler::resourceType() const
2904{
2905 return Sampler;
2906}
2907
2908/*!
2909 \class QRhiRenderPassDescriptor
2910 \internal
2911 \inmodule QtGui
2912 \brief Render pass resource.
2913
2914 A render pass, if such a concept exists in the underlying graphics API, is
2915 a collection of attachments (color, depth, stencil) and describes how those
2916 attachments are used.
2917 */
2918
2919/*!
2920 \internal
2921 */
2922QRhiRenderPassDescriptor::QRhiRenderPassDescriptor(QRhiImplementation *rhi)
2923 : QRhiResource(rhi)
2924{
2925}
2926
2927/*!
2928 \return the resource type.
2929 */
2930QRhiResource::Type QRhiRenderPassDescriptor::resourceType() const
2931{
2932 return RenderPassDescriptor;
2933}
2934
2935/*!
2936 \fn bool QRhiRenderPassDescriptor::isCompatible(const QRhiRenderPassDescriptor *other) const
2937
2938 \return true if the \a other QRhiRenderPassDescriptor is compatible with
2939 this one, meaning \c this and \a other can be used interchangebly in
2940 QRhiGraphicsPipeline::setRenderPassDescriptor().
2941
2942 The concept of the compatibility of renderpass descriptors is similar to
2943 the \l{QRhiShaderResourceBindings::isLayoutCompatible}{layout
2944 compatibility} of QRhiShaderResourceBindings instances. They allow better
2945 reuse of QRhiGraphicsPipeline instances: for example, a
2946 QRhiGraphicsPipeline instance cache is expected to use these functions to
2947 look for a matching pipeline, instead of just comparing pointers, thus
2948 allowing a different QRhiRenderPassDescriptor and
2949 QRhiShaderResourceBindings to be used in combination with the pipeline, as
2950 long as they are compatible.
2951
2952 The exact details of compatibility depend on the underlying graphics API.
2953 Two renderpass descriptors
2954 \l{QRhiTextureRenderTarget::newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor()}{created}
2955 from the same QRhiTextureRenderTarget are always compatible.
2956
2957 Similarly to QRhiShaderResourceBindings, compatibility can also be tested
2958 without having two existing objects available. Extracting the opaque blob by
2959 calling serializedFormat() allows testing for compatibility by comparing the
2960 returned vector to another QRhiRenderPassDescriptor's
2961 serializedFormat(). This has benefits in certain situations, because it
2962 allows testing the compatibility of a QRhiRenderPassDescriptor with a
2963 QRhiGraphicsPipeline even when the QRhiRenderPassDescriptor the pipeline was
2964 originally built was is no longer available (but the data returned from its
2965 serializedFormat() still is).
2966
2967 \sa newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor(), serializedFormat()
2968 */
2969
2970/*!
2971 \fn QRhiRenderPassDescriptor *QRhiRenderPassDescriptor::newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor() const
2972
2973 \return a new QRhiRenderPassDescriptor that is
2974 \l{isCompatible()}{compatible} with this one.
2975
2976 This function allows cloning a QRhiRenderPassDescriptor. The returned
2977 object is ready to be used, and the ownership is transferred to the caller.
2978 Cloning a QRhiRenderPassDescriptor object can become useful in situations
2979 where the object is stored in data structures related to graphics pipelines
2980 (in order to allow creating new pipelines which in turn requires a
2981 renderpass descriptor object), and the lifetime of the renderpass
2982 descriptor created from a render target may be shorter than the pipelines.
2983 (for example, because the engine manages and destroys renderpasses together
2984 with the textures and render targets it was created from) In such a
2985 situation, it can be beneficial to store a cloned version in the data
2986 structures, and thus transferring ownership as well.
2987
2988 \sa isCompatible()
2989 */
2990
2991/*!
2992 \fn QVector<quint32> QRhiRenderPassDescriptor::serializedFormat() const
2993
2994 \return a vector of integers containing an opaque blob describing the data
2995 relevant for \l{isCompatible()}{compatibility}.
2996
2997 Given two QRhiRenderPassDescriptor objects \c rp1 and \c rp2, if the data
2998 returned from this function is identical, then \c{rp1->isCompatible(rp2)},
2999 and vice versa hold true as well.
3000
3001 \note The returned data is meant to be used for storing in memory and
3002 comparisons during the lifetime of the QRhi the object belongs to. It is not
3003 meant for storing on disk, reusing between processes, or using with multiple
3004 QRhi instances with potentially different backends.
3005
3006 \sa isCompatible()
3007 */
3008
3009/*!
3010 \return a pointer to a backend-specific QRhiNativeHandles subclass, such as
3011 QRhiVulkanRenderPassNativeHandles. The returned value is \nullptr when exposing
3012 the underlying native resources is not supported by the backend.
3013
3014 \sa QRhiVulkanRenderPassNativeHandles
3015 */
3016const QRhiNativeHandles *QRhiRenderPassDescriptor::nativeHandles()
3017{
3018 return nullptr;
3019}
3020
3021/*!
3022 \class QRhiRenderTarget
3023 \internal
3024 \inmodule QtGui
3025 \brief Represents an onscreen (swapchain) or offscreen (texture) render target.
3026
3027 \sa QRhiSwapChainRenderTarget, QRhiTextureRenderTarget
3028 */
3029
3030/*!
3031 \internal
3032 */
3033QRhiRenderTarget::QRhiRenderTarget(QRhiImplementation *rhi)
3034 : QRhiResource(rhi)
3035{
3036}
3037
3038/*!
3039 \fn QSize QRhiRenderTarget::pixelSize() const
3040
3041 \return the size in pixels.
3042
3043 Valid only after create() has been called successfully. Until then the
3044 result is a default-constructed QSize.
3045
3046 With QRhiTextureRenderTarget the returned size is the size of the
3047 associated attachments at the time of create(), in practice the size of the
3048 first color attachment, or the depth/stencil buffer if there are no color
3049 attachments. If the associated textures or renderbuffers are resized and
3050 rebuilt afterwards, then pixelSize() performs an implicit call to create()
3051 in order to rebuild the underlying data structures. This implicit check is
3052 similar to what QRhiCommandBuffer::beginPass() does, and ensures that the
3053 returned size is always up-to-date.
3054 */
3055
3056/*!
3057 \fn float QRhiRenderTarget::devicePixelRatio() const
3058
3059 \return the device pixel ratio. For QRhiTextureRenderTarget this is always
3060 1. For targets retrieved from a QRhiSwapChain the value reflects the
3061 \l{QWindow::devicePixelRatio()}{device pixel ratio} of the targeted
3062 QWindow.
3063 */
3064
3065/*!
3066 \internal
3067 */
3068QRhiSwapChainRenderTarget::QRhiSwapChainRenderTarget(QRhiImplementation *rhi, QRhiSwapChain *swapchain_)
3069 : QRhiRenderTarget(rhi),
3070 m_swapchain(swapchain_)
3071{
3072}
3073
3074/*!
3075 \class QRhiSwapChainRenderTarget
3076 \internal
3077 \inmodule QtGui
3078 \brief Swapchain render target resource.
3079
3080 When targeting the color buffers of a swapchain, active render target is a
3081 QRhiSwapChainRenderTarget. This is what
3082 QRhiSwapChain::currentFrameRenderTarget() returns.
3083
3084 \sa QRhiSwapChain
3085 */
3086
3087/*!
3088 \return the resource type.
3089 */
3090QRhiResource::Type QRhiSwapChainRenderTarget::resourceType() const
3091{
3092 return SwapChainRenderTarget;
3093}
3094
3095/*!
3096 \fn QRhiSwapChain *QRhiSwapChainRenderTarget::swapChain() const
3097
3098 \return the swapchain object.
3099 */
3100
3101/*!
3102 \class QRhiTextureRenderTarget
3103 \internal
3104 \inmodule QtGui
3105 \brief Texture render target resource.
3106
3107 A texture render target allows rendering into one or more textures,
3108 optionally with a depth texture or depth/stencil renderbuffer.
3109
3110 For multisample rendering the common approach is to use a renderbuffer as
3111 the color attachment and set the non-multisample destination texture as the
3112 \c{resolve texture}.
3113
3114 \note Textures used in combination with QRhiTextureRenderTarget must be
3115 created with the QRhiTexture::RenderTarget flag.
3116
3117 The simplest example of creating a render target with a texture as its
3118 single color attachment:
3119
3120 \badcode
3121 texture = rhi->newTexture(QRhiTexture::RGBA8, size, 1, QRhiTexture::RenderTarget);
3122 texture->create();
3123 rt = rhi->newTextureRenderTarget({ texture });
3124 rp = rt->newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor();
3125 rt->setRenderPassDescriptor(rt);
3126 rt->create();
3127 // rt can now be used with beginPass()
3128 \endcode
3129 */
3130
3131/*!
3132 \enum QRhiTextureRenderTarget::Flag
3133
3134 Flag values describing the load/store behavior for the render target. The
3135 load/store behavior may be baked into native resources under the hood,
3136 depending on the backend, and therefore it needs to be known upfront and
3137 cannot be changed without rebuilding (and so releasing and creating new
3138 native resources).
3139
3140 \value PreserveColorContents Indicates that the contents of the color
3141 attachments is to be loaded when starting a render pass, instead of
3142 clearing. This is potentially more expensive, especially on mobile (tiled)
3143 GPUs, but allows preserving the existing contents between passes.
3144
3145 \value PreserveDepthStencilContents Indicates that the contents of the
3146 depth texture is to be loaded when starting a render pass, instead
3147 clearing. Only applicable when a texture is used as the depth buffer
3148 (QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription::depthTexture() is set) because
3149 depth/stencil renderbuffers may not have any physical backing and data may
3150 not be written out in the first place.
3151 */
3152
3153/*!
3154 \internal
3155 */
3156QRhiTextureRenderTarget::QRhiTextureRenderTarget(QRhiImplementation *rhi,
3157 const QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription &desc_,
3158 Flags flags_)
3159 : QRhiRenderTarget(rhi),
3160 m_desc(desc_),
3161 m_flags(flags_)
3162{
3163}
3164
3165/*!
3166 \return the resource type.
3167 */
3168QRhiResource::Type QRhiTextureRenderTarget::resourceType() const
3169{
3170 return TextureRenderTarget;
3171}
3172
3173/*!
3174 \fn QRhiRenderPassDescriptor *QRhiTextureRenderTarget::newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor()
3175
3176 \return a new QRhiRenderPassDescriptor that is compatible with this render
3177 target.
3178
3179 The returned value is used in two ways: it can be passed to
3180 setRenderPassDescriptor() and
3181 QRhiGraphicsPipeline::setRenderPassDescriptor(). A render pass descriptor
3182 describes the attachments (color, depth/stencil) and the load/store
3183 behavior that can be affected by flags(). A QRhiGraphicsPipeline can only
3184 be used in combination with a render target that has the same
3185 QRhiRenderPassDescriptor set.
3186
3187 Two QRhiTextureRenderTarget instances can share the same render pass
3188 descriptor as long as they have the same number and type of attachments.
3189 The associated QRhiTexture or QRhiRenderBuffer instances are not part of
3190 the render pass descriptor so those can differ in the two
3191 QRhiTextureRenderTarget instances.
3192
3193 \note resources, such as QRhiTexture instances, referenced in description()
3194 must already have create() called on them.
3195
3196 \sa create()
3197 */
3198
3199/*!
3200 \fn bool QRhiTextureRenderTarget::create()
3201
3202 Creates the corresponding native graphics resources. If there are already
3203 resources present due to an earlier create() with no corresponding
3204 destroy(), then destroy() is called implicitly first.
3205
3206 \note renderPassDescriptor() must be set before calling create(). To obtain
3207 a QRhiRenderPassDescriptor compatible with the render target, call
3208 newCompatibleRenderPassDescriptor() before create() but after setting all
3209 other parameters, such as description() and flags(). To save resources,
3210 reuse the same QRhiRenderPassDescriptor with multiple
3211 QRhiTextureRenderTarget instances, whenever possible. Sharing the same
3212 render pass descriptor is only possible when the render targets have the
3213 same number and type of attachments (the actual textures can differ) and
3214 the same flags.
3215
3216 \note resources, such as QRhiTexture instances, referenced in description()
3217 must already have create() called on them.
3218
3219 \return \c true when successful, \c false when a graphics operation failed.
3220 Regardless of the return value, calling destroy() is always safe.
3221 */
3222
3223/*!
3224 \class QRhiShaderResourceBindings
3225 \internal
3226 \inmodule QtGui
3227 \brief Encapsulates resources for making buffer, texture, sampler resources visible to shaders.
3228
3229 A QRhiShaderResourceBindings is a collection of QRhiShaderResourceBinding
3230 objects, each of which describe a single binding.
3231
3232 Take a fragment shader with the following interface:
3233
3234 \badcode
3235 layout(std140, binding = 0) uniform buf {
3236 mat4 mvp;
3237 int flip;
3238 } ubuf;
3239
3240 layout(binding = 1) uniform sampler2D tex;
3241 \endcode
3242
3243 To make resources visible to the shader, the following
3244 QRhiShaderResourceBindings could be created and then passed to
3245 QRhiGraphicsPipeline::setShaderResourceBindings():
3246
3247 \badcode
3248 srb = rhi->newShaderResourceBindings();
3249 srb->setBindings({
3250 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBuffer(0, QRhiShaderResourceBinding::VertexStage | QRhiShaderResourceBinding::FragmentStage, ubuf),
3251 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::sampledTexture(1, QRhiShaderResourceBinding::FragmentStage, texture, sampler)
3252 });
3253 srb->create();
3254 ...
3255 ps = rhi->newGraphicsPipeline();
3256 ...
3257 ps->setShaderResourceBindings(srb);
3258 ps->create();
3259 ...
3260 cb->setGraphicsPipeline(ps);
3261 cb->setShaderResources(); // binds srb
3262 \endcode
3263
3264 This assumes that \c ubuf is a QRhiBuffer, \c texture is a QRhiTexture,
3265 while \a sampler is a QRhiSampler. The example also assumes that the
3266 uniform block is present in the vertex shader as well so the same buffer is
3267 made visible to the vertex stage too.
3268
3269 \section3 Advanced usage
3270
3271 Building on the above example, let's assume that a pass now needs to use
3272 the exact same pipeline and shaders with a different texture. Creating a
3273 whole separate QRhiGraphicsPipeline just for this would be an overkill.
3274 This is why QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources() allows specifying a \a
3275 srb argument. As long as the layouts (so the number of bindings and the
3276 binding points) match between two QRhiShaderResourceBindings, they can both
3277 be used with the same pipeline, assuming the pipeline was created with one of
3278 them in the first place.
3279
3280 \badcode
3281 srb2 = rhi->newShaderResourceBindings();
3282 ...
3283 cb->setGraphicsPipeline(ps);
3284 cb->setShaderResources(srb2); // binds srb2
3285 \endcode
3286 */
3287
3288/*!
3289 \internal
3290 */
3291QRhiShaderResourceBindings::QRhiShaderResourceBindings(QRhiImplementation *rhi)
3292 : QRhiResource(rhi)
3293{
3294 m_layoutDesc.reserve(size: BINDING_PREALLOC * QRhiShaderResourceBinding::LAYOUT_DESC_ENTRIES_PER_BINDING);
3295}
3296
3297/*!
3298 \return the resource type.
3299 */
3300QRhiResource::Type QRhiShaderResourceBindings::resourceType() const
3301{
3302 return ShaderResourceBindings;
3303}
3304
3305/*!
3306 \return \c true if the layout is compatible with \a other. The layout does
3307 not include the actual resource (such as, buffer or texture) and related
3308 parameters (such as, offset or size). It does include the binding point,
3309 pipeline stage, and resource type, however. The number and order of the
3310 bindings must also match in order to be compatible.
3311
3312 When there is a QRhiGraphicsPipeline created with this
3313 QRhiShaderResourceBindings, and the function returns \c true, \a other can
3314 then safely be passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(), and so
3315 be used with the pipeline in place of this QRhiShaderResourceBindings.
3316
3317 \note This function must only be called after a successful create(), because
3318 it relies on data generated during the baking of the underlying data
3319 structures. This way the function can implement a comparison approach that
3320 is more efficient than iterating through two binding lists and calling
3321 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::isLayoutCompatible() on each pair. This becomes
3322 relevant especially when this function is called at a high frequency.
3323
3324 \sa serializedLayoutDescription()
3325 */
3326bool QRhiShaderResourceBindings::isLayoutCompatible(const QRhiShaderResourceBindings *other) const
3327{
3328 if (other == this)
3329 return true;
3330
3331 if (!other)
3332 return false;
3333
3334 // This can become a hot code path. Therefore we do not iterate and call
3335 // isLayoutCompatible() on m_bindings, but rather check a pre-calculated
3336 // hash code and then, if the hash matched, do a uint array comparison
3337 // (that's still more cache friendly).
3338
3339 return m_layoutDescHash == other->m_layoutDescHash
3340 && m_layoutDesc == other->m_layoutDesc;
3341}
3342
3343/*!
3344 \fn QVector<quint32> QRhiShaderResourceBindings::serializedLayoutDescription() const
3345
3346 \return a vector of integers containing an opaque blob describing the layout
3347 of the binding list, i.e. the data relevant for
3348 \l{isLayoutCompatible()}{layout compatibility tests}.
3349
3350 Given two objects \c srb1 and \c srb2, if the data returned from this
3351 function is identical, then \c{srb1->isLayoutCompatible(srb2), and vice
3352 versa hold true as well.
3353
3354 \note The returned data is meant to be used for storing in memory and
3355 comparisons during the lifetime of the QRhi the object belongs to. It is not
3356 meant for storing on disk, reusing between processes, or using with multiple
3357 QRhi instances with potentially different backends.
3358
3359 \sa isLayoutCompatible()
3360 */
3361
3362void QRhiImplementation::updateLayoutDesc(QRhiShaderResourceBindings *srb)
3363{
3364 srb->m_layoutDescHash = 0;
3365 srb->m_layoutDesc.clear();
3366 auto layoutDescAppender = std::back_inserter(x&: srb->m_layoutDesc);
3367 for (const QRhiShaderResourceBinding &b : std::as_const(t&: srb->m_bindings)) {
3368 const QRhiShaderResourceBinding::Data *d = b.data();
3369 srb->m_layoutDescHash ^= uint(d->binding) ^ uint(d->stage) ^ uint(d->type)
3370 ^ uint(d->arraySize());
3371 layoutDescAppender = d->serialize(dst: layoutDescAppender);
3372 }
3373}
3374
3375/*!
3376 \class QRhiShaderResourceBinding
3377 \internal
3378 \inmodule QtGui
3379 \brief Describes the shader resource for a single binding point.
3380
3381 A QRhiShaderResourceBinding cannot be constructed directly. Instead, use the
3382 static functions such as uniformBuffer() or sampledTexture() to get an
3383 instance.
3384 */
3385
3386/*!
3387 \enum QRhiShaderResourceBinding::Type
3388 Specifies type of the shader resource bound to a binding point
3389
3390 \value UniformBuffer Uniform buffer
3391
3392 \value SampledTexture Combined image sampler
3393
3394 \value ImageLoad Image load (with GLSL this maps to doing imageLoad() on a
3395 single level - and either one or all layers - of a texture exposed to the
3396 shader as an image object)
3397
3398 \value ImageStore Image store (with GLSL this maps to doing imageStore() or
3399 imageAtomic*() on a single level - and either one or all layers - of a
3400 texture exposed to the shader as an image object)
3401
3402 \value ImageLoadStore Image load and store
3403
3404 \value BufferLoad Storage buffer store (with GLSL this maps to reading from
3405 a shader storage buffer)
3406
3407 \value BufferStore Storage buffer store (with GLSL this maps to writing to
3408 a shader storage buffer)
3409
3410 \value BufferLoadStore Storage buffer load and store
3411 */
3412
3413/*!
3414 \enum QRhiShaderResourceBinding::StageFlag
3415 Flag values to indicate which stages the shader resource is visible in
3416
3417 \value VertexStage Vertex stage
3418 \value TessellationControlStage Tessellation control (hull shader) stage
3419 \value TessellationEvaluationStage Tessellation evaluation (domain shader) stage
3420 \value FragmentStage Fragment (pixel shader) stage
3421 \value ComputeStage Compute stage
3422 \value GeometryStage Geometry stage
3423 */
3424
3425/*!
3426 \return \c true if the layout is compatible with \a other. The layout does not
3427 include the actual resource (such as, buffer or texture) and related
3428 parameters (such as, offset or size).
3429
3430 For example, \c a and \c b below are not equal, but are compatible layout-wise:
3431
3432 \badcode
3433 auto a = QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBuffer(0, QRhiShaderResourceBinding::VertexStage, buffer);
3434 auto b = QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBuffer(0, QRhiShaderResourceBinding::VertexStage, someOtherBuffer, 256);
3435 \endcode
3436 */
3437bool QRhiShaderResourceBinding::isLayoutCompatible(const QRhiShaderResourceBinding &other) const
3438{
3439 // everything that goes into a VkDescriptorSetLayoutBinding must match
3440 return d.binding == other.d.binding
3441 && d.stage == other.d.stage
3442 && d.type == other.d.type
3443 && d.arraySize() == other.d.arraySize();
3444}
3445
3446/*!
3447 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3448 stages, and buffer specified by \a binding, \a stage, and \a buf.
3449
3450 \note When \a buf is not null, it must have been created with
3451 QRhiBuffer::UniformBuffer.
3452
3453 \note \a buf can be null. It is valid to create a
3454 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3455 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3456 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3457 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3458 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3459
3460 \note If the size of \a buf exceeds the limit reported for
3461 QRhi::MaxUniformBufferRange, unexpected errors may occur.
3462 */
3463QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBuffer(
3464 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiBuffer *buf)
3465{
3466 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3467 b.d.binding = binding;
3468 b.d.stage = stage;
3469 b.d.type = UniformBuffer;
3470 b.d.u.ubuf.buf = buf;
3471 b.d.u.ubuf.offset = 0;
3472 b.d.u.ubuf.maybeSize = 0; // entire buffer
3473 b.d.u.ubuf.hasDynamicOffset = false;
3474 return b;
3475}
3476
3477/*!
3478 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3479 stages, and buffer specified by \a binding, \a stage, and \a buf. This
3480 overload binds a region only, as specified by \a offset and \a size.
3481
3482 \note It is up to the user to ensure the offset is aligned to
3483 QRhi::ubufAlignment().
3484
3485 \note \a size must be greater than 0.
3486
3487 \note When \a buf is not null, it must have been created with
3488 QRhiBuffer::UniformBuffer.
3489
3490 \note \a buf can be null. It is valid to create a
3491 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3492 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3493 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3494 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3495 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3496
3497 \note If \a size exceeds the limit reported for QRhi::MaxUniformBufferRange,
3498 unexpected errors may occur.
3499 */
3500QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBuffer(
3501 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiBuffer *buf, quint32 offset, quint32 size)
3502{
3503 Q_ASSERT(size > 0);
3504 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3505 b.d.binding = binding;
3506 b.d.stage = stage;
3507 b.d.type = UniformBuffer;
3508 b.d.u.ubuf.buf = buf;
3509 b.d.u.ubuf.offset = offset;
3510 b.d.u.ubuf.maybeSize = size;
3511 b.d.u.ubuf.hasDynamicOffset = false;
3512 return b;
3513}
3514
3515/*!
3516 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3517 stages, and buffer specified by \a binding, \a stage, and \a buf. The
3518 uniform buffer is assumed to have dynamic offset. The dynamic offset can be
3519 specified in QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(), thus allowing using
3520 varying offset values without creating new bindings for the buffer. The
3521 size of the bound region is specified by \a size. Like with non-dynamic
3522 offsets, \c{offset + size} cannot exceed the size of \a buf.
3523
3524 \note When \a buf is not null, it must have been created with
3525 QRhiBuffer::UniformBuffer.
3526
3527 \note \a buf can be null. It is valid to create a
3528 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3529 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3530 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3531 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3532 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3533
3534 \note If \a size exceeds the limit reported for QRhi::MaxUniformBufferRange,
3535 unexpected errors may occur.
3536 */
3537QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBufferWithDynamicOffset(
3538 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiBuffer *buf, quint32 size)
3539{
3540 Q_ASSERT(size > 0);
3541 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3542 b.d.binding = binding;
3543 b.d.stage = stage;
3544 b.d.type = UniformBuffer;
3545 b.d.u.ubuf.buf = buf;
3546 b.d.u.ubuf.offset = 0;
3547 b.d.u.ubuf.maybeSize = size;
3548 b.d.u.ubuf.hasDynamicOffset = true;
3549 return b;
3550}
3551
3552/*!
3553 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3554 stages, texture, and sampler specified by \a binding, \a stage, \a tex,
3555 \a sampler.
3556
3557 \note This function is equivalent to calling sampledTextures() with a
3558 \c count of 1.
3559
3560 \note \a tex and \a sampler can be null. It is valid to create a
3561 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3562 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3563 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3564 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3565 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3566
3567 \sa sampledTextures()
3568 */
3569QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::sampledTexture(
3570 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiTexture *tex, QRhiSampler *sampler)
3571{
3572 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3573 b.d.binding = binding;
3574 b.d.stage = stage;
3575 b.d.type = SampledTexture;
3576 b.d.u.stex.count = 1;
3577 b.d.u.stex.texSamplers[0] = { .tex: tex, .sampler: sampler };
3578 return b;
3579}
3580
3581/*!
3582 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3583 stages, and the array of texture-sampler pairs specified by \a binding, \a
3584 stage, \a count, and \a texSamplers.
3585
3586 \note \a count must be at least 1, and not larger than 16.
3587
3588 \note When \a count is 1, this function is equivalent to sampledTexture().
3589
3590 This function is relevant when arrays of combined image samplers are
3591 involved. For example, in GLSL \c{layout(binding = 5) uniform sampler2D
3592 shadowMaps[8];} declares an array of combined image samplers. The
3593 application is then expected provide a QRhiShaderResourceBinding for
3594 binding point 5, set up by calling this function with \a count set to 8 and
3595 a valid texture and sampler for each element of the array.
3596
3597 \warning All elements of the array must be specified. With the above
3598 example, the only valid, portable approach is calling this function with a
3599 \a count of 8. Additionally, all QRhiTexture and QRhiSampler instances must
3600 be valid, meaning nullptr is not an accepted value. This is due to some of
3601 the underlying APIs, such as, Vulkan, that require a valid image and
3602 sampler object for each element in descriptor arrays. Applications are
3603 advised to provide "dummy" samplers and textures if some array elements are
3604 not relevant (due to not being accessed in the shader).
3605
3606 \note \a texSamplers can be null. It is valid to create a
3607 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3608 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3609 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3610 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3611 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3612
3613 \sa sampledTexture()
3614 */
3615QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::sampledTextures(
3616 int binding, StageFlags stage, int count, const TextureAndSampler *texSamplers)
3617{
3618 Q_ASSERT(count >= 1 && count <= Data::MAX_TEX_SAMPLER_ARRAY_SIZE);
3619 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3620 b.d.binding = binding;
3621 b.d.stage = stage;
3622 b.d.type = SampledTexture;
3623 b.d.u.stex.count = count;
3624 for (int i = 0; i < count; ++i) {
3625 if (texSamplers)
3626 b.d.u.stex.texSamplers[i] = texSamplers[i];
3627 else
3628 b.d.u.stex.texSamplers[i] = { .tex: nullptr, .sampler: nullptr };
3629 }
3630 return b;
3631}
3632
3633/*!
3634 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3635 stages, and texture specified by \a binding, \a stage, \a tex.
3636
3637 \note This function is equivalent to calling textures() with a
3638 \c count of 1.
3639
3640 \note \a tex can be null. It is valid to create a
3641 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3642 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3643 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3644 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3645 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3646
3647 This creates a binding for a separate texture (image) object, whereas
3648 sampledTexture() is suitable for combined image samplers. In
3649 Vulkan-compatible GLSL code separate textures are declared as \c texture2D
3650 as opposed to \c sampler2D: \c{layout(binding = 1) uniform texture2D tex;}
3651
3652 \sa textures(), sampler()
3653 */
3654QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::texture(int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiTexture *tex)
3655{
3656 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3657 b.d.binding = binding;
3658 b.d.stage = stage;
3659 b.d.type = Texture;
3660 b.d.u.stex.count = 1;
3661 b.d.u.stex.texSamplers[0] = { .tex: tex, .sampler: nullptr };
3662 return b;
3663}
3664
3665/*!
3666 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3667 stages, and the array of (separate) textures specified by \a binding, \a
3668 stage, \a count, and \a tex.
3669
3670 \note \a count must be at least 1, and not larger than 16.
3671
3672 \note When \a count is 1, this function is equivalent to texture().
3673
3674 \warning All elements of the array must be specified.
3675
3676 \note \a tex can be null. It is valid to create a
3677 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3678 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3679 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3680 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3681 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3682
3683 \sa texture(), sampler()
3684 */
3685QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::textures(int binding, StageFlags stage, int count, QRhiTexture **tex)
3686{
3687 Q_ASSERT(count >= 1 && count <= Data::MAX_TEX_SAMPLER_ARRAY_SIZE);
3688 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3689 b.d.binding = binding;
3690 b.d.stage = stage;
3691 b.d.type = Texture;
3692 b.d.u.stex.count = count;
3693 for (int i = 0; i < count; ++i) {
3694 if (tex)
3695 b.d.u.stex.texSamplers[i] = { .tex: tex[i], .sampler: nullptr };
3696 else
3697 b.d.u.stex.texSamplers[i] = { .tex: nullptr, .sampler: nullptr };
3698 }
3699 return b;
3700}
3701
3702/*!
3703 \return a shader resource binding for the given binding number, pipeline
3704 stages, and sampler specified by \a binding, \a stage, \a sampler.
3705
3706 \note \a sampler can be null. It is valid to create a
3707 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3708 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3709 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3710 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3711 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3712
3713 Arrays of separate samplers are not supported.
3714
3715 This creates a binding for a separate sampler object, whereas
3716 sampledTexture() is suitable for combined image samplers. In
3717 Vulkan-compatible GLSL code separate samplers are declared as \c sampler
3718 as opposed to \c sampler2D: \c{layout(binding = 2) uniform sampler samp;}
3719
3720 With both a \c texture2D and \c sampler present, they can be used together
3721 to sample the texture: \c{fragColor = texture(sampler2D(tex, samp),
3722 texcoord);}.
3723
3724 \sa texture()
3725 */
3726QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::sampler(int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiSampler *sampler)
3727{
3728 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3729 b.d.binding = binding;
3730 b.d.stage = stage;
3731 b.d.type = Sampler;
3732 b.d.u.stex.count = 1;
3733 b.d.u.stex.texSamplers[0] = { .tex: nullptr, .sampler: sampler };
3734 return b;
3735}
3736
3737/*!
3738 \return a shader resource binding for a read-only storage image with the
3739 given \a binding number and pipeline \a stage. The image load operations
3740 will have access to all layers of the specified \a level. (so if the texture
3741 is a cubemap, the shader must use imageCube instead of image2D)
3742
3743 \note When \a tex is not null, it must have been created with
3744 QRhiTexture::UsedWithLoadStore.
3745
3746 \note \a tex can be null. It is valid to create a QRhiShaderResourceBindings
3747 with unspecified resources, but such an object cannot be used with
3748 QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however suitable for creating
3749 pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used together with another,
3750 layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with resources present passed
3751 to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3752
3753 \note Image load/store is only guaranteed to be available within a compute
3754 pipeline. While some backends may support using these resources in a
3755 graphics pipeline as well, this is not universally supported, and even when
3756 it is, unexpected problems may arise when it comes to barriers and
3757 synchronization. Therefore, avoid using such resources with shaders other
3758 than compute.
3759 */
3760QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::imageLoad(
3761 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiTexture *tex, int level)
3762{
3763 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3764 b.d.binding = binding;
3765 b.d.stage = stage;
3766 b.d.type = ImageLoad;
3767 b.d.u.simage.tex = tex;
3768 b.d.u.simage.level = level;
3769 return b;
3770}
3771
3772/*!
3773 \return a shader resource binding for a write-only storage image with the
3774 given \a binding number and pipeline \a stage. The image store operations
3775 will have access to all layers of the specified \a level. (so if the texture
3776 is a cubemap, the shader must use imageCube instead of image2D)
3777
3778 \note When \a tex is not null, it must have been created with
3779 QRhiTexture::UsedWithLoadStore.
3780
3781 \note \a tex can be null. It is valid to create a QRhiShaderResourceBindings
3782 with unspecified resources, but such an object cannot be used with
3783 QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however suitable for creating
3784 pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used together with another,
3785 layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with resources present passed
3786 to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3787
3788 \note Image load/store is only guaranteed to be available within a compute
3789 pipeline. While some backends may support using these resources in a
3790 graphics pipeline as well, this is not universally supported, and even when
3791 it is, unexpected problems may arise when it comes to barriers and
3792 synchronization. Therefore, avoid using such resources with shaders other
3793 than compute.
3794 */
3795QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::imageStore(
3796 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiTexture *tex, int level)
3797{
3798 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3799 b.d.binding = binding;
3800 b.d.stage = stage;
3801 b.d.type = ImageStore;
3802 b.d.u.simage.tex = tex;
3803 b.d.u.simage.level = level;
3804 return b;
3805}
3806
3807/*!
3808 \return a shader resource binding for a read/write storage image with the
3809 given \a binding number and pipeline \a stage. The image load/store operations
3810 will have access to all layers of the specified \a level. (so if the texture
3811 is a cubemap, the shader must use imageCube instead of image2D)
3812
3813 \note When \a tex is not null, it must have been created with
3814 QRhiTexture::UsedWithLoadStore.
3815
3816 \note \a tex can be null. It is valid to create a QRhiShaderResourceBindings
3817 with unspecified resources, but such an object cannot be used with
3818 QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however suitable for creating
3819 pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used together with another,
3820 layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with resources present passed
3821 to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3822
3823 \note Image load/store is only guaranteed to be available within a compute
3824 pipeline. While some backends may support using these resources in a
3825 graphics pipeline as well, this is not universally supported, and even when
3826 it is, unexpected problems may arise when it comes to barriers and
3827 synchronization. Therefore, avoid using such resources with shaders other
3828 than compute.
3829 */
3830QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::imageLoadStore(
3831 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiTexture *tex, int level)
3832{
3833 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3834 b.d.binding = binding;
3835 b.d.stage = stage;
3836 b.d.type = ImageLoadStore;
3837 b.d.u.simage.tex = tex;
3838 b.d.u.simage.level = level;
3839 return b;
3840}
3841
3842/*!
3843 \return a shader resource binding for a read-only storage buffer with the
3844 given \a binding number and pipeline \a stage.
3845
3846 \note When \a buf is not null, must have been created with
3847 QRhiBuffer::StorageBuffer.
3848
3849 \note \a buf can be null. It is valid to create a
3850 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3851 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3852 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3853 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3854 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3855
3856 \note Buffer load/store is only guaranteed to be available within a compute
3857 pipeline. While some backends may support using these resources in a
3858 graphics pipeline as well, this is not universally supported, and even when
3859 it is, unexpected problems may arise when it comes to barriers and
3860 synchronization. Therefore, avoid using such resources with shaders other
3861 than compute.
3862 */
3863QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::bufferLoad(
3864 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiBuffer *buf)
3865{
3866 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
3867 b.d.binding = binding;
3868 b.d.stage = stage;
3869 b.d.type = BufferLoad;
3870 b.d.u.sbuf.buf = buf;
3871 b.d.u.sbuf.offset = 0;
3872 b.d.u.sbuf.maybeSize = 0; // entire buffer
3873 return b;
3874}
3875
3876/*!
3877 \return a shader resource binding for a read-only storage buffer with the
3878 given \a binding number and pipeline \a stage. This overload binds a region
3879 only, as specified by \a offset and \a size.
3880
3881 \note When \a buf is not null, must have been created with
3882 QRhiBuffer::StorageBuffer.
3883
3884 \note \a buf can be null. It is valid to create a
3885 QRhiShaderResourceBindings with unspecified resources, but such an object
3886 cannot be used with QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(). It is however
3887 suitable for creating pipelines. Such a pipeline must then always be used
3888 together with another, layout compatible QRhiShaderResourceBindings with
3889 resources present passed to QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources().
3890
3891 \note Buffer load/store is only guaranteed to be available within a compute
3892 pipeline. While some backends may support using these resources in a
3893 graphics pipeline as well, this is not universally supported, and even when
3894 it is, unexpected problems may arise when it comes to barriers and
3895 synchronization. Therefore, avoid using such resources with shaders other
3896 than compute.
3897 */
3898QRhiShaderResourceBinding QRhiShaderResourceBinding::bufferLoad(
3899 int binding, StageFlags stage, QRhiBuffer *buf, quint32 offset, quint32 size)
3900{
3901 Q_ASSERT(size > 0);
3902 QRhiShaderResourceBinding b;
