6145 const uchar *p = reinterpret_cast<const uchar *>(rbResult->data.constData());
6146 QImage image(p, rbResult->pixelSize.width(), rbResult->pixelSize.height(), fmt);
6147 image.save("result.png");
6148 }
6149 delete rbResult;
6150 };
6151 u = nextResourceUpdateBatch();
6152 QRhiReadbackDescription rb; // no texture -> uses the current backbuffer of sc
6153 u->readBackTexture(rb, rbResult);
6154 endPass(u);
6155 endFrame(sc);
6156 \endcode
6157
6158 \note The texture must be created with QRhiTexture::UsedAsTransferSource.
6159
6160 \note Multisample textures cannot be read back.
6161
6162 \note The readback returns raw byte data, in order to allow the applications
6163 to interpret it in any way they see fit. Be aware of the blending settings
6164 of rendering code: if the blending is set up to rely on premultiplied alpha,
6165 the results of the readback must also be interpreted as Premultiplied.
6166
6167 \note When interpreting the resulting raw data, be aware that the readback
6168 happens with a byte ordered format. A \l{QRhiTexture::RGBA8}{RGBA8} texture
6169 maps therefore to byte ordered QImage formats, such as,
6170 QImage::Format_RGBA8888.
6171
6172 \note The asynchronous readback is guaranteed to have completed when one of
6173 the following conditions is met: \l{QRhi::finish()}{finish()} has been
6174 called; or, at least \c N frames have been \l{QRhi::endFrame()}{submitted},
6175 including the frame that issued the readback operation, and the
6176 \l{QRhi::beginFrame()}{recording of a new frame} has been started, where \c
6177 N is the \l{QRhi::resourceLimit()}{resource limit value} returned for
6178 QRhi::MaxAsyncReadbackFrames.
6179
6180 A single readback operation copies one mip level of one layer (cubemap face
6181 or 3D slice or texture array element) at a time. The level and layer are
6182 specified by the respective fields in \a rb.
6183
6184 \sa readBackBuffer(), QRhi::resourceLimit()
6185 */
6186void QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::readBackTexture(const QRhiReadbackDescription &rb, QRhiReadbackResult *result)
6187{
6188 const int idx = d->activeTextureOpCount++;
6189 if (idx < d->textureOps.size())
6190 d->textureOps[idx] = QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::TextureOp::read(rb, result);
6191 else
6192 d->textureOps.append(t: QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::TextureOp::read(rb, result));
6193}
6194
6195/*!
6196 Enqueues a mipmap generation operation for the specified texture \a tex.
6197
6198 Both 2D and cube textures are supported.
6199
6200 \note The texture must be created with QRhiTexture::MipMapped and
6201 QRhiTexture::UsedWithGenerateMips.
6202
6203 \warning QRhi cannot guarantee that mipmaps can be generated for all
6204 supported texture formats. For example, QRhiTexture::RGBA32F is not a \c
6205 filterable format in OpenGL ES 3.0 and Metal on iOS, and therefore the
6206 mipmap generation request may fail. RGBA8 and RGBA16F are typically
6207 filterable, so it is recommended to use these formats when mipmap generation
6208 is desired.
6209 */
6210void QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::generateMips(QRhiTexture *tex)
6211{
6212 const int idx = d->activeTextureOpCount++;
6213 if (idx < d->textureOps.size())
6214 d->textureOps[idx] = QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::TextureOp::genMips(tex);
6215 else
6216 d->textureOps.append(t: QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::TextureOp::genMips(tex));
6217}
6218
6219/*!
6220 \return an available, empty batch to which copy type of operations can be
6221 recorded.
6222
6223 \note the return value is not owned by the caller and must never be
6224 destroyed. Instead, the batch is returned the pool for reuse by passing
6225 it to QRhiCommandBuffer::beginPass(), QRhiCommandBuffer::endPass(), or
6226 QRhiCommandBuffer::resourceUpdate(), or by calling
6227 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch::destroy() on it.
6228
6229 \note Can be called outside beginFrame() - endFrame() as well since a batch
6230 instance just collects data on its own, it does not perform any operations.
6231
6232 \warning The maximum number of batches is 64. When this limit is reached,
6233 the function will return null until a batch is returned to the pool.
6234 */
6235QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *QRhi::nextResourceUpdateBatch()
6236{
6237 auto nextFreeBatch = [this]() -> QRhiResourceUpdateBatch * {
6238 auto isFree = [this](int i) -> QRhiResourceUpdateBatch * {
6239 const quint64 mask = 1ULL << quint64(i);
6240 if (!(d->resUpdPoolMap & mask)) {
6241 d->resUpdPoolMap |= mask;
6242 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *u = d->resUpdPool[i];
6243 QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::get(b: u)->poolIndex = i;
6244 d->lastResUpdIdx = i;
6245 return u;
6246 }
6247 return nullptr;
6248 };
6249 const int poolSize = d->resUpdPool.size();
6250 for (int i = d->lastResUpdIdx + 1; i < poolSize; ++i) {
6251 if (QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *u = isFree(i))
6252 return u;
6253 }
6254 for (int i = 0; i <= d->lastResUpdIdx; ++i) {
6255 if (QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *u = isFree(i))
6256 return u;
6257 }
6258 return nullptr;
6259 };
6260
6261 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *u = nextFreeBatch();
6262 if (!u) {
6263 const int oldSize = d->resUpdPool.size();
6264 const int newSize = oldSize + qMin(a: 4, b: qMax(a: 0, b: 64 - oldSize));
6265 d->resUpdPool.resize(sz: newSize);
6266 for (int i = oldSize; i < newSize; ++i)
6267 d->resUpdPool[i] = new QRhiResourceUpdateBatch(d);
6268 u = nextFreeBatch();
6269 if (!u)
6270 qWarning(msg: "Resource update batch pool exhausted (max is 64)");
6271 }
6272
6273 return u;
6274}
6275
6276void QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::free()
6277{
6278 Q_ASSERT(poolIndex >= 0 && rhi->resUpdPool[poolIndex] == q);
6279
6280 activeBufferOpCount = 0;
6281 activeTextureOpCount = 0;
6282
6283 const quint64 mask = 1ULL << quint64(poolIndex);
6284 rhi->resUpdPoolMap &= ~mask;
6285 poolIndex = -1;
6286
6287 textureOps.clear();
6288}
6289
6290void QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::merge(QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate *other)
6291{
6292 int combinedSize = activeBufferOpCount + other->activeBufferOpCount;
6293 if (bufferOps.size() < combinedSize)
6294 bufferOps.resize(sz: combinedSize);
6295 for (int i = activeBufferOpCount; i < combinedSize; ++i)
6296 bufferOps[i] = std::move(other->bufferOps[i - activeBufferOpCount]);
6297 activeBufferOpCount += other->activeBufferOpCount;
6298
6299 combinedSize = activeTextureOpCount + other->activeTextureOpCount;
6300 if (textureOps.size() < combinedSize)
6301 textureOps.resize(sz: combinedSize);
6302 for (int i = activeTextureOpCount; i < combinedSize; ++i)
6303 textureOps[i] = std::move(other->textureOps[i - activeTextureOpCount]);
6304 activeTextureOpCount += other->activeTextureOpCount;
6305}
6306
6307bool QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::hasOptimalCapacity() const
6308{
6309 return activeBufferOpCount < BUFFER_OPS_STATIC_ALLOC - 16
6310 && activeTextureOpCount < TEXTURE_OPS_STATIC_ALLOC - 16;
6311}
6312
6313void QRhiResourceUpdateBatchPrivate::trimOpLists()
6314{
6315 Q_ASSERT(poolIndex == -1); // must not be in use
6316
6317 activeBufferOpCount = 0;
6318 bufferOps.clear();
6319
6320 activeTextureOpCount = 0;
6321 textureOps.clear();
6322}
6323
6324/*!
6325 Sometimes committing resource updates is necessary without starting a
6326 render pass. Not often needed, updates should typically be passed to
6327 beginPass (or endPass, in case of readbacks) instead.
6328
6329 \note Cannot be called inside a pass.
6330 */
6331void QRhiCommandBuffer::resourceUpdate(QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *resourceUpdates)
6332{
6333 if (resourceUpdates)
6334 m_rhi->resourceUpdate(cb: this, resourceUpdates);
6335}
6336
6337/*!
6338 Records starting a new render pass targeting the render target \a rt.
6339
6340 \a resourceUpdates, when not null, specifies a resource update batch that
6341 is to be committed and then released.
6342
6343 The color and depth/stencil buffers of the render target are normally
6344 cleared. The clear values are specified in \a colorClearValue and \a
6345 depthStencilClearValue. The exception is when the render target was created
6346 with QRhiTextureRenderTarget::PreserveColorContents and/or
6347 QRhiTextureRenderTarget::PreserveDepthStencilContents. The clear values are
6348 ignored then.
6349
6350 \note Enabling preserved color or depth contents leads to decreased
6351 performance depending on the underlying hardware. Mobile GPUs with tiled
6352 architecture benefit from not having to reload the previous contents into
6353 the tile buffer. Similarly, a QRhiTextureRenderTarget with a QRhiTexture as
6354 the depth buffer is less efficient than a QRhiRenderBuffer since using a
6355 depth texture triggers requiring writing the data out to it, while with
6356 renderbuffers this is not needed (as the API does not allow sampling or
6357 reading from a renderbuffer).
6358
6359 \note Do not assume that any state or resource bindings persist between
6360 passes.
6361
6362 \note The QRhiCommandBuffer's \c set and \c draw functions can only be
6363 called inside a pass. Also, with the exception of setGraphicsPipeline(),
6364 they expect to have a pipeline set already on the command buffer.
6365 Unspecified issues may arise otherwise, depending on the backend.
6366
6367 If \a rt is a QRhiTextureRenderTarget, beginPass() performs a check to see
6368 if the texture and renderbuffer objects referenced from the render target
6369 are up-to-date. This is similar to what setShaderResources() does for
6370 QRhiShaderResourceBindings. If any of the attachments had been rebuilt
6371 since QRhiTextureRenderTarget::create(), an implicit call to create() is
6372 made on \a rt. Therefore, if \a rt has a QRhiTexture color attachment \c
6373 texture, and one needs to make the texture a different size, the following
6374 is then valid:
6375 \badcode
6376 rt = rhi->newTextureRenderTarget({ { texture } });
6377 rt->create();
6378 ...
6379 texture->setPixelSize(new_size);
6380 texture->create();
6381 cb->beginPass(rt, ...); // this is ok, no explicit rt->create() is required before
6382 \endcode
6383
6384 \sa endPass()
6385 */
6386void QRhiCommandBuffer::beginPass(QRhiRenderTarget *rt,
6387 const QColor &colorClearValue,
6388 const QRhiDepthStencilClearValue &depthStencilClearValue,
6389 QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *resourceUpdates,
6390 BeginPassFlags flags)
6391{
6392 m_rhi->beginPass(cb: this, rt, colorClearValue, depthStencilClearValue, resourceUpdates, flags);
6393}
6394
6395/*!
6396 Records ending the current render pass.
6397
6398 \a resourceUpdates, when not null, specifies a resource update batch that
6399 is to be committed and then released.
6400
6401 \sa beginPass()
6402 */
6403void QRhiCommandBuffer::endPass(QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *resourceUpdates)
6404{
6405 m_rhi->endPass(cb: this, resourceUpdates);
6406}
6407
6408/*!
6409 Records setting a new graphics pipeline \a ps.
6410
6411 \note This function must be called before recording other \c set or \c draw
6412 commands on the command buffer.
6413
6414 \note QRhi will optimize out unnecessary invocations within a pass, so
6415 therefore overoptimizing to avoid calls to this function is not necessary
6416 on the applications' side.
6417
6418 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning
6419 between a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6420
6421 \note The new graphics pipeline \a ps must be a valid pointer.
6422 */
6423void QRhiCommandBuffer::setGraphicsPipeline(QRhiGraphicsPipeline *ps)
6424{
6425 Q_ASSERT(ps != nullptr);
6426 m_rhi->setGraphicsPipeline(cb: this, ps);
6427}
6428
6429/*!
6430 Records binding a set of shader resources, such as, uniform buffers or
6431 textures, that are made visible to one or more shader stages.
6432
6433 \a srb can be null in which case the current graphics or compute pipeline's
6434 associated QRhiShaderResourceBindings is used. When \a srb is non-null, it
6435 must be
6436 \l{QRhiShaderResourceBindings::isLayoutCompatible()}{layout-compatible},
6437 meaning the layout (number of bindings, the type and binding number of each
6438 binding) must fully match the QRhiShaderResourceBindings that was
6439 associated with the pipeline at the time of calling the pipeline's create().
6440
6441 There are cases when a seemingly unnecessary setShaderResources() call is
6442 mandatory: when rebuilding a resource referenced from \a srb, for example
6443 changing the size of a QRhiBuffer followed by a QRhiBuffer::create(), this
6444 is the place where associated native objects (such as descriptor sets in
6445 case of Vulkan) are updated to refer to the current native resources that
6446 back the QRhiBuffer, QRhiTexture, QRhiSampler objects referenced from \a
6447 srb. In this case setShaderResources() must be called even if \a srb is
6448 the same as in the last call.
6449
6450 When \a srb is not null, the QRhiShaderResourceBindings object the pipeline
6451 was built with in create() is guaranteed to be not accessed in any form. In
6452 fact, it does not need to be valid even at this point: destroying the
6453 pipeline's associated srb after create() and instead explicitly specifying
6454 another, \l{QRhiShaderResourceBindings::isLayoutCompatible()}{layout
6455 compatible} one in every setShaderResources() call is valid.
6456
6457 \a dynamicOffsets allows specifying buffer offsets for uniform buffers that
6458 were associated with \a srb via
6459 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::uniformBufferWithDynamicOffset(). This is
6460 different from providing the offset in the \a srb itself: dynamic offsets
6461 do not require building a new QRhiShaderResourceBindings for every
6462 different offset, can avoid writing the underlying descriptors (with
6463 backends where applicable), and so they may be more efficient. Each element
6464 of \a dynamicOffsets is a \c binding - \c offset pair.
6465 \a dynamicOffsetCount specifies the number of elements in \a dynamicOffsets.
6466
6467 \note All offsets in \a dynamicOffsets must be byte aligned to the value
6468 returned from QRhi::ubufAlignment().
6469
6470 \note Some backends may limit the number of supported dynamic offsets.
6471 Avoid using a \a dynamicOffsetCount larger than 8.
6472
6473 \note QRhi will optimize out unnecessary invocations within a pass (taking
6474 the conditions described above into account), so therefore overoptimizing
6475 to avoid calls to this function is not necessary on the applications' side.
6476
6477 \note This function can only be called inside a render or compute pass,
6478 meaning between a beginPass() and endPass(), or beginComputePass() and
6479 endComputePass().
6480 */
6481void QRhiCommandBuffer::setShaderResources(QRhiShaderResourceBindings *srb,
6482 int dynamicOffsetCount,
6483 const DynamicOffset *dynamicOffsets)
6484{
6485 m_rhi->setShaderResources(cb: this, srb, dynamicOffsetCount, dynamicOffsets);
6486}
6487
6488/*!
6489 Records vertex input bindings.
6490
6491 The index buffer used by subsequent drawIndexed() commands is specified by
6492 \a indexBuf, \a indexOffset, and \a indexFormat. \a indexBuf can be set to
6493 null when indexed drawing is not needed.
6494
6495 Vertex buffer bindings are batched. \a startBinding specifies the first
6496 binding number. The recorded command then binds each buffer from \a
6497 bindings to the binding point \c{startBinding + i} where \c i is the index
6498 in \a bindings. Each element in \a bindings specifies a QRhiBuffer and an
6499 offset.
6500
6501 \note Some backends may limit the number of vertex buffer bindings. Avoid
6502 using a \a bindingCount larger than 8.
6503
6504 Superfluous vertex input and index changes in the same pass are ignored
6505 automatically with most backends and therefore applications do not need to
6506 overoptimize to avoid calls to this function.
6507
6508 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning
6509 between a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6510
6511 As a simple example, take a vertex shader with two inputs:
6512
6513 \badcode
6514 layout(location = 0) in vec4 position;
6515 layout(location = 1) in vec3 color;
6516 \endcode
6517
6518 and assume we have the data available in interleaved format, using only 2
6519 floats for position (so 5 floats per vertex: x, y, r, g, b). A QRhiGraphicsPipeline for
6520 this shader can then be created using the input layout:
6521
6522 \badcode
6523 QRhiVertexInputLayout inputLayout;
6524 inputLayout.setBindings({
6525 { 5 * sizeof(float) }
6526 });
6527 inputLayout.setAttributes({
6528 { 0, 0, QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float2, 0 },
6529 { 0, 1, QRhiVertexInputAttribute::Float3, 2 * sizeof(float) }
6530 });
6531 \endcode
6532
6533 Here there is one buffer binding (binding number 0), with two inputs
6534 referencing it. When recording the pass, once the pipeline is set, the
6535 vertex bindings can be specified simply like the following (using C++11
6536 initializer syntax), assuming vbuf is the QRhiBuffer with all the
6537 interleaved position+color data:
6538
6539 \badcode
6540 const QRhiCommandBuffer::VertexInput vbufBinding(vbuf, 0);
6541 cb->setVertexInput(0, 1, &vbufBinding);
6542 \endcode
6543 */
6544void QRhiCommandBuffer::setVertexInput(int startBinding, int bindingCount, const VertexInput *bindings,
6545 QRhiBuffer *indexBuf, quint32 indexOffset,
6546 IndexFormat indexFormat)
6547{
6548 m_rhi->setVertexInput(cb: this, startBinding, bindingCount, bindings, indexBuf, indexOffset, indexFormat);
6549}
6550
6551/*!
6552 Records setting the active viewport rectangle specified in \a viewport.
6553
6554 With backends where the underlying graphics API has scissoring always
6555 enabled, this function also sets the scissor to match the viewport whenever
6556 the active QRhiGraphicsPipeline does not have
6557 \l{QRhiGraphicsPipeline::UsesScissor}{UsesScissor} set.
6558
6559 \note QRhi assumes OpenGL-style viewport coordinates, meaning x and y are
6560 bottom-left.
6561
6562 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning
6563 between a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6564 */
6565void QRhiCommandBuffer::setViewport(const QRhiViewport &viewport)
6566{
6567 m_rhi->setViewport(cb: this, viewport);
6568}
6569
6570/*!
6571 Records setting the active scissor rectangle specified in \a scissor.
6572
6573 This can only be called when the bound pipeline has
6574 \l{QRhiGraphicsPipeline::UsesScissor}{UsesScissor} set. When the flag is
6575 set on the active pipeline, this function must be called because scissor
6576 testing will get enabled and so a scissor rectangle must be provided.
6577
6578 \note QRhi assumes OpenGL-style viewport coordinates, meaning x and y are
6579 bottom-left.
6580
6581 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning
6582 between a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6583 */
6584void QRhiCommandBuffer::setScissor(const QRhiScissor &scissor)
6585{
6586 m_rhi->setScissor(cb: this, scissor);
6587}
6588
6589/*!
6590 Records setting the active blend constants to \a c.
6591
6592 This can only be called when the bound pipeline has
6593 QRhiGraphicsPipeline::UsesBlendConstants set.
6594
6595 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning
6596 between a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6597 */
6598void QRhiCommandBuffer::setBlendConstants(const QColor &c)
6599{
6600 m_rhi->setBlendConstants(cb: this, c);
6601}
6602
6603/*!
6604 Records setting the active stencil reference value to \a refValue.
6605
6606 This can only be called when the bound pipeline has
6607 QRhiGraphicsPipeline::UsesStencilRef set.
6608
6609 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning between
6610 a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6611 */
6612void QRhiCommandBuffer::setStencilRef(quint32 refValue)
6613{
6614 m_rhi->setStencilRef(cb: this, refValue);
6615}
6616
6617/*!
6618 Records a non-indexed draw.
6619
6620 The number of vertices is specified in \a vertexCount. For instanced
6621 drawing set \a instanceCount to a value other than 1. \a firstVertex is the
6622 index of the first vertex to draw. When drawing multiple instances, the
6623 first instance ID is specified by \a firstInstance.
6624
6625 \note \a firstInstance may not be supported, and is ignored when the
6626 QRhi::BaseInstance feature is reported as not supported. The first ID is
6627 always 0 in that case.
6628
6629 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning
6630 between a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6631 */
6632void QRhiCommandBuffer::draw(quint32 vertexCount,
6633 quint32 instanceCount,
6634 quint32 firstVertex,
6635 quint32 firstInstance)
6636{
6637 m_rhi->draw(cb: this, vertexCount, instanceCount, firstVertex, firstInstance);
6638}
6639
6640/*!
6641 Records an indexed draw.
6642
6643 The number of vertices is specified in \a indexCount. \a firstIndex is the
6644 base index. The effective offset in the index buffer is given by
6645 \c{indexOffset + firstIndex * n} where \c n is 2 or 4 depending on the
6646 index element type. \c indexOffset is specified in setVertexInput().
6647
6648 \note The effective offset in the index buffer must be 4 byte aligned with
6649 some backends (for example, Metal). With these backends the
6650 \l{QRhi::NonFourAlignedEffectiveIndexBufferOffset}{NonFourAlignedEffectiveIndexBufferOffset}
6651 feature will be reported as not-supported.
6652
6653 For instanced drawing set \a instanceCount to a value other than 1. When
6654 drawing multiple instances, the first instance ID is specified by \a
6655 firstInstance.
6656
6657 \note \a firstInstance may not be supported, and is ignored when the
6658 QRhi::BaseInstance feature is reported as not supported. The first ID is
6659 always 0 in that case.
6660
6661 \a vertexOffset (also called \c{base vertex}) is a signed value that is
6662 added to the element index before indexing into the vertex buffer. Support
6663 for this is not always available, and the value is ignored when the feature
6664 QRhi::BaseVertex is reported as unsupported.
6665
6666 \note This function can only be called inside a render pass, meaning
6667 between a beginPass() and endPass() call.
6668 */
6669void QRhiCommandBuffer::drawIndexed(quint32 indexCount,
6670 quint32 instanceCount,
6671 quint32 firstIndex,
6672 qint32 vertexOffset,
6673 quint32 firstInstance)
6674{
6675 m_rhi->drawIndexed(cb: this, indexCount, instanceCount, firstIndex, vertexOffset, firstInstance);
6676}
6677
6678/*!
6679 Records a named debug group on the command buffer. This is shown in
6680 graphics debugging tools such as \l{https://renderdoc.org/}{RenderDoc} and
6681 \l{https://developer.apple.com/xcode/}{XCode}. The end of the grouping is
6682 indicated by debugMarkEnd().
6683
6684 \note Ignored when QRhi::DebugMarkers are not supported or
6685 QRhi::EnableDebugMarkers is not set.
6686
6687 \note Can be called anywhere within the frame, both inside and outside of passes.
6688 */
6689void QRhiCommandBuffer::debugMarkBegin(const QByteArray &name)
6690{
6691 m_rhi->debugMarkBegin(cb: this, name);
6692}
6693
6694/*!
6695 Records the end of a debug group.
6696
6697 \note Ignored when QRhi::DebugMarkers are not supported or
6698 QRhi::EnableDebugMarkers is not set.
6699
6700 \note Can be called anywhere within the frame, both inside and outside of passes.
6701 */
6702void QRhiCommandBuffer::debugMarkEnd()
6703{
6704 m_rhi->debugMarkEnd(cb: this);
6705}
6706
6707/*!
6708 Inserts a debug message \a msg into the command stream.
6709
6710 \note Ignored when QRhi::DebugMarkers are not supported or
6711 QRhi::EnableDebugMarkers is not set.
6712
6713 \note With some backends debugMarkMsg() is only supported inside a pass and
6714 is ignored when called outside a pass. With others it is recorded anywhere
6715 within the frame.
6716 */
6717void QRhiCommandBuffer::debugMarkMsg(const QByteArray &msg)
6718{
6719 m_rhi->debugMarkMsg(cb: this, msg);
6720}
6721
6722/*!
6723 Records starting a new compute pass.
6724
6725 \a resourceUpdates, when not null, specifies a resource update batch that
6726 is to be committed and then released.
6727
6728 \note Do not assume that any state or resource bindings persist between
6729 passes.
6730
6731 \note A compute pass can record setComputePipeline(), setShaderResources(),
6732 and dispatch() calls, not graphics ones. General functionality, such as,
6733 debug markers and beginExternal() is available both in render and compute
6734 passes.
6735
6736 \note Compute is only available when the \l{QRhi::Compute}{Compute} feature
6737 is reported as supported.
6738 */
6739void QRhiCommandBuffer::beginComputePass(QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *resourceUpdates, BeginPassFlags flags)
6740{
6741 m_rhi->beginComputePass(cb: this, resourceUpdates, flags);
6742}
6743
6744/*!
6745 Records ending the current compute pass.
6746
6747 \a resourceUpdates, when not null, specifies a resource update batch that
6748 is to be committed and then released.
6749 */
6750void QRhiCommandBuffer::endComputePass(QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *resourceUpdates)
6751{
6752 m_rhi->endComputePass(cb: this, resourceUpdates);
6753}
6754
6755/*!
6756 Records setting a new compute pipeline \a ps.
6757
6758 \note This function must be called before recording setShaderResources() or
6759 dispatch() commands on the command buffer.
6760
6761 \note QRhi will optimize out unnecessary invocations within a pass, so
6762 therefore overoptimizing to avoid calls to this function is not necessary
6763 on the applications' side.
6764
6765 \note This function can only be called inside a compute pass, meaning
6766 between a beginComputePass() and endComputePass() call.
6767 */
6768void QRhiCommandBuffer::setComputePipeline(QRhiComputePipeline *ps)
6769{
6770 m_rhi->setComputePipeline(cb: this, ps);
6771}
6772
6773/*!
6774 Records dispatching compute work items, with \a x, \a y, and \a z
6775 specifying the number of local workgroups in the corresponding dimension.
6776
6777 \note This function can only be called inside a compute pass, meaning
6778 between a beginComputePass() and endComputePass() call.
6779
6780 \note \a x, \a y, and \a z must fit the limits from the underlying graphics
6781 API implementation at run time. The maximum values are typically 65535.
6782
6783 \note Watch out for possible limits on the local workgroup size as well.
6784 This is specified in the shader, for example: \c{layout(local_size_x = 16,
6785 local_size_y = 16) in;}. For example, with OpenGL the minimum value mandated
6786 by the specification for the number of invocations in a single local work
6787 group (the product of \c local_size_x, \c local_size_y, and \c local_size_z)
6788 is 1024, while with OpenGL ES (3.1) the value may be as low as 128. This
6789 means that the example given above may be rejected by some OpenGL ES
6790 implementations as the number of invocations is 256.
6791 */
6792void QRhiCommandBuffer::dispatch(int x, int y, int z)
6793{
6794 m_rhi->dispatch(cb: this, x, y, z);
6795}
6796
6797/*!
6798 \return a pointer to a backend-specific QRhiNativeHandles subclass, such as
6799 QRhiVulkanCommandBufferNativeHandles. The returned value is \nullptr when
6800 exposing the underlying native resources is not supported by, or not
6801 applicable to, the backend.
6802
6803 \sa QRhiVulkanCommandBufferNativeHandles,
6804 QRhiMetalCommandBufferNativeHandles, beginExternal(), endExternal()
6805 */
6806const QRhiNativeHandles *QRhiCommandBuffer::nativeHandles()
6807{
6808 return m_rhi->nativeHandles(cb: this);
6809}
6810
6811/*!
6812 To be called when the application before the application is about to
6813 enqueue commands to the current pass' command buffer by calling graphics
6814 API functions directly.
6815
6816 \note This is only available when the intent was declared upfront in
6817 beginPass() or beginComputePass(). Therefore this function must only be
6818 called when the pass recording was started with specifying
6819 QRhiCommandBuffer::ExternalContent.
6820
6821 With Vulkan or Metal one can query the native command buffer or encoder
6822 objects via nativeHandles() and enqueue commands to them. With OpenGL or
6823 Direct3D 11 the (device) context can be retrieved from
6824 QRhi::nativeHandles(). However, this must never be done without ensuring
6825 the QRhiCommandBuffer's state stays up-to-date. Hence the requirement for
6826 wrapping any externally added command recording between beginExternal() and
6827 endExternal(). Conceptually this is the same as QPainter's
6828 \l{QPainter::beginNativePainting()}{beginNativePainting()} and
6829 \l{QPainter::endNativePainting()}{endNativePainting()} functions.
6830
6831 For OpenGL in particular, this function has an additional task: it makes
6832 sure the context is made current on the current thread.
6833
6834 \note Once beginExternal() is called, no other render pass specific
6835 functions (\c set* or \c draw*) must be called on the
6836 QRhiCommandBuffer until endExternal().
6837
6838 \warning Some backends may return a native command buffer object from
6839 QRhiCommandBuffer::nativeHandles() that is different from the primary one
6840 when inside a beginExternal() - endExternal() block. Therefore it is
6841 important to (re)query the native command buffer object after calling
6842 beginExternal(). In practical terms this means that with Vulkan for example
6843 the externally recorded Vulkan commands are placed onto a secondary command
6844 buffer (with VK_COMMAND_BUFFER_USAGE_RENDER_PASS_CONTINUE_BIT).
6845 nativeHandles() returns this secondary command buffer when called between
6846 begin/endExternal.
6847
6848 \sa endExternal(), nativeHandles()
6849 */
6850void QRhiCommandBuffer::beginExternal()
6851{
6852 m_rhi->beginExternal(cb: this);
6853}
6854
6855/*!
6856 To be called once the externally added commands are recorded to the command
6857 buffer or context.
6858
6859 \note All QRhiCommandBuffer state must be assumed as invalid after calling
6860 this function. Pipelines, vertex and index buffers, and other state must be
6861 set again if more draw calls are recorded after the external commands.
6862
6863 \sa beginExternal(), nativeHandles()
6864 */
6865void QRhiCommandBuffer::endExternal()
6866{
6867 m_rhi->endExternal(cb: this);
6868}
6869
6870/*!
6871 \return the value (typically an offset) \a v aligned to the uniform buffer
6872 alignment given by by ubufAlignment().
6873 */
6874int QRhi::ubufAligned(int v) const
6875{
6876 const int byteAlign = ubufAlignment();
6877 return (v + byteAlign - 1) & ~(byteAlign - 1);
6878}
6879
6880/*!
6881 \return the number of mip levels for a given \a size.
6882 */
6883int QRhi::mipLevelsForSize(const QSize &size) const
6884{
6885 return qFloor(v: std::log2(x: qMax(a: size.width(), b: size.height()))) + 1;
6886}
6887
6888/*!
6889 \return the texture image size for a given \a mipLevel, calculated based on
6890 the level 0 size given in \a baseLevelSize.
6891 */
6892QSize QRhi::sizeForMipLevel(int mipLevel, const QSize &baseLevelSize) const
6893{
6894 const int w = qMax(a: 1, b: baseLevelSize.width() >> mipLevel);
6895 const int h = qMax(a: 1, b: baseLevelSize.height() >> mipLevel);
6896 return QSize(w, h);
6897}
6898
6899/*!
6900 \return \c true if the underlying graphics API has the Y axis pointing up
6901 in framebuffers and images.
6902
6903 In practice this is \c true for OpenGL only.
6904 */
6905bool QRhi::isYUpInFramebuffer() const
6906{
6907 return d->isYUpInFramebuffer();
6908}
6909
6910/*!
6911 \return \c true if the underlying graphics API has the Y axis pointing up
6912 in its normalized device coordinate system.
6913
6914 In practice this is \c false for Vulkan only.
6915
6916 \note clipSpaceCorrMatrix() includes the corresponding adjustment (to make
6917 Y point up) in its returned matrix.
6918 */
6919bool QRhi::isYUpInNDC() const
6920{
6921 return d->isYUpInNDC();
6922}
6923
6924/*!
6925 \return \c true if the underlying graphics API uses depth range [0, 1] in
6926 clip space.
6927
6928 In practice this is \c false for OpenGL only, because OpenGL uses a
6929 post-projection depth range of [-1, 1]. (not to be confused with the
6930 NDC-to-window mapping controlled by glDepthRange(), which uses a range of
6931 [0, 1], unless overridden by the QRhiViewport) In some OpenGL versions
6932 glClipControl() could be used to change this, but the OpenGL backend of
6933 QRhi does not use that function as it is not available in OpenGL ES or
6934 OpenGL versions lower than 4.5.
6935
6936 \note clipSpaceCorrMatrix() includes the corresponding adjustment in its
6937 returned matrix. Therefore, many users of QRhi do not need to take any
6938 further measures apart from pre-multiplying their projection matrices with
6939 clipSpaceCorrMatrix(). However, some graphics techniques, such as, some
6940 types of shadow mapping, involve working with and outputting depth values
6941 in the shaders. These will need to query and take the value of this
6942 function into account as appropriate.
6943 */
6944bool QRhi::isClipDepthZeroToOne() const
6945{
6946 return d->isClipDepthZeroToOne();
6947}
6948
6949/*!
6950 \return a matrix that can be used to allow applications keep using
6951 OpenGL-targeted vertex data and perspective projection matrices (such as,
6952 the ones generated by QMatrix4x4::perspective()), regardless of the active
6953 QRhi backend.
6954
6955 In a typical renderer, once \c{this_matrix * mvp} is used instead of just
6956 \c mvp, vertex data with Y up and viewports with depth range 0 - 1 can be
6957 used without considering what backend (and so graphics API) is going to be
6958 used at run time. This way branching based on isYUpInNDC() and
6959 isClipDepthZeroToOne() can be avoided (although such logic may still become
6960 required when implementing certain advanced graphics techniques).
6961
6962 See
6963 \l{https://matthewwellings.com/blog/the-new-vulkan-coordinate-system/}{this
6964 page} for a discussion of the topic from Vulkan perspective.
6965 */
6966QMatrix4x4 QRhi::clipSpaceCorrMatrix() const
6967{
6968 return d->clipSpaceCorrMatrix();
6969}
6970
6971/*!
6972 \return \c true if the specified texture \a format modified by \a flags is
6973 supported.
6974
6975 The query is supported both for uncompressed and compressed formats.
6976 */
6977bool QRhi::isTextureFormatSupported(QRhiTexture::Format format, QRhiTexture::Flags flags) const
6978{
6979 return d->isTextureFormatSupported(format, flags);
6980}
6981
6982/*!
6983 \return \c true if the specified \a feature is supported
6984 */
6985bool QRhi::isFeatureSupported(QRhi::Feature feature) const
6986{
6987 return d->isFeatureSupported(feature);
6988}
6989
6990/*!
6991 \return the value for the specified resource \a limit.
6992
6993 The values are expected to be queried by the backends upon initialization,
6994 meaning calling this function is a light operation.
6995 */
6996int QRhi::resourceLimit(ResourceLimit limit) const
6997{
6998 return d->resourceLimit(limit);
6999}
7000
7001/*!
7002 \return a pointer to the backend-specific collection of native objects
7003 for the device, context, and similar concepts used by the backend.
7004
7005 Cast to QRhiVulkanNativeHandles, QRhiD3D11NativeHandles,
7006 QRhiGles2NativeHandles, QRhiMetalNativeHandles as appropriate.
7007
7008 \note No ownership is transferred, neither for the returned pointer nor for
7009 any native objects.
7010 */
7011const QRhiNativeHandles *QRhi::nativeHandles()
7012{
7013 return d->nativeHandles();
7014}
7015
7016/*!
7017 With OpenGL this makes the OpenGL context current on the current thread.
7018 The function has no effect with other backends.
7019
7020 Calling this function is relevant typically in Qt framework code, when one
7021 has to ensure external OpenGL code provided by the application can still
7022 run like it did before with direct usage of OpenGL, as long as the QRhi is
7023 using the OpenGL backend.
7024
7025 \return false when failed, similarly to QOpenGLContext::makeCurrent(). When
7026 the operation failed, isDeviceLost() can be called to determine if there
7027 was a loss of context situation. Such a check is equivalent to checking via
7028 QOpenGLContext::isValid().
7029
7030 \sa QOpenGLContext::makeCurrent(), QOpenGLContext::isValid()
7031 */
7032bool QRhi::makeThreadLocalNativeContextCurrent()
7033{
7034 return d->makeThreadLocalNativeContextCurrent();
7035}
7036
7037/*!
7038 Attempts to release resources in the backend's caches. This can include both
7039 CPU and GPU resources. Only memory and resources that can be recreated
7040 automatically are in scope. As an example, if the backend's
7041 QRhiGraphicsPipeline implementation maintains a cache of shader compilation
7042 results, calling this function leads to emptying that cache, thus
7043 potentially freeing up memory and graphics resources.
7044
7045 Calling this function makes sense in resource constrained environments,
7046 where at a certain point there is a need to ensure minimal resource usage,
7047 at the expense of performance.
7048 */
7049void QRhi::releaseCachedResources()
7050{
7051 d->releaseCachedResources();
7052
7053 for (QRhiResourceUpdateBatch *u : d->resUpdPool) {
7054 if (u->d->poolIndex < 0)
7055 u->d->trimOpLists();
7056 }
7057}
7058
7059/*!
7060 \return true if the graphics device was lost.
7061
7062 The loss of the device is typically detected in beginFrame(), endFrame() or
7063 QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize(), depending on the backend and the underlying
7064 native APIs. The most common is endFrame() because that is where presenting
7065 happens. With some backends QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize() can also fail
7066 due to a device loss. Therefore this function is provided as a generic way
7067 to check if a device loss was detected by a previous operation.
7068
7069 When the device is lost, no further operations should be done via the QRhi.
7070 Rather, all QRhi resources should be released, followed by destroying the
7071 QRhi. A new QRhi can then be attempted to be created. If successful, all
7072 graphics resources must be reinitialized. If not, try again later,
7073 repeatedly.
7074
7075 While simple applications may decide to not care about device loss,
7076 on the commonly used desktop platforms a device loss can happen
7077 due to a variety of reasons, including physically disconnecting the
7078 graphics adapter, disabling the device or driver, uninstalling or upgrading
7079 the graphics driver, or due to errors that lead to a graphics device reset.
7080 Some of these can happen under perfectly normal circumstances as well, for
7081 example the upgrade of the graphics driver to a newer version is a common
7082 task that can happen at any time while a Qt application is running. Users
7083 may very well expect applications to be able to survive this, even when the
7084 application is actively using an API like OpenGL or Direct3D.
7085
7086 Qt's own frameworks built on top of QRhi, such as, Qt Quick, can be
7087 expected to handle and take appropriate measures when a device loss occurs.
7088 If the data for graphics resources, such as textures and buffers, are still
7089 available on the CPU side, such an event may not be noticeable on the
7090 application level at all since graphics resources can seamlessly be
7091 reinitialized then. However, applications and libraries working directly
7092 with QRhi are expected to be prepared to check and handle device loss
7093 situations themselves.
7094
7095 \note With OpenGL, applications may need to opt-in to context reset
7096 notifications by setting QSurfaceFormat::ResetNotification on the
7097 QOpenGLContext. This is typically done by enabling the flag in
7098 QRhiGles2InitParams::format. Keep in mind however that some systems may
7099 generate context resets situations even when this flag is not set.
7100 */
7101bool QRhi::isDeviceLost() const
7102{
7103 return d->isDeviceLost();
7104}
7105
7106/*!
7107 \return a binary \a data blob with data collected from the
7108 QRhiGraphicsPipeline and QRhiComputePipeline successfully created during
7109 the lifetime of this QRhi.
7110
7111 By saving and then, in subsequent runs of the same application, reloading
7112 the cache data, pipeline and shader creation times can potentially be
7113 reduced. What exactly the cache and its serialized version includes is not
7114 specified, is always specific to the backend used, and in some cases also
7115 dependent on the particular implementation of the graphics API.
7116
7117 When the PipelineCacheDataLoadSave is reported as unsupported, the returned
7118 QByteArray is empty.
7119
7120 When the EnablePipelineCacheDataSave flag was not specified when calling
7121 create(), the returned QByteArray may be empty, even when the
7122 PipelineCacheDataLoadSave feature is supported.
7123
7124 When the returned data is non-empty, it is always specific to the Qt
7125 version and QRhi backend. In addition, in some cases there is a strong
7126 dependency to the graphics device and the exact driver version used. QRhi
7127 takes care of adding the appropriate header and safeguards that ensure that
7128 the data can always be passed safely to setPipelineCacheData(), therefore
7129 attempting to load data from a run on another version of a driver will be
7130 handled safely and gracefully.
7131
7132 \note Calling releaseCachedResources() may, depending on the backend, clear
7133 the pipeline data collected. A subsequent call to this function may then
7134 not return any data.
7135
7136 See EnablePipelineCacheDataSave for further details about this feature.
7137
7138 \note Minimize the number of calls to this function. Retrieving the blob is
7139 not always a cheap operation, and therefore this function should only be
7140 called at a low frequency, ideally only once e.g. when closing the
7141 application.
7142
7143 \sa setPipelineCacheData(), create(), isFeatureSupported()
7144 */
7145QByteArray QRhi::pipelineCacheData()
7146{
7147 return d->pipelineCacheData();
7148}
7149
7150/*!
7151 Loads \a data into the pipeline cache, when applicable.
7152
7153 When the PipelineCacheDataLoadSave is reported as unsupported, the function
7154 is safe to call, but has no effect.
7155
7156 The blob returned by pipelineCacheData() is always specific to the Qt
7157 version, the QRhi backend, and, in some cases, also to the graphics device,
7158 and a given version of the graphics driver. QRhi takes care of adding the
7159 appropriate header and safeguards that ensure that the data can always be
7160 passed safely to this function. If there is a mismatch, e.g. because the
7161 driver has been upgraded to a newer version, or because the data was
7162 generated from a different QRhi backend, a warning is printed and \a data
7163 is safely ignored.
7164
7165 With Vulkan, this maps directly to VkPipelineCache. Calling this function
7166 creates a new Vulkan pipeline cache object, with its initial data sourced
7167 from \a data. The pipeline cache object is then used by all subsequently
7168 created QRhiGraphicsPipeline and QRhiComputePipeline objects, thus
7169 accelerating, potentially, the pipeline creation.
7170
7171 With other APIs there is no real pipeline cache, but they may provide a
7172 cache with bytecode from shader compilations (D3D) or program binaries
7173 (OpenGL). In applications that perform a lot of shader compilation from
7174 source at run time this can provide a significant boost in subsequent runs
7175 if the "pipeline cache" is pre-seeded from an earlier run using this
7176 function.
7177
7178 \note QRhi cannot give any guarantees that \a data has an effect on the
7179 pipeline and shader creation performance. With APIs like Vulkan, it is up
7180 to the driver to decide if \a data is used for some purpose, or if it is
7181 ignored.
7182
7183 See EnablePipelineCacheDataSave for further details about this feature.
7184
7185 \note This mechanism offered by QRhi is independent of the drivers' own
7186 internal caching mechanism, if any. This means that, depending on the
7187 graphics API and its implementation, the exact effects of retrieving and
7188 then reloading \a data are not predictable. Improved performance may not be
7189 visible at all in case other caching mechanisms outside of Qt's control are
7190 already active.
7191
7192 \note Minimize the number of calls to this function. Loading the blob is
7193 not always a cheap operation, and therefore this function should only be
7194 called at a low frequency, ideally only once e.g. when starting the
7195 application.
7196
7197 \sa pipelineCacheData(), isFeatureSupported()
7198 */
7199void QRhi::setPipelineCacheData(const QByteArray &data)
7200{
7201 d->setPipelineCacheData(data);
7202}
7203
7204/*!
7205 \struct QRhiStats
7206 \internal
7207 \inmodule QtGui
7208
7209 \brief Statistics provided from the underlying memory allocator.
7210 */
7211
7212#ifndef QT_NO_DEBUG_STREAM
7213QDebug operator<<(QDebug dbg, const QRhiStats &info)
7214{
7215 QDebugStateSaver saver(dbg);
7216 dbg.nospace() << "QRhiStats("
7217 << "totalPipelineCreationTime=" << info.totalPipelineCreationTime
7218 << " blockCount=" << info.blockCount
7219 << " allocCount=" << info.allocCount
7220 << " usedBytes=" << info.usedBytes
7221 << " unusedBytes=" << info.unusedBytes
7222 << ')';
7223 return dbg;
7224}
7225#endif
7226
7227/*!
7228 Gathers and returns statistics about the timings and allocations of
7229 graphics resources.
7230
7231 Data about memory allocations is only available with some backends, where
7232 such operations are under Qt's control. With graphics APIs where there is
7233 no lower level control over resource memory allocations, this will never be
7234 supported and all relevant fields in the results are 0.
7235
7236 With Vulkan in particular, the values are valid always, and are queried
7237 from the underlying memory allocator library. This gives an insight into
7238 the memory requirements of the active buffers and textures.
7239
7240 Additional data, such as the total time in milliseconds spent in graphics
7241 and compute pipeline creation (which usually involves shader compilation or
7242 cache lookups, and potentially expensive processing) is available with most
7243 backends.
7244
7245 \note The elapsed times for operations such as pipeline creation may be
7246 affected by various factors. The results should not be compared between
7247 different backends since the concept of "pipelines" and what exactly
7248 happens under the hood during, for instance, a call to
7249 QRhiGraphicsPipeline::create(), differ greatly between graphics APIs and
7250 their implementations.
7251
7252 \note Additionally, many drivers will likely employ various caching
7253 strategies for shaders, programs, pipelines. (independently of Qt's own
7254 similar facilities, such as setPipelineCacheData() or the OpenGL-specific
7255 program binary disk cache). Because such internal behavior is transparent
7256 to the API client, Qt and QRhi have no knowledge or control over the exact
7257 caching strategy, persistency, invalidation of the cached data, etc. When
7258 reading timings, such as the time spent on pipeline creation, the potential
7259 presence and unspecified behavior of driver-level caching mechanisms should
7260 be kept in mind.
7261 */
7262QRhiStats QRhi::statistics() const
7263{
7264 return d->statistics();
7265}
7266
7267/*!
7268 \return a new graphics pipeline resource.
7269
7270 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7271 */
7272QRhiGraphicsPipeline *QRhi::newGraphicsPipeline()
7273{
7274 return d->createGraphicsPipeline();
7275}
7276
7277/*!
7278 \return a new compute pipeline resource.
7279
7280 \note Compute is only available when the \l{QRhi::Compute}{Compute} feature
7281 is reported as supported.
7282
7283 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7284 */
7285QRhiComputePipeline *QRhi::newComputePipeline()
7286{
7287 return d->createComputePipeline();
7288}
7289
7290/*!
7291 \return a new shader resource binding collection resource.
7292
7293 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7294 */
7295QRhiShaderResourceBindings *QRhi::newShaderResourceBindings()
7296{
7297 return d->createShaderResourceBindings();
7298}
7299
7300/*!
7301 \return a new buffer with the specified \a type, \a usage, and \a size.
7302
7303 \note Some \a usage and \a type combinations may not be supported by all
7304 backends. See \l{QRhiBuffer::UsageFlag}{UsageFlags} and
7305 \l{QRhi::NonDynamicUniformBuffers}{the feature flags}.
7306
7307 \note Backends may choose to allocate buffers bigger than \a size. This is
7308 done transparently to applications, so there are no special restrictions on
7309 the value of \a size. QRhiBuffer::size() will always report back the value
7310 that was requested in \a size.
7311
7312 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7313 */
7314QRhiBuffer *QRhi::newBuffer(QRhiBuffer::Type type,
7315 QRhiBuffer::UsageFlags usage,
7316 quint32 size)
7317{
7318 return d->createBuffer(type, usage, size);
7319}
7320
7321/*!
7322 \return a new renderbuffer with the specified \a type, \a pixelSize, \a
7323 sampleCount, and \a flags.
7324
7325 When \a backingFormatHint is set to a texture format other than
7326 QRhiTexture::UnknownFormat, it may be used by the backend to decide what
7327 format to use for the storage backing the renderbuffer.
7328
7329 \note \a backingFormatHint becomes relevant typically when multisampling
7330 and floating point texture formats are involved: rendering into a
7331 multisample QRhiRenderBuffer and then resolving into a non-RGBA8
7332 QRhiTexture implies (with some graphics APIs) that the storage backing the
7333 QRhiRenderBuffer uses the matching non-RGBA8 format. That means that
7334 passing a format like QRhiTexture::RGBA32F is important, because backends
7335 will typically opt for QRhiTexture::RGBA8 by default, which would then
7336 break later on due to attempting to set up RGBA8->RGBA32F multisample
7337 resolve in the color attachment(s) of the QRhiTextureRenderTarget.
7338
7339 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7340 */
7341QRhiRenderBuffer *QRhi::newRenderBuffer(QRhiRenderBuffer::Type type,
7342 const QSize &pixelSize,
7343 int sampleCount,
7344 QRhiRenderBuffer::Flags flags,
7345 QRhiTexture::Format backingFormatHint)
7346{
7347 return d->createRenderBuffer(type, pixelSize, sampleCount, flags, backingFormatHint);
7348}
7349
7350/*!
7351 \return a new 1D or 2D texture with the specified \a format, \a pixelSize, \a
7352 sampleCount, and \a flags.
7353
7354 A 1D texture array must have QRhiTexture::OneDimensional set in \a flags. This
7355 function will implicitly set this flag if the \a pixelSize height is 0.
7356
7357 \note \a format specifies the requested internal and external format,
7358 meaning the data to be uploaded to the texture will need to be in a
7359 compatible format, while the native texture may (but is not guaranteed to,
7360 in case of OpenGL at least) use this format internally.
7361
7362 \note 1D textures are only functional when the OneDimensionalTextures feature is
7363 reported as supported at run time. Further, mipmaps on 1D textures are only
7364 functional when the OneDimensionalTextureMipmaps feature is reported at run time.
7365
7366 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7367 */
7368QRhiTexture *QRhi::newTexture(QRhiTexture::Format format,
7369 const QSize &pixelSize,
7370 int sampleCount,
7371 QRhiTexture::Flags flags)
7372{
7373 if (pixelSize.height() == 0)
7374 flags |= QRhiTexture::OneDimensional;
7375
7376 return d->createTexture(format, pixelSize, depth: 1, arraySize: 0, sampleCount, flags);
7377}
7378
7379/*!
7380 \return a new 1D, 2D or 3D texture with the specified \a format, \a width, \a
7381 height, \a depth, \a sampleCount, and \a flags.
7382
7383 This overload is suitable for 3D textures because it allows specifying \a
7384 depth. A 3D texture must have QRhiTexture::ThreeDimensional set in \a
7385 flags, but using this overload that can be omitted because the flag is set
7386 implicitly whenever \a depth is greater than 0. For 1D, 2D and cube textures \a
7387 depth should be set to 0.
7388
7389 A 1D texture must have QRhiTexture::OneDimensional set in \a flags. This overload
7390 will implicitly set this flag if both \a height and \a depth are 0.
7391
7392 \note 3D textures are only functional when the ThreeDimensionalTextures
7393 feature is reported as supported at run time.
7394
7395 \note 1D textures are only functional when the OneDimensionalTextures feature is
7396 reported as supported at run time. Further, mipmaps on 1D textures are only
7397 functional when the OneDimensionalTextureMipmaps feature is reported at run time.
7398
7399 \overload
7400 */
7401QRhiTexture *QRhi::newTexture(QRhiTexture::Format format,
7402 int width, int height, int depth,
7403 int sampleCount,
7404 QRhiTexture::Flags flags)
7405{
7406 if (depth > 0)
7407 flags |= QRhiTexture::ThreeDimensional;
7408
7409 if (height == 0 && depth == 0)
7410 flags |= QRhiTexture::OneDimensional;
7411
7412 return d->createTexture(format, pixelSize: QSize(width, height), depth, arraySize: 0, sampleCount, flags);
7413}
7414
7415/*!
7416 \return a new 1D or 2D texture array with the specified \a format, \a arraySize,
7417 \a pixelSize, \a sampleCount, and \a flags.
7418
7419 This function implicitly sets QRhiTexture::TextureArray in \a flags.
7420
7421 A 1D texture array must have QRhiTexture::OneDimensional set in \a flags. This
7422 function will implicitly set this flag if the \a pixelSize height is 0.
7423
7424 \note Do not confuse texture arrays with arrays of textures. A QRhiTexture
7425 created by this function is usable with 1D or 2D array samplers in the shader, for
7426 example: \c{layout(binding = 1) uniform sampler2DArray texArr;}. Arrays of
7427 textures refers to a list of textures that are exposed to the shader via
7428 QRhiShaderResourceBinding::sampledTextures() and a count > 1, and declared
7429 in the shader for example like this: \c{layout(binding = 1) uniform
7430 sampler2D textures[4];}
7431
7432 \note This is only functional when the TextureArrays feature is reported as
7433 supported at run time.
7434
7435 \note 1D textures are only functional when the OneDimensionalTextures feature is
7436 reported as supported at run time. Further, mipmaps on 1D textures are only
7437 functional when the OneDimensionalTextureMipmaps feature is reported at run time.
7438
7439
7440 \sa newTexture()
7441 */
7442QRhiTexture *QRhi::newTextureArray(QRhiTexture::Format format,
7443 int arraySize,
7444 const QSize &pixelSize,
7445 int sampleCount,
7446 QRhiTexture::Flags flags)
7447{
7448 flags |= QRhiTexture::TextureArray;
7449
7450 if (pixelSize.height() == 0)
7451 flags |= QRhiTexture::OneDimensional;
7452
7453 return d->createTexture(format, pixelSize, depth: 1, arraySize, sampleCount, flags);
7454}
7455
7456/*!
7457 \return a new sampler with the specified magnification filter \a magFilter,
7458 minification filter \a minFilter, mipmapping mode \a mipmapMode, and the
7459 addressing (wrap) modes \a addressU, \a addressV, and \a addressW.
7460
7461 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7462 */
7463QRhiSampler *QRhi::newSampler(QRhiSampler::Filter magFilter,
7464 QRhiSampler::Filter minFilter,
7465 QRhiSampler::Filter mipmapMode,
7466 QRhiSampler::AddressMode addressU,
7467 QRhiSampler::AddressMode addressV,
7468 QRhiSampler::AddressMode addressW)
7469{
7470 return d->createSampler(magFilter, minFilter, mipmapMode, u: addressU, v: addressV, w: addressW);
7471}
7472
7473/*!
7474 \return a new texture render target with color and depth/stencil
7475 attachments given in \a desc, and with the specified \a flags.
7476
7477 \sa QRhiResource::destroy()
7478 */
7479
7480QRhiTextureRenderTarget *QRhi::newTextureRenderTarget(const QRhiTextureRenderTargetDescription &desc,
7481 QRhiTextureRenderTarget::Flags flags)
7482{
7483 return d->createTextureRenderTarget(desc, flags);
7484}
7485
7486/*!
7487 \return a new swapchain.
7488
7489 \sa QRhiResource::destroy(), QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize()
7490 */
7491QRhiSwapChain *QRhi::newSwapChain()
7492{
7493 return d->createSwapChain();
7494}
7495
7496/*!
7497 Starts a new frame targeting the next available buffer of \a swapChain.
7498
7499 A frame consists of resource updates and one or more render and compute
7500 passes.
7501
7502 \a flags can indicate certain special cases.
7503
7504 The high level pattern of rendering into a QWindow using a swapchain:
7505
7506 \list
7507
7508 \li Create a swapchain.
7509
7510 \li Call QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize() whenever the surface size is
7511 different than before.
7512
7513 \li Call QRhiSwapChain::destroy() on
7514 QPlatformSurfaceEvent::SurfaceAboutToBeDestroyed.
7515
7516 \li Then on every frame:
7517 \badcode
7518 beginFrame(sc);
7519 updates = nextResourceUpdateBatch();
7520 updates->...
7521 QRhiCommandBuffer *cb = sc->currentFrameCommandBuffer();
7522 cb->beginPass(sc->currentFrameRenderTarget(), colorClear, dsClear, updates);
7523 ...
7524 cb->endPass();
7525 ... // more passes as necessary
7526 endFrame(sc);
7527 \endcode
7528
7529 \endlist
7530
7531 \return QRhi::FrameOpSuccess on success, or another QRhi::FrameOpResult
7532 value on failure. Some of these should be treated as soft, "try again
7533 later" type of errors: When QRhi::FrameOpSwapChainOutOfDate is returned,
7534 the swapchain is to be resized or updated by calling
7535 QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize(). The application should then attempt to
7536 generate a new frame. QRhi::FrameOpDeviceLost means the graphics device is
7537 lost but this may also be recoverable by releasing all resources, including
7538 the QRhi itself, and then recreating all resources. See isDeviceLost() for
7539 further discussion.
7540
7541 \sa endFrame(), beginOffscreenFrame(), isDeviceLost()
7542 */
7543QRhi::FrameOpResult QRhi::beginFrame(QRhiSwapChain *swapChain, BeginFrameFlags flags)
7544{
7545 if (d->inFrame)
7546 qWarning(msg: "Attempted to call beginFrame() within a still active frame; ignored");
7547
7548 QRhi::FrameOpResult r = !d->inFrame ? d->beginFrame(swapChain, flags) : FrameOpSuccess;
7549 if (r == FrameOpSuccess)
7550 d->inFrame = true;
7551
7552 return r;
7553}
7554
7555/*!
7556 Ends, commits, and presents a frame that was started in the last
7557 beginFrame() on \a swapChain.
7558
7559 Double (or triple) buffering is managed internally by the QRhiSwapChain and
7560 QRhi.
7561
7562 \a flags can optionally be used to change the behavior in certain ways.
7563 Passing QRhi::SkipPresent skips queuing the Present command or calling
7564 swapBuffers.
7565
7566 \return QRhi::FrameOpSuccess on success, or another QRhi::FrameOpResult
7567 value on failure. Some of these should be treated as soft, "try again
7568 later" type of errors: When QRhi::FrameOpSwapChainOutOfDate is returned,
7569 the swapchain is to be resized or updated by calling
7570 QRhiSwapChain::createOrResize(). The application should then attempt to
7571 generate a new frame. QRhi::FrameOpDeviceLost means the graphics device is
7572 lost but this may also be recoverable by releasing all resources, including
7573 the QRhi itself, and then recreating all resources. See isDeviceLost() for
7574 further discussion.
7575
7576 \sa beginFrame(), isDeviceLost()
7577 */
7578QRhi::FrameOpResult QRhi::endFrame(QRhiSwapChain *swapChain, EndFrameFlags flags)
7579{
7580 if (!d->inFrame)
7581 qWarning(msg: "Attempted to call endFrame() without an active frame; ignored");
7582
7583 QRhi::FrameOpResult r = d->inFrame ? d->endFrame(swapChain, flags) : FrameOpSuccess;
7584 d->inFrame = false;
7585 // deleteLater is a high level QRhi concept the backends know
7586 // nothing about - handle it here.
7587 qDeleteAll(c: d->pendingDeleteResources);
7588 d->pendingDeleteResources.clear();
7589
7590 return r;
7591}
7592
7593/*!
7594 \return true when there is an active frame, meaning there was a
7595 beginFrame() (or beginOffscreenFrame()) with no corresponding endFrame()
7596 (or endOffscreenFrame()) yet.
7597
7598 \sa currentFrameSlot(), beginFrame(), endFrame()
7599 */
7600bool QRhi::isRecordingFrame() const
7601{
7602 return d->inFrame;
7603}
7604
7605/*!
7606 \return the current frame slot index while recording a frame. Unspecified
7607 when called outside an active frame (that is, when isRecordingFrame() is \c
7608 false).
7609
7610 With backends like Vulkan or Metal, it is the responsibility of the QRhi
7611 backend to block whenever starting a new frame and finding the CPU is
7612 already \c{FramesInFlight - 1} frames ahead of the GPU (because the command
7613 buffer submitted in frame no. \c{current} - \c{FramesInFlight} has not yet
7614 completed).
7615
7616 Resources that tend to change between frames (such as, the native buffer
7617 object backing a QRhiBuffer with type QRhiBuffer::Dynamic) exist in
7618 multiple versions, so that each frame, that can be submitted while a
7619 previous one is still being processed, works with its own copy, thus
7620 avoiding the need to stall the pipeline when preparing the frame. (The
7621 contents of a resource that may still be in use in the GPU should not be
7622 touched, but simply always waiting for the previous frame to finish would
7623 reduce GPU utilization and ultimately, performance and efficiency.)
7624
7625 Conceptually this is somewhat similar to copy-on-write schemes used by some
7626 C++ containers and other types. It may also be similar to what an OpenGL or
7627 Direct 3D 11 implementation performs internally for certain type of objects.
7628
7629 In practice, such double (or triple) buffering resources is realized in
7630 the Vulkan, Metal, and similar QRhi backends by having a fixed number of
7631 native resource (such as, VkBuffer) \c slots behind a QRhiResource. That
7632 can then be indexed by a frame slot index running 0, 1, ..,
7633 FramesInFlight-1, and then wrapping around.
7634
7635 All this is managed transparently to the users of QRhi. However,
7636 applications that integrate rendering done directly with the graphics API
7637 may want to perform a similar double or triple buffering of their own
7638 graphics resources. That is then most easily achieved by knowing the values
7639 of the maximum number of in-flight frames (retrievable via resourceLimit())
7640 and the current frame (slot) index (returned by this function).
7641
7642 \sa isRecordingFrame(), beginFrame(), endFrame()
7643 */
7644int QRhi::currentFrameSlot() const
7645{
7646 return d->currentFrameSlot;
7647}
7648
7649/*!
7650 Starts a new offscreen frame. Provides a command buffer suitable for
7651 recording rendering commands in \a cb. \a flags is used to indicate
7652 certain special cases, just like with beginFrame().
7653
7654 \note The QRhiCommandBuffer stored to *cb is not owned by the caller.
7655
7656 Rendering without a swapchain is possible as well. The typical use case is
7657 to use it in completely offscreen applications, e.g. to generate image
7658 sequences by rendering and reading back without ever showing a window.
7659
7660 Usage in on-screen applications (so beginFrame, endFrame,
7661 beginOffscreenFrame, endOffscreenFrame, beginFrame, ...) is possible too
7662 but it does reduce parallelism so it should be done only infrequently.
7663
7664 Offscreen frames do not let the CPU - potentially - generate another frame
7665 while the GPU is still processing the previous one. This has the side
7666 effect that if readbacks are scheduled, the results are guaranteed to be
7667 available once endOffscreenFrame() returns. That is not the case with
7668 frames targeting a swapchain.
7669
7670 The skeleton of rendering a frame without a swapchain and then reading the
7671 frame contents back could look like the following:
7672
7673 \badcode
7674 QRhiReadbackResult rbResult;
7675 QRhiCommandBuffer *cb;
7676 beginOffscreenFrame(&cb);
7677 beginPass
7678 ...
7679 u = nextResourceUpdateBatch();
7680 u->readBackTexture(rb, &rbResult);
7681 endPass(u);
7682 endOffscreenFrame();
7683 // image data available in rbResult
7684 \endcode
7685
7686 \sa endOffscreenFrame(), beginFrame()
7687 */
7688QRhi::FrameOpResult QRhi::beginOffscreenFrame(QRhiCommandBuffer **cb, BeginFrameFlags flags)
7689{
7690 if (d->inFrame)
7691 qWarning(msg: "Attempted to call beginOffscreenFrame() within a still active frame; ignored");
7692
7693 QRhi::FrameOpResult r = !d->inFrame ? d->beginOffscreenFrame(cb, flags) : FrameOpSuccess;
7694 if (r == FrameOpSuccess)
7695 d->inFrame = true;
7696
7697 return r;
7698}
7699
7700/*!
7701 Ends and waits for the offscreen frame.
7702
7703 \sa beginOffscreenFrame()
7704 */
7705QRhi::FrameOpResult QRhi::endOffscreenFrame(EndFrameFlags flags)
7706{
7707 if (!d->inFrame)
7708 qWarning(msg: "Attempted to call endOffscreenFrame() without an active frame; ignored");
7709
7710 QRhi::FrameOpResult r = d->inFrame ? d->endOffscreenFrame(flags) : FrameOpSuccess;
7711 d->inFrame = false;
7712 qDeleteAll(c: d->pendingDeleteResources);
7713 d->pendingDeleteResources.clear();
7714
7715 return r;
7716}
7717
7718/*!
7719 Waits for any work on the graphics queue (where applicable) to complete,
7720 then executes all deferred operations, like completing readbacks and
7721 resource releases. Can be called inside and outside of a frame, but not
7722 inside a pass. Inside a frame it implies submitting any work on the
7723 command buffer.
7724
7725 \note Avoid this function. One case where it may be needed is when the
7726 results of an enqueued readback in a swapchain-based frame are needed at a
7727 fixed given point and so waiting for the results is desired.
7728 */
7729QRhi::FrameOpResult QRhi::finish()
7730{
7731 return d->finish();
7732}
7733
7734/*!
7735 \return the list of supported sample counts.
7736
7737 A typical example would be (1, 2, 4, 8).
7738
7739 With some backend this list of supported values is fixed in advance, while
7740 with some others the (physical) device properties indicate what is
7741 supported at run time.
7742 */
7743QList<int> QRhi::supportedSampleCounts() const
7744{
7745 return d->supportedSampleCounts();
7746}
7747
7748/*!
7749 \return the minimum uniform buffer offset alignment in bytes. This is
7750 typically 256.
7751
7752 Attempting to bind a uniform buffer region with an offset not aligned to
7753 this value will lead to failures depending on the backend and the
7754 underlying graphics API.
7755
7756 \sa ubufAligned()
7757 */
7758int QRhi::ubufAlignment() const
7759{
7760 return d->ubufAlignment();
7761}
7762
7763Q_CONSTINIT static QBasicAtomicInteger<QRhiGlobalObjectIdGenerator::Type> counter = Q_BASIC_ATOMIC_INITIALIZER(0);
7764
7765QRhiGlobalObjectIdGenerator::Type QRhiGlobalObjectIdGenerator::newId()
7766{
7767 return counter.fetchAndAddRelaxed(valueToAdd: 1) + 1;
7768}
7769
7770bool QRhiPassResourceTracker::isEmpty() const
7771{
7772 return m_buffers.isEmpty() && m_textures.isEmpty();
7773}
7774
7775void QRhiPassResourceTracker::reset()
7776{
7777 m_buffers.clear();
7778 m_textures.clear();
7779}
7780
7781static inline QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufferStage earlierStage(QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufferStage a,
7782 QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufferStage b)
7783{
7784 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufferStage(qMin(a: int(a), b: int(b)));
7785}
7786
7787void QRhiPassResourceTracker::registerBuffer(QRhiBuffer *buf, int slot, BufferAccess *access, BufferStage *stage,
7788 const UsageState &state)
7789{
7790 auto it = m_buffers.find(key: buf);
7791 if (it != m_buffers.end()) {
7792 if (it->access != *access) {
7793 const QByteArray name = buf->name();
7794 qWarning(msg: "Buffer %p (%s) used with different accesses within the same pass, this is not allowed.",
7795 buf, name.constData());
7796 return;
7797 }
7798 if (it->stage != *stage) {
7799 it->stage = earlierStage(a: it->stage, b: *stage);
7800 *stage = it->stage;
7801 }
7802 return;
7803 }
7804
7805 Buffer b;
7806 b.slot = slot;
7807 b.access = *access;
7808 b.stage = *stage;
7809 b.stateAtPassBegin = state; // first use -> initial state
7810 m_buffers.insert(key: buf, value: b);
7811}
7812
7813static inline QRhiPassResourceTracker::TextureStage earlierStage(QRhiPassResourceTracker::TextureStage a,
7814 QRhiPassResourceTracker::TextureStage b)
7815{
7816 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::TextureStage(qMin(a: int(a), b: int(b)));
7817}
7818
7819static inline bool isImageLoadStore(QRhiPassResourceTracker::TextureAccess access)
7820{
7821 return access == QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexStorageLoad
7822 || access == QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexStorageStore
7823 || access == QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexStorageLoadStore;
7824}
7825
7826void QRhiPassResourceTracker::registerTexture(QRhiTexture *tex, TextureAccess *access, TextureStage *stage,
7827 const UsageState &state)
7828{
7829 auto it = m_textures.find(key: tex);
7830 if (it != m_textures.end()) {
7831 if (it->access != *access) {
7832 // Different subresources of a texture may be used for both load
7833 // and store in the same pass. (think reading from one mip level
7834 // and writing to another one in a compute shader) This we can
7835 // handle by treating the entire resource as read-write.
7836 if (isImageLoadStore(access: it->access) && isImageLoadStore(access: *access)) {
7837 it->access = QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexStorageLoadStore;
7838 *access = it->access;
7839 } else {
7840 const QByteArray name = tex->name();
7841 qWarning(msg: "Texture %p (%s) used with different accesses within the same pass, this is not allowed.",
7842 tex, name.constData());
7843 }
7844 }
7845 if (it->stage != *stage) {
7846 it->stage = earlierStage(a: it->stage, b: *stage);
7847 *stage = it->stage;
7848 }
7849 return;
7850 }
7851
7852 Texture t;
7853 t.access = *access;
7854 t.stage = *stage;
7855 t.stateAtPassBegin = state; // first use -> initial state
7856 m_textures.insert(key: tex, value: t);
7857}
7858
7859QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufferStage QRhiPassResourceTracker::toPassTrackerBufferStage(QRhiShaderResourceBinding::StageFlags stages)
7860{
7861 // pick the earlier stage (as this is going to be dstAccessMask)
7862 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::VertexStage))
7863 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufVertexStage;
7864 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::TessellationControlStage))
7865 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufTCStage;
7866 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::TessellationEvaluationStage))
7867 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufTEStage;
7868 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::FragmentStage))
7869 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufFragmentStage;
7870 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::ComputeStage))
7871 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufComputeStage;
7872 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::GeometryStage))
7873 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufGeometryStage;
7874
7875 Q_UNREACHABLE_RETURN(QRhiPassResourceTracker::BufVertexStage);
7876}
7877
7878QRhiPassResourceTracker::TextureStage QRhiPassResourceTracker::toPassTrackerTextureStage(QRhiShaderResourceBinding::StageFlags stages)
7879{
7880 // pick the earlier stage (as this is going to be dstAccessMask)
7881 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::VertexStage))
7882 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexVertexStage;
7883 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::TessellationControlStage))
7884 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexTCStage;
7885 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::TessellationEvaluationStage))
7886 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexTEStage;
7887 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::FragmentStage))
7888 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexFragmentStage;
7889 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::ComputeStage))
7890 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexComputeStage;
7891 if (stages.testFlag(flag: QRhiShaderResourceBinding::GeometryStage))
7892 return QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexGeometryStage;
7893
7894 Q_UNREACHABLE_RETURN(QRhiPassResourceTracker::TexVertexStage);
7895}
7896
7897QT_END_NAMESPACE
7898
